{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2019}} {{Multiple issues| {{advert|date=May 2018}} {{POV check|date=April 2014}} }} {{Infobox automobile | name = Chevrolet Equinox | image = 2018 Chevrolet Equinox front 1.22.19.jpg | manufacturer = [[General Motors]] | production = 2004–present | model_years = 2005–present | class = [[Mid-size car|Mid-size]] [[Crossover SUV]] (2004-2017)
[[Compact car|Compact]] [[Crossover SUV]] (from 2017) | body_style = 5-door [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]] | layout = {{Plainlist| *[[Front-engine, front-wheel-drive layout|FF layout]] *[[Front-engine, four-wheel-drive layout|AWD layout]] }} | predecessor = {{Plainlist| *[[Chevrolet Tracker (Americas)|Chevrolet Tracker]] *[[Chevrolet S-10 Blazer|Chevrolet Blazer]] *[[Chevrolet TrailBlazer]] *[[Chevrolet Captiva]] *[[Chevrolet Captiva Sport]] }} | successor = [[Chevrolet Blazer (crossover)|Chevrolet Blazer]] (for 2004–2017 models) }} The '''Chevrolet Equinox''' is a series of [[Mid-size car|mid-size]], later [[Compact sport utility vehicle|compact crossover SUV]] from [[Chevrolet]], introduced in 2004 for the 2005 model year. {{TOC left}} {{clear}} == First generation (2005–2009) == {{See also|Pontiac Torrent}} {{Infobox automobile | name = First generation | aka = [[Pontiac Torrent]] (2005-2009) | image = 1st Chevrolet Equinox LS.jpg | production = 2004-2009 | model_year = {{plainlist| *2005-2009 (Equinox) *2006-2009 (Torrent) }} | assembly = [[Ingersoll, Ontario]] | class = [[Mid-size car|Mid-size]] [[Crossover (automobile)|crossover SUV]] | platform = [[GM Theta platform|GM Theta platform/GMT191]] | related = {{Plainlist| *[[GM HydroGen4]] *[[Opel Antara]] *[[Saturn Vue]] *[[Suzuki XL7]] *[[Pontiac Torrent]] }} | engine = {{Plainlist| *3.4 L ''[[General Motors 60° V6 engine#LNJ|LNJ]]'' [[V6 engine|V6]]{{cite press|publisher=GM|date=August 1, 2007|title=2008 Pontiac Torrent|url=http://archives.media.gm.com/us/pontiac/en/product_services/r_cars/r_c_torrent/08index.html}} *3.6 L ''[[GM High Feature engine#LY7|LY7]]'' V6 }} | transmission = {{Plainlist| *5-speed [[Aisin AF33 transmission|Aisin ''AF33'']] [[automatic transmission|automatic]] *6-speed [[GM-Ford 6-speed automatic transmission|GM-Ford ''6T70'']] automatic }} | wheelbase = {{convert|2857|mm|in|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} | length = {{convert|188.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|71.4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|68.3|-|69.3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} }} [[File:Chevrolet Equinox LS AWD 2006.jpg|thumb|left|Rear view]] [[File:Chevrolet Equinox Fuel Cell interior.jpg|thumb|left|Interior]] The Chevrolet Equinox was introduced in 2004 for the 2005 model year. Originally, the Equinox was shown at the [[Detroit Auto Show#2003|2003 Detroit Auto Show]]. The Pontiac Torrent was introduced in 2005 for the 2006 model year. The Pontiac Torrent was originally shown at the [[Los Angeles Auto Show#2005|2005 Los Angeles Auto Show]] Riding on the [[GM Theta platform]], the [[monocoque|unibody]] is mechanically similar to the [[Saturn Vue]] and the [[Suzuki XL7]]. However, the Equinox and the Torrent are larger than the Vue, riding on a {{convert|112.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} wheelbase, {{convert|5.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} longer than the Vue. [[Front-wheel drive]] is standard, with optional [[four-wheel drive|all-wheel drive]]. They are not designed for serious off-roading like the truck-based [[Chevrolet Tahoe]] and [[Chevrolet TrailBlazer]]. For the 2006 model year, GM updated the Equinox for the first time, adding GM badges on the front doors, as well as recoloring the dashboard panel from gray to black. The first generation Equinox and Torrent were produced exclusively at the [[CAMI Automotive]] [[General Motors|GM]]/[[Suzuki]] [[joint venture]] plant in [[Ingersoll, Ontario]], Canada. The 3.4 L ''[[LNJ]]'' [[V6 engine]] is made in [[People's Republic of China|China]] (by [[SAIC-GM-Wuling|Shanghai GM]]), while the [[Aisin AF33 transmission]] is made in [[Japan]]. Starting with the 2008 model year, the Equinox Sport and Pontiac GXP were available with a 3.6 L V6 engine that was made in the [[United States]]. Production ended in May 2009. The Chevrolet Equinox was not sold in [[Mexico]] during the 2009 model year. === Pontiac Torrent === [[File:Pontiac Torrent -- 08-28-2009.jpg|thumb|left|Pontiac Torrent]] While the Torrent shares its basic body structure and mechanicals with the Equinox, it does have a different front and rear styling. The suspension (''FE2'') and electronic power steering were both modified to feel firmer and sportier. The Torrent was discontinued after the 2009 model year as part of the discontinuation of the [[Pontiac]] brand, with the last one rolling off the assembly line on September 2, 2009. A [[Buick]] Theta crossover SUV was to be made, effectively taking place of the Pontiac Torrent.{{cite web|first=Craig |last=Migliori |work=AutoWeek |date=August 19, 2009 |url=http://www.autoweek.com/article/20090819/CARNEWS/908199989 |title=General Motors cancels plans for Buick compact crossover |accessdate=2009-08-19 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090821190742/http://www.autoweek.com/article/20090819/CARNEWS/908199989 |archivedate=August 21, 2009 }} Instead, GM replaced the Torrent with the [[GMC Terrain]], which shares the Theta platform with the second generation Equinox. === Engines === {| class="wikitable" |- !Years !Engine !Power !Torque |- |2005–2009||3.4 L ''[[GM 60-Degree V6 engine#LNJ|LNJ]]'' [[V6 engine|V6]]||{{convert|185|hp|kW|abbr=on}}||{{convert|210|lb·ft|0|abbr=on}} |- |2008–2009||3.6 L ''[[GM High Feature engine#LY7|LY7]]'' V6||{{convert|264|hp|kW|abbr=on}}||{{convert|250|lb·ft|0|abbr=on}} |} === Sport Trims === [[File:2008 Pontiac Torrent GXP.jpg|thumb|2008 Pontiac Torrent GXP]] For the 2008 and 2009 model years, [[General Motors|GM]] offered sportier versions of the Equinox and Torrent; called '''Sport''' and '''GXP''', respectively. Featuring the new 3.6 ''[[General Motors High Feature engine#LY7|LY7]]'' [[Overhead camshaft#Dual overhead camshaft|DOHC]] [[V6 engine]] paired with a new 6-speed [[automatic transmission]] (with Manual Tap Up/Down shifting capability). This larger and more powerful ({{convert|264|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} or 40% increase) engine allowed acceleration from 0 to {{convert|60|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}} in under seven seconds. These models also received a {{convert|1|in|mm|abbr=on}} lowered ride height with a performance-tuned suspension and unique front and rear body kits. The lower stance is accented by the 18 inch 5-spoke chrome wheels and the absence of the roof rack, giving them a smoother design flow compared to the standard models. The GXP had twin hood scoops, hydraulic power-assisted steering (as opposed to the electric power-assisted standard Torrent), improved interior trim with unique gauges, and a dual chrome-tipped exhaust. Optional features included [[navigation system|navigation]], heated sport leather seats, DVD entertainment system, a sunroof and all-wheel drive.{{cite web|url=http://www.leftlanenews.com/2008-chevrolet-equinox-sport-revealed.html |title=2008 Chevrolet Equinox Sport |publisher=Leftlanenews.com |date=2006-12-14 |accessdate=2009-10-16}} [[General Motors|GM]] stated the Equinox Sport was the first vehicle to reflect its more cautious naming standards. Instead of using the [[Super Sport (Chevrolet)|Super Sport]] badge as it had in the past on higher performance vehicles (such as this one), GM opted to reserve the SS nomenclature for special models worthy of its namesake.{{cite web|url=http://www.leftlanenews.com/gm-overusing-ss-label-a-mistake.html |title=GM: Overusing SS label a mistake |publisher=Leftlanenews.com |date=2006-12-15 |accessdate=2009-10-16}} GM also prominently promoted the GXP in television advertisements by touting its horsepower advantage over the BMW X3, in an effort to brand Pontiac more as a direct, low-cost rival to BMW. === Equinox LTZ === [[File:Nox chrome.jpg|thumb|right|Chevrolet Equinox LTZ]] An Equinox LTZ model was added{{When|date=June 2018}}. It is differentiated by its 17-inch chrome-clad aluminum wheels, bright chrome door handles and bright chrome luggage rack side rail inserts. Standard interior features include heated front seats, leather seating inserts, head [[Side curtain airbag|curtain side impact air bags]], AM/FM stereo with six-disc in-dash CD changer and [[MP3]] CD playback capability, and a [[Pioneer Corporation|Pioneer]] premium seven-speaker audio system. Equinox LTZ came with the same ride and handling package as LS and LT models. === 2008 model features === Changes to 2008 Equinox and Torrent models included the relocation of the [[compass]] readout from the inside rearview mirror to the driver information center (on models so-equipped), and three new exterior colors: Navy Blue Metallic, Black Granite Metallic, and Golden Teal Metallic. [[OnStar]] was standard on the 2008 Equinox and Torrent. This system included for Turn-by-Turn [[Navigation]], the first factory-installed, fully integrated GPS navigation system from OnStar. The 2008 models included an enhanced ride and handling package with stiffer shocks, bushings, and tuned spring rates. Four-wheel disc brakes with [[Anti-lock braking system|ABS]] and tire pressure monitoring system was standard. An Electronic Trailer Sway Control was introduced that integrated into the standard [[StabiliTrak]] system. This can detect the occurrence of trailer sway that may be caused by improper trailer weight balance or excessive vehicle speed. If the trailer begins to sway, [[StabiliTrak]] will apply brakes individually, independent of the driver controlling the brake pedal, to assist stabilizing the vehicle. Under these conditions a light will flash to signal the driver to reduce vehicle speed. If trailer sway continues, the system will reduce engine torque to reduce the speed of the vehicle. Head curtain side air bags were optional. === Olympic-themed Special Editions === [[File:'08 Pontiac Torrent Podium Edition (Montreal).JPG|thumb|2008 Pontiac Torrent Podium Edition at the [[Montreal Auto Show]]]] For the 2008 model year, in tribute to the [[Vancouver 2010]] [[Winter Olympic Games]], the Equinox and Torrent each received a special edition; the '''Team Canada Edition''' and the '''Podium Edition''', respectively. This package added chrome-clad wheels, sunroof, premium sound system, and special badging.{{cite web | url = http://www.gm.ca/gm/english/vehicles/chevrolet/equinox/overview | title = 2009 Chevrolet Equinox Overview Page | publisher = GM Canada | accessdate = 2009-05-22}} These trims were sold only in Canada. {{clear}} == Second generation (2010–2017) == {{Infobox automobile | image = 2011 Chevrolet Equinox LTZ -- 03-09-2011.jpg | name = Second generation | production = June 2009–2017 | model_years = 2010-2017 | assembly = {{Plainlist| *Canada: [[Ingersoll, Ontario]] / [[Oshawa, Ontario]] *USA: [[Spring Hill, Tennessee]] (May 2013–2015){{cite web|url= http://media.gm.com/media/us/en/gm/company_info/facilities/assembly/springhill.html |title=Spring Hill Manufacturing |publisher=GM |date=2015-10-29 |accessdate=2015-12-21}} }} | class = [[Mid-size car|Mid-size]] [[Crossover (automobile)|crossover SUV]] | platform = [[GM Theta platform|GM Theta platform/GMT192]] | related = {{Plainlist| *[[GMC Terrain]] *[[Cadillac SRX]] *[[Saab 9-4X]] *[[Saturn Vue]] *[[Pontiac Torrent]] *[[Opel Antara]] *[[Suzuki XL7]] }} | designer = Ron Aselton{{cite web|title=Vehicle body|url=https://patents.google.com/patent/USD608691S1|accessdate=20 September 2016}} | engine = {{Plainlist| *2.4 L ''[[GM Ecotec engine#LAF|LAF]]'' [[Inline-four engine|I4]] *2.4 L ''[[GM Ecotec engine#LEA|LEA]]'' I4 *3.0 L [[GM High Feature engine#LF1|''LF1'' or ''LFW'']] [[V6 engine|V6]] *3.6 L ''[[GM High Feature engine#LFX|LFX]]'' V6 }} | transmission = 6-speed [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] | width = {{convert|72.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|66.3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|187.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | wheelbase = {{convert|2857|mm|in|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} }} [[File:Chevrolet Equinox 3.6 LTZ AWD 2011 (15200556529).jpg|thumb|left|Chevrolet Equinox LTZ AWD (Chile)]] The second generation Equinox was announced by GM on December 21, 2008, and debuted at the 2009 [[North American International Auto Show]] in Detroit.{{cite web|url=http://www.automoblog.net/2008/12/22/2010-chevy-equinox/ |title=2010 Chevy Equinox Unveiled |work=Automoblog.net |accessdate=2008-12-23 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606081109/http://www.automoblog.net/2008/12/22/2010-chevy-equinox/ |archivedate=June 6, 2011 }}{{cite web |url= http://www.caranddriver.com/news/auto_shows/2009_detroit_auto_show_naias_auto_shows/production_debuts/2010_chevrolet_equinox_auto_shows |title= 2010 chevrolet equinox auto shows |accessdate= 2009-02-26 |url-status= dead |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121031161923/http://www.caranddriver.com/news/2010-chevrolet-equinox-auto-shows |archivedate= 2012-10-31 |date= 2008-12-19 }} The 2010 Equinox went on sale in June 2009. It is built on a stiffened version of the same "Theta" platform used in the previous model. The second generation Equinox was built with a pair of upgraded [[gasoline direct injection]] engines, with better fuel economy claimed by GM. Earlier 2010 models had the GM badges on the front doors, but were later deleted.{{cite web|url= http://www.detnews.com/article/20090825/AUTO01/908250320/1148/rss25 |title=GM to drop corporate logo from vehicles |publisher=The Detroit News |date= |accessdate=2010-09-30}}{{dead link|date=February 2016}} Marketing of Chevrolet Equinox resumed in [[Mexico]] during late November 2009, for the 2010 model year after a year of absence. Sales of the Chevrolet Equinox to Mexico were stopped after the 2011 model year. However, in October 2015 the Equinox was reintroduced in Mexico to replace the Captiva Sport for the 2016 model year. The second generation Equinox is available standard with a 2.4-liter [[Inline-four engine|I4]] engine produced in [[Tonawanda (city), New York|Tonawanda, New York]] and [[Spring Hill Manufacturing|Spring Hill, Tennessee]], with a 3.0-liter V6 engine is available as an option.{{cite web|url=http://wot.motortrend.com/6509317/auto-news/2010-chevrolet-equinox-gets-32-mpg-highway-in-early-tests-awaits-epa-validation/index.html |title=2010 2010 Chevrolet Equinox Gets 32 MPG (13.6km/L) Highway in Early Tests; Awaits EPA Validation |publisher=MotorTrend.com |accessdate=2009-05-04 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090614184912/http://wot.motortrend.com/6509317/auto-news/2010-chevrolet-equinox-gets-32-mpg-highway-in-early-tests-awaits-epa-validation/index.html |archivedate=June 14, 2009 }} Both powertrains contain six-speed automatics and optional all-wheel-drive systems, with front-wheel-drive being standard.{{cite web|url=http://www.automoblog.net/2009/09/19/2010-chevy-equinox-review/|title=2010 Chevy Equinox Review|publisher=Automoblog.net|date=2009-09-19}} The second generation Equinox is Chevrolet's third best-selling vehicle in North America, after the [[Chevrolet Silverado|Silverado]] and [[Chevrolet Cruze|Cruze]], respectively.{{cite web |url=http://www.caranddriver.com/news/2016-chevrolet-equinox-crossover-photos-and-info-news |title=2016 Chevrolet Equinox Unveiled: New Cosmetics and Gadgets |work=Car and Driver |last=Wendler |first=Andrew |date=Feb 2015 |accessdate=2015-06-28}} === Model year changes === ====2013==== For the 2013 model year, a new direct-injected 3.6L V-6 became available on LT and LTZ models, providing 301 horsepower (225 kW) and 272 lb.-ft. of torque (369 Nm). This engine offered 14 percent more horsepower and 22 percent more torque than the previous 3.0L V-6, with the same [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|EPA]]-estimated fuel economy. A new FE2 suspension package was offered, matched with the 3.6L V-6 and packaged with 18-inch or 19-inch chrome-clad wheels on LTZ models. The 2013 model year introduced [[Chevrolet MyLink]] telematics system to the Equinox. Additional new features for 2013 models included a dual-player DVD entertainment system, a Power convenience package, a safety package with [[lane departure warning system]], [[forward collision warning]] and [[rear park assist]], as well as three new exterior colors; Champagne Silver Metallic, Atlantis Metallic and Tungsten Metallic.{{cite press release|url= http://media.gm.com/content/media/us/en/chevrolet/vehicles/Equinox/2013.html |title=Chevrolet Equinox - 2013 |publisher=Media.gm.com |date=2014-12-15 |accessdate=2015-06-26}} ====2014==== For the 2014 model year, chrome-clad wheels became standard on LTZ models, and two new exterior colors, Red Rock Metallic and Silver Topaz Metallic, became available. ====2015==== The 2015 model year saw the addition of OnStar with 4G LTE and built-in Wi-Fi hotspot, which included a 3GB/three-month data trial, standard on LT and LTZ models, with navigation available on LTZ and 2LT. Blue Velvet Metallic and Sea Grass Metallic were added to the list of available exterior colors. ====2016==== For 2016, the Chevrolet Equinox received its first mid-cycle refresh along with its cousin the [[GMC Terrain]], which was unveiled at the 2015 [[Chicago Auto Show]] on February 12, 2015. The refreshed Equinox received a new [[Grille (motor vehicle)|grille]], headlights and front fascia as well as reworked tail lights. In the interior, the Equinox gained a new gear selector, a second storage shelf underneath the dashboard, as well as deletion of the door lock buttons from the dashboard. A new level trim, L, was introduced as the base level, as LS was made the second level, followed by LT and another new trim Premier (replacing LTZ for 2017). Both LT1, LT2, and LTZ level trims were discontinued. Premier took the place of LTZ. [[File:'16 Chevrolet Equinox.jpg|thumb|2016 Chevrolet Equinox]] More features are in LTZ and LS trims, while LT is unchanged from 2015. However, the OnStar delete feature was removed along with the discontinuation of five color palates, the CD/AM/FM/MP3/WMA Playback audio system, the rear seat entertainment system and one set of 19-inch chrome wheels. In its place are the Chevrolet MyLink system that became standard on all trims, four new color palates, and new 17- and 18-inch wheel trims.{{cite web|url= http://gmauthority.com/blog/2015/06/2016-chevy-equinox-gets-new-colors-equipment-changes-and-more |title=2016 Chevy Equinox Gets New Colors, Equipment Changes, And More |work=GM Authority|date=June 8, 2015 |first=Chris |last=Ecclestone |accessdate=February 27, 2016}} === Engines === {| class="wikitable" |- !Years !Engine !Power !Torque |- |2010–2011||2.4 L ''[[GM Ecotec engine#LAF|Ecotec LAF]]'' [[inline-four engine|I4]]||182 [[Horsepower|hp]] (136 [[Kilowatt|kW]])||172 [[Foot pound force|lb·ft]] (233 [[Newton metre|N·m]]) |- |2012–2017||2.4 L ''[[GM Ecotec engine#LEA|Ecotec LEA]]'' I4||182 hp (136 kW||172 lb·ft (233 N·m) |- |2010–2012||3.0 L ''[[GM High Feature engine#LF1|High Feature LF1 or LFW]]'' [[V6 engine|V6]]||264 hp (197 kW)||222 lb·ft (301 N·m) |- |2013–2017||3.6 L ''[[GM High Feature engine#LXF|High Feature LFX]]'' V6||301 hp (224 kW)||272 lb·ft (369 N·m) |} ===EPA fuel economy ratings === Skepticism about the Equinox's EPA fuel economy ratings has been raised after a number of road tests at the model's launch achieved 20 to 30% lower fuel economy than the official EPA ratings. After achieving {{convert|18.8|mpgus|L/100 km mpgimp|abbr=on}} in a road test, ''[[Edmunds.com|Edmunds InsideLine]]'' stated, "...our testing didn't come close to achieving [the EPA's numbers], even though we're usually within 1 mpg of the EPA combined number. "{{cite web|url=http://www.insideline.com/chevrolet/equinox/2010/2010-chevrolet-equinox-lt2-full-test-and-video.html |title=2010 Chevrolet Equinox LT2 Full Test and Video |publisher=Edmunds InsideLine |date=2009-09-29 |accessdate=2010-02-17 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100209022300/http://www.insideline.com/chevrolet/equinox/2010/2010-chevrolet-equinox-lt2-full-test-and-video.html |archivedate=February 9, 2010 }} ''[[Car and Driver]]'' recorded another {{convert|18|mpgus|L/100 km mpgimp|abbr=on}} figure and noted its "...fuel economy that won’t live up to the {{convert|22|mpgus|L/100 km mpgimp|abbr=on}}/{{convert|32|mpgus|L/100 km mpgimp|abbr=on}} EPA ratings in real-world use...".{{cite web|url=http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/car/09q3/2010_chevrolet_equinox_lt-short_take_road_test|title=2010 Chevrolet Equinox LT - Short Take Road Test|author=Jared Gall|publisher=Car and Driver|date=August 2009|accessdate=2010-02-17|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100111064558/http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/car/09q3/2010_chevrolet_equinox_lt-short_take_road_test|archivedate=2010-01-11}} Green Car Reports recorded as much as {{convert|25.8|mpgus|L/100 km mpgimp|abbr=on}} on a road trip, driving almost exclusively highway miles in "Eco" mode;{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarreports.com/blog/1037186_drive-report-26-mpg-in-2010-chevrolet-equinox-four-cylinder|title=Drive Report: 26mpg in 2010 Chevrolet Equinox Four-Cylinder|author=John Voelcker|publisher=GreenCarReports.com|date=2009-10-27|accessdate=2010-02-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091031055759/http://www.greencarreports.com/blog/1037186_drive-report-26-mpg-in-2010-chevrolet-equinox-four-cylinder|archive-date=31 October 2009|url-status=dead}} this is about 20% below the published highway EPA rating. [[AutoWeek]] only averaged {{convert|23|mpgus|L/100 km mpgimp|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.autoweek.com/article/20100120/CARREVIEWS/100129995 |title=The 2010 Chevrolet Equinox 2LT, an AutoWeek Drivers Log |publisher=autoweek.com |date=2010-02-24 |accessdate=2010-07-21 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100329103947/http://www.autoweek.com/article/20100120/CARREVIEWS/100129995 |archivedate=March 29, 2010 }} [[The Truth About Cars]] published an editorial suggesting that GM "inflated" the Equinox's fuel economy ratings for [[public relations]] purposes and that the trip computer inaccurately reports fuel economy reported to the driver.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetruthaboutcars.com/why-the-chevy-equinox-epa-mileage-numbers-dont-add-up/ |title=Why the Chevy Equinox EPA Mileage Numbers Don't Add Up |publisher=Thetruthaboutcars.com |date= 2010-02-16|accessdate=2010-08-23}} Motorweek, however, managed to achieve {{convert|29.3|mpgus|L/100 km mpgimp|abbr=on}} with their test car during mixed driving.{{cite web|url=http://www.mpt.org/motorweek/reviews/rt2939a.shtml |title=2010 Chevrolet Equinox vs. 2011 Kia Sorento, Program #2939 |publisher=Motorweek |date=2010-05-28 |accessdate=2010-07-06 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100601073606/http://www.mpt.org/motorweek/reviews/rt2939a.shtml |archivedate=June 1, 2010 }} LeftlaneNews.com was also able to average {{convert|28|mpgus|L/100 km mpgimp|abbr=on}} average in mixed city and highway driving.{{cite web|url=http://www.leftlanenews.com/chevrolet-equinox-review.html|title=Review: 2010 Chevrolet Equinox LT FWD}} == Third generation (2017–present) == {{Infobox automobile | name = Third generation | image = 2018 Chevrolet Equinox LT, front 3.24.19.jpg | aka = Holden Equinox (Australia & New Zealand (2018-2020) | production = 2017–present | model_years = 2018–present (Worldwide), 2018-2020 (Australia & New Zealand) | assembly = {{Plainlist| *Canada: [[Ingersoll, Ontario]] ([[CAMI Automotive|CAMI]]) *China: [[Wuhan]], Hubei ([[SAIC-GM-Wuling|Shanghai GM]]) *Mexico: [[San Luis Potosi, San Luis Potosi]] ([[San Luis Potosí Assembly]]){{cite web |url=http://elexpres.com/2015/nota.php?story_id=133704 |title=Inicia GM producción de la Equinox en SLP |work=elexpres |author= Redaccion |date=April 8, 2017 |accessdate=April 8, 2017}} / [[Ramos Arizpe, Coahuila]] ([[Ramos Arizpe Assembly]]){{cite web |url=http://www.dineroenimagen.com/2017-06-30/88319 |title=Nueva Equinox, de México al mundo |work=Dinero en imagen |author= Villavicencio Alexandra |date=June 30, 2017 |accessdate=July 1, 2017}} *Argentina: [[Alvear, Corrientes]] }} | class = [[Compact sport utility vehicle|Compact crossover SUV]]http://media.chevrolet.com/media/us/en/chevrolet/home.detail.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2016/sep/0922-2018-equinox.html | platform = [[GM Delta platform|GM D2XX]] | related = {{Plainlist| *[[Buick Envision]] *[[GMC Terrain]] }} | engine = {{Plainlist| *1.5 L ''[[GM small gasoline engine#LYX|LYX]]'' [[Turbocharger|turbo]] [[Inline-four engine|I4]] *2.0 L ''[[GM Ecotec engine#LTG|LTG]]'' turbo I4 *1.6 L ''[[GM Medium Diesel engine|LH7]]'' [[Turbodiesel]] I4 }} | transmission = {{Plainlist| *6-speed [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] *9-speed automatic }} | wheelbase = {{convert|2725|mm|in|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} | length = {{convert|4652|mm|in|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} | width = {{convert|1843|mm|in|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} | height = {{convert|1661|mm|in|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} | predecessor = [[Chevrolet Captiva|Holden Captiva]] (Australia & New Zealand) }} [[File:2018 Chevrolet Equinox LT, rear 3.24.19.jpg|thumb|left|Rear view]] [[File:Chevrolet Equinox 2017 CUV Interior.jpg|thumb|left|Interior]] Chevrolet unveiled the third-generation Equinox on the [[autumnal equinox]] on September 22, 2016.http://media.chevrolet.com/media/us/en/chevrolet/home.detail.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2016/sep/0922-2018-equinox.html Gasoline-powered variants of the 2018 Chevrolet Equinox went on sale in early 2017, while diesel-powered variants arrived in autumn 2017. The third-generation Equinox is available with up to three engine choices. Gasoline engines are identical to the 2016 [[Chevrolet Malibu]]: a 1.5L turbocharged inline four-cylinder (I4) engine that produces 170 horsepower (12 hp less than the 2.4L engine in the previous Equinox but more torque), a 2.0L turbocharged I4 engine that produces 252 horsepower (48 hp less than the 3.6L V6 engine in the previous Equinox), or a 1.6L turbo-diesel I4 engine that produces 136 horsepower (the latter will also be available in future [[Chevrolet Cruze]] models as well). The 3.6L V6 engine option did not carry on to the third generation. The 2.0L unit will also be paired with a nine-speed automatic transmission. New safety features introduced in the third-generation Equinox include a [[Omniview technology|surround-view camera]], [[forward collision warning]], low-speed [[Anti-lock braking system|automatic braking]], a Safety Alert Seat that uses vibration pulses to help alert the driver and avoid crashes, as well as a Rear Seat Alert system that alerts drivers who had opened the back door at the start of a trip to check the back seat once they get to their destination, a feature first introduced on the 2017 [[GMC Acadia]].{{cite web |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2016/09/22/2018-chevy-equinox-turbo-diesel-engine/ |title=2018 Chevy Equinox gains turbo power and an optional diesel |work=[[Weblogs, Inc.|Autoblog]] |author=Turkus, Brandon |date=September 22, 2016 |accessdate=October 12, 2016}} The third-generation Equinox also introduced a new [[All-wheel drive|AWD]] system from [[GKN Driveline]], which allows the driver to disengage the driveshaft to reduce friction and rotational inertia during the times when AWD is not needed.{{cite web |url=http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/equinox/2018/2018-chevrolet-equinox-first-look-review/ |title=2018 CHEVROLET EQUINOX FIRST LOOK |work=[[Motortrend]] |author=Markus, Frank |date=September 23, 2016 |accessdate=April 12, 2018}} After the 2019 model year, AWD was no longer offered for the diesel-powered Equinox, due to low consumer demand.[http://gmauthority.com/blog/2019/05/2020-chevy-equinox-gmc-terrain-diesel-say-so-long-to-awd/ "2020 Chevy Equinox, GMC Terrain Diesel Say So Long To AWD"] from GM Authority (May 1, 2019) ===Trim levels=== Chevrolet has released preliminary specifications for the 2018 Equinox. The third-generation Equinox will be available in eight trim levels: '''L 1.5L Turbo''', '''LS 1.5L Turbo''', '''LT 1.5L Turbo''', '''LT 1.6L Turbo Diesel''', '''LT 2.0L Turbo''', '''Premier 1.5L Turbo''', '''Premier 1.6L Turbo Diesel''', and '''Premier 2.0L Turbo'''. Each trim level will feature its own list of standard equipment:http://gmfleetorderguide.com/NASApp/domestic/proddesc.jsp?year=2017®ionID=1&divisionID=1&type=0&vehicleID=20745§ion=oi_def&page=7&butID=16 '''L'''/'''1SM''': 1.5L Turbocharged Inline Four-Cylinder (I4) engine, six-speed automatic transmission, Seventeen-inch all-season tires, seventeen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, Chevrolet MyLink infotainment system (Seven-inch (7.0") color touch-screen display, AM/FM radio, Bluetooth with A2DP wireless streaming stereo audio, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, USB integration, and OnStar 4G LTE connectivity), rear view backup camera system, six-speaker audio system, power windows and door locks, keyless entry, keyless access system, keyless ignition with push-button start, and premium cloth seating surfaces. There are no available options for this trim, being the "base" Chevrolet Equinox trim and is aimed towards fleet purchases, but is still available for public sale. The base trim is available only with Front-Wheel-Drive (FWD) and in only three (neutral only) colors. '''LS'''/'''1LS''': Sixteen-inch compact spare tire with steel spare wheel. Available options are limited for this trim, being one of the less-expensive Chevrolet Equinox trims, but still comes with a couple packages (one of which includes privacy glass) and adds more color options. '''LT'''/'''1LT''': Optional 2.0L Turbocharged Inline Four-Cylinder engine with 9 speed automatic transmission, AWD optional, [[Sirius XM Satellite Radio]], power-adjustable front driver's bucket seat, remote start, High Intensity Discharge (HID) front head lamps, and leather-wrapped transmission gear selector. Available options include an eight-inch (8.0") [[Chevrolet MyLink]] infotainment system, and advanced driver assistance technologies. '''Premier'''/'''1LZ''': Optional 2.0L Turbocharged Inline Four-Cylinder engine with 9 speed automatic transmission, AWD optional, Eighteen-inch all-season tires, Eighteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels Chevrolet MyLink infotainment system (Eight-inch (8.0") color touch-screen display, AM-FM radio, [[HD Radio]], SiriusXM Satellite Radio, [[Bluetooth]] with [[A2DP]] streaming stereo audio, [[CarPlay|Apple CarPlay]] and [[Android Auto]], wireless charging capabilities, USB integration, and OnStar 4G LTE connectivity), remote vehicle starter system, leather-trimmed seating surfaces, heated dual front bucket seats, rear park assist system, leather-wrapped steering wheel, front-mounted fog lamps, LED front headlamps and LED rear tail lamps, and power rear tailgate. Available options include a GPS navigation radio, a [[Bose Corporation|Bose]] premium seven-speaker audio system, and advanced driver assistance technologies. Also there will be one appearance package available on the Equinox known as the Redline Edition. The Redline Edition is only available on the LT trim without the panoramic sunroof or diesel engine. The Redline Edition will be available in October 2017. The Midnight trim line came to Mexico on September 2, 2019.https://www.motorpasion.com.mx/industria/chevrolet-equinox-midnight-mexico-precio ===2021 refresh=== On February 6, 2020, Chevrolet unveiled a refresh Equinox at the [[Chicago Auto Show]]. The updated vehicle now sports a new front grille (adopting the Chevrolet design language and having a similar look as the Blazer), which extends into the redesigned headlamps, along with a restyled lower fascia with different foglamps. The rear also sees small changes in the way of redesigned taillamps and a different bumper. The level trims also expands as well, with the RS joining the primary LS, LT, and Premier offerings. The sport/street-centric RS trim is set apart by its unique front and rear fascias, black exterior accents, black badges, “Dark Android” 19-inch wheels and quad-tip exhaust. Inside, the sport-inspired crossover features black upholstery with red contrasting stitching and an RS-branded shift knob. The refreshed Equinox will go on sale in the third quarter of 2020.[https://gmauthority.com/blog/2020/02/2021-chevrolet-equinox-unveiled-at-the-chicago-auto-show/ "2021 Chevrolet Equinox Unveiled At The Chicago Auto Show"] from Autoblog (February 6, 2020) ===Engines=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Model Year ! Type/model ! Power ! Torque |- | 2018– (all markets) | 1.5 L (91 cu in) ''[[GM small gasoline engine#LYX|LYX]]'' [[Turbocharger|turbo]] [[Inline-four engine|I4]] | {{convert|170|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 5,600 rpm | {{convert|203|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} at 2,000–4,000 rpm |- | 2018– (select markets) | 2.0 L (122 cu in) ''[[GM Ecotec engine#LTG|LTG]]'' turbo I4 | {{convert|252|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 5,500 rpm | {{convert|260|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} at 2,500–4,500 rpm |- | 2018– (select markets) | 1.6 L (98 cu in) ''[[GM Medium Diesel engine|LH7]]'' [[turbodiesel]] I4 | {{convert|137|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} at 3,750 rpm | {{convert|240|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} at 2,000 rpm |} ===Holden Equinox=== [[File:2018 Holden Equinox (EQ) LS wagon (2018-11-29) 01.jpg|thumb|Holden Equinox (Australia and New Zealand)]] [[Holden]] launched the Holden Equinox (EQ series) in [[Australia]] in November 2017, with the first cars arriving in December. It was available with a 1.5 L [[Turbocharged petrol engines|turbocharged]] engine on the base LS and LS+ models, while the more potent 2.0 L turbocharged model was available for all other models - LT, LTZ and LTZ-V. The 1.6 L [[turbo-diesel]] engine launched in 2018.{{Cite news|url=http://www.caradvice.com.au/600902/2018-holden-equinox-pricing-and-specs/|title=2018 Holden Equinox pricing and specs {{!}} CarAdvice|work=CarAdvice.com|access-date=2017-11-17|language=en-GB}} It was produced at GM's [[Ramos Arizpe Assembly|Ramos Arizpe assembly]] facility in Mexico, and replaced the Korean-built five-seat [[Holden Captiva|Captiva]]. The Australasian Equinox was sold alongside the seven-seat Holden Acadia, known as the [[GMC Acadia]] in the Americas, rather than the [[Chevrolet Traverse]], which sits above the Equinox in select [[Chevrolet]] markets.{{Cite news|url=http://www.caradvice.com.au/568625/2018-holden-acadia-quick-drive-review/|title=2018 Holden Acadia quick drive review {{!}} CarAdvice|work=CarAdvice.com|access-date=2017-11-17|language=en-GB}} On October 17, 2018, Holden halted production on the Equinox due to slow sales and unsold inventory at its dealerships.[http://gmauthority.com/blog/2018/10/amid-sales-downturn-holden-stops-production-of-commodore-equinox/ "Holden Stops Commodore, Equinox Production"] from GM Authority (October 17, 2018) The Equinox was discontinued in 2020, along with the rest of the Holden lineup, following GM's decision to terminate the marque in Australia and New Zealand.https://media.gm.com/media/au/en/holden/home.detail.html/content/Pages/news/au/en/2020/feb/0217_Holden.html == Fuel Cell == {{see also|GM HydroGen4}} [[File:Equinox Fuel Cell EDTA DC 04 2011 1813.jpg|thumb|right|Chevrolet Equinox Fuel Cell with its first generation]] The Chevrolet Equinox [[Fuel cell vehicle]] uses [[hydrogen]] for fuel with water as its only exhaust. The Equinox Fuel Cell uses the fourth-generation hydrogen technology found in the [[Chevrolet Sequel]] concept, which was unveiled in September 2009. The fuel cell is designed for only {{convert|50000|mi|km}} of driving, but is engineered to be operable in subfreezing temperatures throughout its life. GM states that the Equinox Fuel Cell is about {{convert|500|lb}} heavier than the original Equinox and has one inch less ground clearance. To reduce weight, it has aluminum doors and a carbon fiber hood. It uses headlights from the [[Pontiac Torrent]].{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} A dashboard mounted screen calculates the fuel savings to that of a gasoline-powered Equinox. It also includes a kilowatt meter and a fuel cell energy display. The fuel cell has four vapor outlets that replace the exhaust pipe. Three [[Carbon-fiber-reinforced polymer|carbon-fiber]] fuel tanks store up to a maximum of 9.25 [[pound (mass)|pound]]s (4.2 kg) of gaseous hydrogen at 10,000 psi (70 [[megapascal|MPa]]), and give the Equinox a range of {{convert|200|mi|km}}. The Equinox Fuel Cell is certified by the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|EPA]] as a [[zero-emission vehicle]] (ZEV). GM built 115 Chevrolet Equinox Fuel Cell vehicles and deployed them in 2007–2008 in several target areas including New York and California as part of a comprehensive plan dubbed "Project Driveway".{{cite web|url=http://www.chevrolet.com/experience/fuel-solutions/fuel-cell/ |title=The Best Emissions Strategy Is A Zero-Emissions Strategy |publisher=Chevrolet.com |date= |accessdate=2009-10-16}} The Equinox Fuel Cell includes safety features such as [[Anti-lock braking system|ABS]], [[traction control system]], and GM's [[OnStar]] telematics service, which offers drivers advice on operating the cars as well as information on nearby hydrogen filling stations. The car meets all 2007 federal safety standards. === Performance === ''[[Motor Trend]]'' assessed the vehicle's performance as nearly the same as the 3.6-liter gasoline-powered equivalent, while bemoaning the dearth of high-pressure hydrogen filling stations near Riverside, California, in 2008.{{cite journal |author=Kim Reynolds |title=First Test: 2008 Chevrolet Equinox FCV - Waterworks: Fourteen Days In The Hydrogen Economy |journal=Motor Trend |date=October 2008 |url= http://www.motortrend.com/roadtests/suvs/112_0812_2008_chevrolet_equinox_fcv_first_test/ |accessdate=2015-06-26}} ==Natural gas version== In 2013, Nat G CNG Solutions and AGA Systems announced that they had begun offering a [[Compressed Natural Gas]] (CNG) version of the Chevy Equinox and the [[GMC Terrain]] using the 2.4 L Direct Injection engine. The natural gas version is a "bi-fuel" CNG vehicle, meaning that it can run on either gasoline or natural gas, giving it extended range. The Terrain/Equinox were the first direct-injection natural gas vehicles ever approved by the US EPA.{{cite web|last=Piellisch|first=Rich|title=Nat G CNG for New GM Crossovers|url=http://www.fleetsandfuels.com/fuels/cng/2013/12/nat-g-cng-for-gm-crossovers/|publisher=Fleets and Fuels.com|accessdate=2 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419100215/http://www.fleetsandfuels.com/fuels/cng/2013/12/nat-g-cng-for-gm-crossovers/|archive-date=19 April 2014|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}} Silver Eagle Distributors, a distributor of [[Anheuser-Busch]] products, was the launch customer for the natural gas version with an initial order of up to 100 of the natural gas GMC Terrains. [[CenterPoint Energy]] was an early customer of the natural gas Chevy Equinox.{{cite news|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/aga-systems-nat-g-cng-150000994.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140420074442/http://finance.yahoo.com/news/aga-systems-nat-g-cng-150000994.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=April 20, 2014 |date=November 18, 2013 |work=Business Wire |publisher=yahoo.com |accessdate=November 19, 2013 }} === CNG configurations === The CNG version was available as a newly purchased Equinox through select dealers or as a retrofit on 2013 and 2014 models. Nat G CNG Solutions offered the vehicle in two options: a two-seater "cargo version" and a five-seat "passenger version." The cargo version has an 837-mile combined gasoline / natural gas (9.2 [[Gasoline gallon equivalent|gge]] of CNG) while the passenger version has a 775-mile combined highway range (6.8 [[Gasoline gallon equivalent|gge]] of CNG). === Emissions and performance === The companies claimed that the natural gas version had tested at the EPA lab at 31 mpg highway on natural gas and had achieved a Bin 3 emissions equivalent to the [[Toyota Prius]]. {{-}} == Electric conversion == [[File:Equinox amp EV EDTA DC 04 2011 1834.jpg|thumb|Chevrolet Equinox [[Amp Electric Vehicles|AMP]]-converted [[battery electric vehicle]]]] [[Amp Electric Vehicles]] sells an [[all-electric vehicle|all-electric]] conversion of the Chevrolet Equinox. They have sold their first electric Equinox to [[DPL Inc.|Dayton Power & Light]], and had a five-year, thousand-SUV order from Northern Lights Energy in [[Iceland]]. == Sales == {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{Infobox automobile | name = Chevrolet Biscayne | image = 1958 Chevrolet Biscayne State Car.jpg | caption = 1958 Chevrolet Biscayne four-door sedan
former Irish government state car, RHD | manufacturer = [[Chevrolet]] ([[General Motors]]) | production = 1958–1972 (U.S.) | predecessor = [[Chevrolet 210]] | successor = [[Chevrolet Bel Air]] | class = [[Full-size]] | platform = [[GM B platform]] | layout = [[FR layout]] | related = {{ubl | [[Chevrolet Bel Air]] | [[Chevrolet Impala]] | [[Chevrolet Caprice]] }} }} The '''Chevrolet Biscayne''' was a series of [[full-size car]]s produced by the [[United States|American]] manufacturer [[Chevrolet]] between 1958 and 1972. Named after a show car displayed at the 1955 [[General Motors Motorama]], the Biscayne was the least expensive model in the Chevrolet full-size car range (except the 1958-only [[Chevrolet Delray]]). The absence of most exterior and fancy interior trimmings remained through the life of the series, as the slightly costlier [[Chevrolet Bel Air]] offered more interior and exterior features at a price significantly lower than the top of the line [[Chevrolet Impala]]. The Biscayne was named after [[Biscayne Bay]], near [[Miami]], [[Florida]], following a trend by Chevrolet at the time to name cars after coastal cities or beaches such as the Bel Air and the later [[Chevrolet Malibu]]. __TOC__ ==Overview== Biscaynes were produced primarily for the fleet market, though they were also available to the general public — particularly to those who wanted low-cost, [[no-frills]] transportation with the convenience, room and power of a [[Full-size car|full-size]] [[car|automobile]]. While most Biscaynes were sold with a six-cylinder engine through the late 1960s, the [[V8 engine|V8]] engine became the more popular powerplant by the early 1970s.[[#Footnotes|1]]. The Biscayne was usually built as a two- or four-door [[sedan (automobile)|sedan]], although a four-door [[station wagon]] was available between 1962 and 1968 (and again after 1973 in Canada only). A low-priced, full-size Biscayne [[station wagon]] equivalent was available as the [[Chevrolet Brookwood]] both before and after this period. The two-door sedan was dropped after 1969, and consequently, from 1970 to 1972 the only Biscayne model available was a four-door sedan. In 1958, the [[Chevrolet Delray|Delray]] was priced below the Biscayne but was discontinued the following year. Many of the luxury convenience options available on the more expensive full-sized Chevrolet models, such as [[power windows]], were not available on the Biscayne. However, customers could purchase a Biscayne with any of Chevrolet's high-output [[Chevrolet Big-Block engine|big-block]] [[V8 engine|V8]] engines and performance-oriented transmissions, including the floor-mounted four-speed [[manual transmission]] with Hurst shifter and low-ratio final drive. Original production numbers of cars built this way were very low, and examples of these high-performance cars are highly sought after by collectors today. Notably, Baldwin Chevrolet of Long Island, New York, became famous for offering the "Street Racer Special," a 1968 Biscayne coupe with dealer-fitted high-performance 427 cubic-inch V8, and heavy-duty suspension components, turning the Biscayne into a serious drag car. Biscayne with high-performance equipment was often nicknamed "Bisquick" by enthusiasts. Like the slightly upscale Bel Airs, Biscaynes are easily identified by the use of two taillights per side; the only exceptions to this were in 1959 and 1972. The more expensive Impalas (and later Caprices) have three taillights per side. The Biscayne was largely devoid of exterior chrome trim and was normally fitted with small hubcaps, though several exterior trim pieces and upgraded wheel covers were available at extra cost. Interior trim was spartan, with lower-grade cloth and vinyl or all-vinyl upholstery trim, a standard steering wheel with centre horn button, and rubber floor mats. Slight upgrades were made throughout the life of the series — for instance, the 1964 models came standard with deluxe steering wheels with horn rings, deep-twist carpeting and foam-cushioned front seats. ==First generation (1958–1960)== {{Infobox automobile | name = First generation | image = 1959-chevy-biscayne-chevrolet-archives.jpg | caption = 1959 Chevrolet Biscayne four-door sedan | model_years = 1958–1960 | transmission = 3-speed [[Manual transmission|manual]]

[[Woodville, South Australia|Woodville]], [[Australia]] (1958 model)Norm Darwin, 100 Years of GM in Australia, 2002, page 152. | related = }} At its introduction for the 1958 model year, the Biscayne was available as a two- or four-door pillared sedan. In 1958, there was also the even lower-priced [[Chevrolet Delray]], but this was discontinued for 1959. In 1959, the car was redesigned, and now sat on an inch-and-a-half ({{convert|1.5|in|cm|disp=output only}}) longer wheelbase.{{cite web|url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Chevrolet/1959_Chevrolet/1959_Chevrolet_Brochure/1959%20Chevrolet-02.html |title=Directory Index: Chevrolet/1959_Chevrolet/1959_Chevrolet_Brochure |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}} In 1959 the two-door Utility Sedan appeared, a version lacking a rear seat and being intended as a delivery vehicle. [[File:Chevrolet Biscayne 1960 (13986675109).jpg|thumb|left|1960 Biscayne four-door sedan]] ===Biscayne Fleetmaster=== In 1960, a lower-priced, sparsely trimmed version of the Biscayne called the Fleetmaster was produced. Aimed primarily at the fleet market, the Fleetmaster included a lower grade of upholstery than the standard Biscayne and deleted routine convenience items such as a [[Cigarette lighter receptacle|cigarette lighter]], door armrests, and passenger-side sun visor. In addition, many parts were painted rather than [[Chrome plating|chrome plated]]. Both two- and four-door sedans were available. A number of economy-minded options were available exclusive to the Fleetmaster model, although the performance-oriented engines and transmissions were also available (for police applications or performance-oriented customers who wanted the lightest car possible). The Fleetmaster was dropped after 1961. {{clear}} [[thumb]] ==Second generation (1961–1964)== {{Infobox automobile | name = Second generation | image = 1963 Chevrolet Biscayne 2dr (DVS1mn, 3).jpg | caption = 1963 Chevrolet Biscayne two-door sedan | model_years = 1961–1964 | transmission = 3/4-speed manual

{{convert|235.5|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chevrolet straight-6 engine#Second generation|''Blue Flame'']] I6 | {{convert|283|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[V8 engine|V8]] | {{convert|348|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 (1961) | {{convert|327|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 (1962–1964) | {{convert|409|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 }} | body_style = two-/four-door [[Sedan (automobile)|sedan]]
four-door [[station wagon]] (1962–1964) | assembly = [[Arlington, Texas]], United States
[[South Gate, California]], United States
[[Oshawa, Ontario]], [[Canada]] | related = }} [[File:1961 Chevrolet Biscayne two-door, rear right (blue).jpg|thumb|left|1961 Chevrolet Biscayne two-door, rear view]] [[File:Flickr - DVS1mn - 61 Chevrolet Biscayne (2).jpg|thumb|left|1961 Chevrolet Biscayne two-door, front view]] The Biscayne underwent a full model change for the 1961 model year. The stripped down Fleetmaster and the three-passenger Utility Sedan were still available for 1961 but sold in very small numbers. Series numbers were 1100 and 1200 (six- and eight-cylinder Biscayne), with the 1300 and 1400 used for the six- and eight-cylinder Fleetmaster. For 1963, the short-stroke [[Chevrolet straight-6 engine#Third generation|third generation]] inline-six replaced the earlier "Stovebolt" 235, meaning lower weight and a slight gain in power. In 1962, a four-door [[station wagon]] version appeared, replacing the earlier [[Chevrolet Brookwood|Brookwood]] model. As usual, the full range of GM's full-size engine and transmission options were available to the low priced Biscayne. A very few of the brand-new, high-powered 409 V8s (of which only 142 were built in 1961) even found their way into the bargain-basement Biscayne Fleetmaster, with the direct intention of being used for drag racing.{{cite web | last = Marion | first = Doug | title = 1961 Chevrolet Biscayne Fleetmaster - 41 From ’61 = 1 Of A Kind | url = http://www.superchevy.com/features/1306-1961-chevrolet-biscayne-fleetmaster-41-from-61-1-of-a-kind/ | publisher = The Enthusiast Network | work = Super Chevy | accessdate = 2015-06-08 | date = 2013-09-16 }} {{clear}} ==Third generation (1965–1970)== {{Infobox automobile | name = Third generation | model_years = 1965–1970 | image = Chevrolet Biscayne Coupe (Orange Julep).JPG | caption = 1968 Chevrolet Biscayne two-door sedan | transmission = 3/4-speed manual
[[Powerglide]] auto
3-speed [[Turbo Hydramatic]] automatic | engine = {{convert|230|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Straight-six engine|I6]] (1965–1966)
{{convert|250|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} I6 (1965–1970)
{{convert|283|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[V8 engine|V8]] (1965–1967)
{{convert|327|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 (1965–1967)
{{convert|307|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 (1968)
{{convert|350|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 (1969–1970)
{{convert|400|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 (1970)
{{convert|409|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 (1965–1966)
{{convert|396|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8 (1965–1969)
{{convert|427|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chevrolet Big-Block engine#427|''Big-Block'']] V8 (1966–1969) {{convert|454|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} ''Big-Block'' V8 (1970) | body_style = two-door [[Sedan (automobile)|sedan]] (1965–1969)
four-door [[Sedan (automobile)|sedan]]
four-door [[station wagon]] | assembly = [[Arlington, Texas]], United States
[[South Gate, California]], United States
[[Oshawa, Ontario]], [[Canada]] | related = }} [[File:'65 Chevrolet Biscayne (Toronto Spring '12 Classic Car Auction).JPG|thumb|left|1965 Chevrolet Biscayne]] [[File:'68 Chevrolet Biscayne Coupe (Centropolis Laval '10).jpg|thumb|left|1968 Biscayne two-door sedan]] The all-new 1965 Biscayne was larger yet, and offered an even wider range of engines, including a new, larger 250-ci inline-six. For the 1967 model year the smaller 230 was dropped. For 1966 the top engine became the new [[Chevrolet Big-Block engine#427|Big-Block]] 427 ci V8, available in a high-powered, high-revving {{convert|425|hp|kW|abbr=on}} version with solid lifters. Although not available for the big Chevrolets in 1967, it returned in 1968 for two more model years. After 1968 the Biscayne station wagon was discontinued, henceforth being sold as the [[Chevrolet Brookwood|Brookwood]]. [[Power steering]] and power brakes were made standard for the 1970 model year. [[File:1970 Chevrolet Biscayne 4-door sedan, rear left.jpg|thumb|left|1970 Chevrolet Biscayne four-door sedan. The brightwork around the windows and side moldings are non-stock items that were added later.]] {{clear}} ==Fourth generation (1971–1975)== {{Infobox automobile | name = Fourth generation | model_years = 1971-1975 (Canada) | engine = {{convert|350|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[V8 engine|V8]]
{{convert|400|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[V8 engine|V8]]
{{convert|454|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[V8 engine|V8]]
{{convert|250|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Straight-6|I6]] | body_style = {{ubl | four-door [[Sedan (automobile)|sedan]] | four-door [[station wagon]] (Canada, 1973-75) }} | platform = [[GM B platform|B-body]] | related = | assembly = [[Oshawa, Ontario]], [[Canada]] | transmission = 3-speed [[Manual transmission|manual]] (standard, 1971–1973 on all six-cylinder cars)
3-speed [[Turbo-Hydramatic]] automatic (optional 1971–1973 on six-cylinder cars; standard on V8-powered cars from mid-1971 onwards) }} The TurboHydramatic transmission was made standard on all cars ordered with a V8 engine starting midway through the 1971 model year. Production of the Biscayne for the United States market ended for 1971. However, the Biscayne name survived in [[Canada]] through the 1975 model year, with a 350 cubic-inch [[V8 engine|V8]] engine and TurboHydramatic [[automatic transmission]] made standard for 1974.{{cite web | last=Mays|first=James C|title=1974 Chevrolet Caprice Classic, Impala, Bel Air and Biscayne|url=http://www.oldcarscanada.com/2012/08/1974-chevrolet-caprice-classic-impala.html|work=www.OldCarsCanada.com|accessdate=March 6, 2013}} The station wagon model had been sold as the [[Chevrolet Brookwood|Brookwood]], but for 1973 the Biscayne station wagon made a return for the Canadian market only. Like its stablemates, the 1975 Biscayne received new dashboard, radio and climate control graphics (including a 100-mph speedometer with kilometer equivalents) and the availability of two new options: an Econominder gauge package (with temperature gauge and a gauge that monitored fuel economy, based on the driver's current driving habits) and intermittent windshield wipers. The fourth generation wagons featured a [[Station wagon#Tailgate evolution|'clamshell' design]] marketed as the ''Glide-away'' tailgate, also called a "disappearing" tailgate because when open, the tailgate was completely out of view. On the clamshell design, the rear power-operated glass slid up into the roof and the lower tailgate (with either manual or optional power operation), lowered completely below the load floor. The manual lower tailgate was counterbalanced by a torque rod similar to the torque rods used in holding a trunk lid open, requiring a 35 lb push to fully lower the gate. Raising the manual gate required a 5 lb pull via a handhold integral to the top edge of the retractable gate.{{cite journal|title=The '71 Wagons, Big Changes Coming Up |journal=Popular Science |date=October 1970 |pages=74–75 |first=Jan P. |last=Norbye |first2=Jim |last2=Dunne |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=QwEAAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA75&dq=%22glide+away%22+tailgate#v=onepage&q=%22glide%20away%22%20tailgate&f=false |accessdate=October 10, 2015}} The power operation of both upper glass and lower tailgate became standard equipment in later model years. Wagons with the design featured an optional third row of forward-facing seats accessed by the rear side doors and a folding second-row seat — and could accommodate a 4 x 8' sheet of plywood with rear seats folded. The clamshell design required no increased footprint or operational area to open, allowing a user to stand at the cargo opening without impediment of a door — for example, in a closed garage. {{clear_left}} ==Footnotes== *1 A total of 76,800 Biscaynes were equipped with V8 engines compared to 16,700 [[Straight-6|six-cylinder]] engine models years 1970, 1971 and 1972. Biscayne engine distribution (V8/I6) 23,100/12,300 (1970); 34,700/2,900 (1971); and 19,000/1,500 (1972), or one six-cylinder power Biscayne for every 4.5 V8 cars produced. (Gunnell) ==References== {{reflist}} * {{cite book | editor-last = Gunnell | editor-first = John | title = The Standard Catalog of American Cars 1946–1975 | publisher = Krause Publications | year = 1987 | isbn = 978-0-87341-096-0 }} * {{Citation | last=Biel | first=John | title=A Glass Half Full: The Story of the 1958 Chevrolet | journal=Collectible Automobile|volume=21 |issue=6 | year=2005| pages=8–23 }}. {{commons category|Chevrolet Biscayne}} {{Chevrolet vehicles}} {{Chevrolet cars timeline 1950–1979}} [[Category:Chevrolet vehicles|Biscayne]] [[Category:Full-size vehicles]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Sedans]] [[Category:Station wagons]] [[Category:Police vehicles]] [[Category:1950s cars]] [[Category:1960s cars]] [[Category:1970s cars]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]] [[Category:Cars of Canada]]

{{refimprove|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox automobile | name = Chevrolet Citation | image = Chevrolet Citation II front.jpg | caption = ''1984-1985 Chevrolet Citation II 5-door'' | manufacturer = [[General Motors]] | production = 1979–1985 | model_years = 1980–1985 | assembly = [[Oklahoma City Assembly|Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]], U.S.
[[Sleepy Hollow, New York|North Tarrytown, New York]], U.S.
[[Ramos Arizpe]], [[Mexico]] | predecessor = [[Chevrolet Nova]] | successor = [[Chevrolet Corsica]]
[[Chevrolet Beretta]] | class = [[Compact car|Compact]] | body_style = 2-door [[notchback]]
3-door [[hatchback]]
5-door [[hatchback]] | layout = [[Front-engine, front-wheel-drive layout|Transverse front-engine, front-wheel drive]] | platform = [[GM X platform (1980)|X-body]] | engine = 2.5 L [[GM Iron Duke engine|Iron Duke]] [[Straight-4|I4]]
2.8 L [[GM 60-Degree V6 engine#LE2|LE2]] [[V6 engine|V6]]
2.8 L [[GM 60-Degree V6 engine#LH7|LH7]] [[V6 High Output engine|HO V6]]
2.8 L [[GM 60-Degree V6 engine#LB6|LB6]] [[V6 MPFI engine|MPFI V6]] | transmission = 3-speed [[Turbo-Hydramatic 125|TH-125]] [[automatic transmission|automatic]]
4-speed [[manual transmission|manual]] | wheelbase = {{Convert|104.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | length = {{Convert|176.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | width = {{Convert|68.3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = {{Convert|53.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | weight = | related = [[Buick_Skylark#Fourth_generation_(1980–1985)|Buick Skylark]]
[[Pontiac_Phoenix#Second generation (1980–1984)|Pontiac Phoenix]]
[[Oldsmobile_Omega#Third_generation_(1980–1984)|Oldsmobile Omega]] | designer = | sp = us }}The '''Chevrolet Citation''' is a range of [[compact car]]s that was produced by the [[Chevrolet]] division of [[General Motors]]. The first Chevrolet sold with [[front-wheel drive]], a single generation of the Citation was sold from the 1980 to 1985 model years, succeeding the [[Chevrolet Chevy II / Nova|Chevrolet Nova]]. The model range was offered in three body styles: three-door and five-door hatchbacks and a two-door [[Notchback|notchback coupe]].{{Cite web|url=https://auto.howstuffworks.com/chevrolet-citation1.htm|title=Chevrolet Citation|last=|first=|date=2007-08-02|website=HowStuffWorks|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-02-07}} The Citation was built on the second-generation compact GM [[GM X platform (1980)|X-platform]]. For 1980, the platform was switched to front-wheel drive and significantly [[Downsize (automobile)|downsized]] (nearly reducing its exterior footprint to that of the 1970s [[GM H platform (1971)|H-platform]] subcompacts). The Citation was sold alongside the [[Pontiac Phoenix]], [[Buick Skylark]], and [[Oldsmobile Omega]]; while the Phoenix was also produced as a hatchback and the Skylark and Omega were produced as two-doors, the two-door notchback coupé body was exclusive to the Citation. Alongside a standard trim level, Chevrolet offered the Citation X-11, offering performance-oriented upgrades. In an extended 1980 model year, over 800,000 examples of the Citation were sold; along with becoming the best-selling car in the United States for the model year, the Citation was among the most successful product launches in General Motors history.{{cite web|url=https://auto.howstuffworks.com/chevrolet-citation2.htm|title=Chevrolet Citation|author=The Auto Editors of Consumer Guide|first=|date=|website=|publisher=HowStuffWorks.com|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|accessdate=2010-01-23}} After the 1981 model year, sales of the Citation significantly decreased as the launches of the [[Chevrolet Cavalier]] and [[Chevrolet Celebrity]] expanded the front-wheel drive Chevrolet product range. After the 1985 model year, Chevrolet discontinued the Citation, replacing the model line with the [[Chevrolet Beretta]] two-door coupe and [[Chevrolet Corsica]] four-door sedan/five-door hatchback. In total, Chevrolet manufactured 1,642,587 examples of the model line during its production run. == Development == To better compete in the compact segment following the [[1973 oil crisis|1973 fuel crisis]], General Motors commenced work in April 1974 on a replacement for its [[GM X platform (1962)|X-body]] compact lines, including the [[Chevrolet Nova]]. As the 1970s progressed, import-brand compact cars continued to grow in popularity, gaining sales from domestic counterparts. Largely serving as a second generation of the [[Chevrolet Vega]], the [[Chevrolet Monza]] proved relatively successful, though inefficient and outdated in comparison to front-wheel drive compacts such as the [[Honda Accord]] and the [[Volkswagen Golf Mk1|Volkswagen Rabbit]] (the layout of the latter was nearly copied outright by Chrysler to develop the 1978 [[Dodge Omni|Dodge Omni/Plymouth Horizon]]). While GM had produced front-wheel drive vehicles for nearly a decade, its experience involved large personal luxury coupes ([[Cadillac Eldorado]] and [[Oldsmobile Toronado]]) and recreational vehicles ([[GMC motorhome|GMC Motorhome]]), neither fuel-efficient nor compact. Following the reverse-engineering of [[Lancia]] vehicles, GM selected a transverse front-wheel drive layout for the new X-body{{Cite web|url=https://www.automobilemag.com/news/gm-x-cars-chevrolet-citation-oldsmobile-buick-pontiac-photos-history/|title=GM's X-Cars: Anatomy of a Miserable Failure {{!}} Automobile Magazine|date=2019-05-21|website=Automobile|language=en|access-date=2020-02-07}}; in the mid-summer of 1976, the first vehicle prototypes entered testing; in its development, Chevrolet would design the front suspension of the platform, with Pontiac responsible for the rear. Intended for a 1978 model release, the Chevrolet Nova replacement was to adopt the "Condor" nameplate. Coinciding with the downsizing of the A-body mid-size line for 1978, the launch of the Chevrolet Condor was moved to 1980, as GM parts suppliers were trying to adjust to large-scale production of a front-wheel drive car. During the delay, the Chevrolet Condor name was scrapped in favor of Chevrolet Citation.{{Cite web|url=http://everything2.com/user/schizophasic/writeups/Chevrolet+Citation|title=Chevrolet Citation (thing) by schizophasic - Everything2.com|website=everything2.com|accessdate=2015-11-14}} ==History == Along with its debut as the first front-wheel drive Chevrolet, the Citation also marked the downsizing of the Chevrolet compact model line (following the downsizing of the 1977 Caprice/Impala and 1978 Malibu). While packaged with similar interior space as the Malibu and trunk space as the Impala{{Cite web|url=https://www.dancummins.com/remembering-chevy-citation/|title=Remembering the Chevy Citation {{!}} Dan Cummins|last=KY|last2=https://www.dancummins.com/wp-content/themes/DealerInspireDealerTheme/images/logo.png|first2=40361 United States 877-661-2805|website=Dan Cummins Chevrolet Buick|language=en|access-date=2020-02-07}}, the Citation shed 20 inches of length (only an inch longer than a Vega), 4 inches of width, and 800 pounds of weight from the 1979 Nova. Through its production, as one of the front-wheel drive X-body vehicles, the Chevrolet Citation would undergo a number of manufacturer recalls. In 1980, 225,000 examples were recalled to fix a transmission hose related to underhood fires.{{Cite web|url=https://www.conceptcarz.com/vehicle/series.aspx?modelID=3441|title=Citation - Model Information|website=conceptcarz.com|language=en|access-date=2020-02-07}} The X-body cars (which included the Citation) were the target of an unsuccessful lawsuit by the U.S. [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] (NHTSA), which cited a tendency for the vehicles to lose control under heavy braking, and power steering problems. === 1980 === [[File:1980 Chevrolet Citation fr.jpg|thumb|left|1980 Citation 3-door]] [[File:Chevrolet Citation.jpg|thumb|1980 Citation 5-door]] In April 1979, the Citation was released as a 1980 model in two trim levels. Alongside the standard trim, a sporty X-11 version was produced. Priced under [[US dollar|US$]]6,000, with hatchbacks in a much larger package than the Dodge Omni/Plymouth Horizon, demand proved very high for the Citation. Helped by an April release and yet another gasoline shortage during the same time, over 800,000 Citations were sold by Chevrolet for the model year. However, as the second gas crisis created demand for more fuel-efficient vehicles, GM was left with significant shortages of 4-cylinder engines, leaving some customers to wait several months to receive their vehicles. Before the fuel crisis, Chevrolet had anticipated 70% of customers purchasing the V6 engine option, leading to production lines unable to keep up with demand for four-cylinder models. In an extended 1980 model year, Chevrolet would sell over 810,000 examples of the Citation; in addition to making for one of the most successful product launches in General Motors history, the Chevrolet Citation would become the best-selling car in the United States in 1980.
=== 1981 === For 1981, while the Citation saw no visible changes, the model line was pared down, with the two-door coupe discontinued (in response to slow sales). The X-11 gained additional performance, as the model received a 135-hp high output version of its 2.8L V6. In 1981, the Chevrolet Citation gained its most direct competitor, as Chrysler introduced the [[Plymouth Reliant|Dodge Aries/Plymouth Reliant]] (the [[Chrysler K platform|Chrysler K-Cars]]). While also produced in front-wheel drive, the K-Cars offered sedan and station wagon body styles unavailable from Chevrolet. === 1982 === [[File:Chevrolet Citation Coupe.jpg|thumb|left|The Citation coupe body was unique to Chevy and not shared with another GM badge]] For 1982, fuel injection was added to the 2.5L engine; to further increase fuel economy, low rolling resistance tires were added to all Citations (including the X-11).{{Cite web|url=https://auto.howstuffworks.com/chevrolet-citation3.htm|title=Chevrolet Citation|last=|first=|date=2007-08-02|website=HowStuffWorks|language=en|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-02-07}} As a running change during the year, the two-door notchback (coupe) made its return after being dropped for 1981. Chevrolet introduced two models for 1982 that would produce a significant effect on Citation sales. Phased in to replace the Malibu, the [[Chevrolet Celebrity]] was an [[GM A platform (1982)|A-Body]] vehicle. While sharing its wheelbase and powertrain with the Citation, the sedan and wagon bodies of the Celebrity were considered mid-size cars. Replacing the Monza, the [[Chevrolet Cavalier]] J-body subcompact further expanded the front-wheel drive product offering with its own coupe, hatchback, and station wagon competing closely against the Citation. The Citation, Celebrity, and Cavalier were sold with Buick, Oldsmobile, and Pontiac counterparts (the latter was also sold as a Cadillac). === 1983 === For 1983, few external changes were made to the Citation, while several revisions were made to the interior.{{Cite web|url=https://auto.howstuffworks.com/chevrolet-citation.htm|title=Chevrolet Citation|date=2007-08-02|website=HowStuffWorks|language=en|access-date=2020-02-07}} The dash underwent minor trim updates for the first time since 1980, with the front seats receiving adjustable head restraints. The X-11 package returned to the two-door coupe (for the first time since 1980), while its HO V6 became an option on all Citations. === 1984 === [[File:Chevrolet Citation II rear.jpg|thumb|250px|Chevrolet Citation II|alt=]] For 1984, the Citation was renamed the Citation II.{{Cite web|url=https://auto.howstuffworks.com/chevrolet-citation.htm|title=Chevrolet Citation|date=2007-08-02|website=HowStuffWorks|language=en|access-date=2020-02-07}} While undergoing almost no visible changes outside of badging, the rebranding was intended to draw attention away from previous recalls and quality issues. All three body styles remained, along with the X-11. For the first time, Citation sales increased over the previous year (though remaining under 100,000). === 1985 === For 1985, the Citation II saw several revisions in its final year of production. The two-door Citation II was discontinued for good, though the X-11 remained. The dashboard underwent a redesign with a horizontally-mounted radio and a new steering wheel. The 2.8L HO engine became fuel injected (reducing output to 130 hp). The last Citation rolled off the assembly line on June 21, 1985. ==Powertrain== In addition to the X platform, GM also created a new line of engines for the Citation and its sisters. The 2.8 L ''[[GM 60-Degree V6 engine#LE2|LE2]]'' [[V6]] was the first of the [[GM 60-Degree V6 engine|60°Family]] of [[Internal combustion engine|engines]]. The X platform was used in 1982 as the basis for the new [[front-wheel drive]] [[GM A platform (FWD)|A-body]] cars. The X platform was also the basis for the future [[GM L platform|L-body]] and [[GM N platform|N-body]] cars. ==X-11== [[File:1980 Chevrolet Citation X11.jpg|thumb|1980 Citation X-11]] Produced as a separate trim level, the Citation X-11 was a variant featuring cosmetic, chassis, and powertrain upgrades over the standard Citation. While less powerful than the Camaro Z28 (and later Monte Carlo SS), the Citation X-11 would also take over the role of the similarly-sized Chevrolet Monza. The X-11 was offered throughout the production run of the Citation/Citation II, on the 3-door hatchback and 2-door "club coupe" (discontinued in 1981 and 1985). In 1981, the Citation X-11 accelerated from 0–60 MPH in 8.5 seconds; the 1982–1984 version accelerated from 0–60 MPH in 9.2 seconds. === Chassis upgrades === At its 1980 launch, the chassis of the Citation X-11 was upgraded with front and rear stabilizer bars and a retuned sport suspension, which were kept throughout its production. In place of steel wheels, the X-11 featured 13-inch [[rallye rim|rallye rims]] with Goodyear P205/70R-13 white-letter tires. In 1981, the 13-inch wheels were replaced with 14-inch wheels with Goodyear Eagle GT P215/60 R14 radial tires. To upgrade handling, for 1982, the steering rack was relocated from the firewall to the subframe holding the engine and front suspension. The design change was intended to prevent subframe movement from affecting steering behavior. For 1980, the X-11 offered only handling upgrades over a Citation, with the powertrain consisting of a 90hp 2.5L inline-4 and a 115hp 2.8L V6. Alongside the standard Citation, the X-11 was available with either a 4-speed overdrive manual transmission or a 3-speed automatic transmission (the only transmission available for 1985). To aid acceleration, axle ratios of the X-11 were changed, alongside the transmission gearing. A taller first gear was intended to allow the X-11 to accelerate to 60 mph without shifting to third gear. For 1981, the X-11 was powered exclusively by a "high-output" version of the 2.8L V6; a higher-performance dual-tip exhaust system raised output to 135hp/165lb-ft of torque. As before, the X-11 maintained separate final-drive ratios. In 1982, emissions regulations required a decrease in torque output, to 145 lb-ft (horsepower remained unchanged). This output remained the same through 1984. In 1985, the carbureted engine was replaced by a fuel-injected version of the 2.8L V6 with output decreased to 130hp/155lb-ft of torque. In slightly different tuning, the Citation X-11 shared its powertrain with the Chevrolet Celebrity Eurosport, Pontiac 6000STE, and Pontiac Fiero. === Body upgrades === In 1980, the Citation X-11 shared most of its powertrain with the standard Citation, with the model being mostly a chassis and visual upgrade. Alongside the alloy wheels and tires, the X-11 featured a trunklid spoiler, sport mirrors, body skirting, and side striping. In 1981, to better distinguish the model from standard two-tone Citations, the side striping of the X-11 was replaced in favor of large "X-11" door graphic, which remained in use for the rest of its production. The model is best distinguished from a standard Citation by its use of a black grille (the only exterior chrome trim on a Citation II X-11 is the Chevrolet grille bowtie and trunklid badging). In 1981, a functional cowl-induction hood scoop was added. Under hard acceleration, a solenoid operated switch opened a flap that let in extra air. While produced without the front bench seat seen in the launch of the Citation, the interior of the X-11 was most widely differentiated with the use of a sport steering wheel. The X-11 was produced with its own instrument panel, which featured a full set of engine gauges (6000 RPM tachometer for 1980, 7000 RPM tachometer for 1981–1985). === Racing === The [[SCCA]] classified the X-11 in Showroom Stock B class. Bob McConnell drove a 1981 X-11 to SSB National Championships in 1982 and 1984. == Awards == The Chevrolet Citation was awarded [[Motor Trend Car of the Year]] for 1980. In 2009, the editorial staff of Car and Driver criticized the 1980 Motor Trend decision (alongside several other vehicle awards{{cite web|url=http://www.caranddriver.com/features/dishonorable-mention-the-10-most-embarrassing-award-winners-in-automotive-history|title=Dishonorable Mention: The 10 Most Embarrassing Award Winners in Automotive History|date=|publisher=www.caranddriver.com|accessdate=2012-06-29}}), citing poor build quality and mechanical reliability undeserving of such an award in hindsight. [[Car and Driver]], along with several other car magazines of the time, were duped when GM lent them specially modified versions of the X-body vehicles in which heavy [[torque steer]] had been engineered out (torque steer was a handling trait common to X-platform vehicles). [[Patrick Bedard]] of ''Car and Driver'' said that they were completely surprised by this when they drove a production version some time later.{{cite web|url=http://www.caranddriver.com/features/08q2/the_skeptic_has_a_malibu_moment-column|title=The Skeptic has a Malibu Moment – Column – Auto Reviews|publisher=Car and Driver|accessdate=2010-05-01|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609084833/http://www.caranddriver.com/features/08q2/the_skeptic_has_a_malibu_moment-column|archivedate=2011-06-09}} Like the other X-body cars, the Citation was plagued by numerous reports of a [[GM X platform (1980)#Mechanical problems|tendency to lock the rear wheels upon braking]], causing it to lose control and crash. == Sales == {| class="wikitable" |+ ! colspan="2" |Chevrolet Citation production |- !Year !Sales |- |1980 |811,540 |- |1981 |413,379 |- |1982 |165,557 |- |1983 |92,184 |- |1984 |97,205 |- |1985 |62,722 |} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{commons category-inline|Chevrolet Citation}} {{Chevrolet}} {{Chevrolet vehicles}} [[Category:1980s cars]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1979]] [[Category:Chevrolet vehicles|Citation]] [[Category:Compact cars]] [[Category:Coupés]] [[Category:Front-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Hatchbacks]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]]

{{About|the coupé utility produced since 2003|the Minivan produced since 1997 sold in America|Pontiac Montana}} {{unreferenced|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox automobile |name = Chevrolet Montana |aka = Chevrolet Tornado ([[Mexico]])
Chevrolet Utility ([[South Africa]])
