{{convert|55.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} (sedan) | weight = {{convert|5166|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} }} [[File:1991 Caprice Classic base.jpg|left|thumb|Pre-facelift Caprice Classic sedan]] [[File:Norfolk Police VA USA - CHevrolet Caprice.jpg|thumb|left|Chevrolet Caprice (9C1)]] The 1991 model was completely restyled—It replaced the 1977-based rectilinear design with rounded, more [[aerodynamic]] sheetmetal. While the body and interior were all new, the chassis and powertrain were largely carried over from the 1990 model; the steel fuel tank was replaced by a HDPE tank (with capacity on sedans decreasing from {{convert|25|USgal|L}} to {{convert|23|USgal|L}}), and [[anti-lock brakes]] were added as standard equipment on all models.Sanow, Edwin J. ''Chevrolet Police Cars'' (Iola, WI: Krause Publications, Inc 1997), p.166. Several major components (including the floor pan) are entirely interchangeable between 1977 and 1996. Much of the engine availability was carried over from the previous generation, which included for all models the 5.0 L [[Chevrolet small-block engine#L03|L03]] V8. A 5.7L[[Chevrolet small-block engine#L05|L05]] V8 was also carried over; it was originally only available on 1991 and 1992 9C1 Police package models, but finally made generally available to the general public on the 1993 Caprice LTZ. ''[[Motor Trend]]'' awarded the new Caprice Classic [[Motor Trend Car of the Year|Car of the Year]]. Two trim levels were initially offered—Caprice and Caprice Classic, replacing the previous Classic and Brougham models. [[General Motors]] had hoped to regain the top spot as America's favorite automobile with the new aerodynamic styling of their full-size offering. [[File:93-96 Chevrolet Caprice Sedan.jpg|left|thumb|1993 facelift Caprice sedan]] [[File:1995 Chevrolet Caprice Classic sedan, front left side.jpg|thumb|left|1995 facelift Caprice]] However, the final B-body Caprice was not well received by critics and did not hold on to high sales numbers. The car's styling was criticized with car aficionados calling it a "beached whale"{{cite web |url=http://www.conceptcarz.com/vehicle/z12088/Chevrolet-Caprice.aspx |title=Chevrolet Caprice |publisher=www.conceptcarz.com |author=Anonymous |accessdate=2009-12-29}}{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/1997/04/28/225531/index.htm |title=GM: Time to Get in Gear |publisher=www.CNNMoney.com |author=Alex Taylor III |accessdate=2009-12-29 |date=1997-04-28}} and "an upside-down bathtub". For 1993 there were some revisions, the most obvious being the removal of the skirted rear wheel wells in favor of more conventional, open wheel wells. This applied only to the [[sedan (car)|sedan]] model; station wagons retained the skirted wheel wells. A final appearance tweak appeared on the 1995 Caprice sedan in the form of a restyled side window between the back door and C pillar (windows on Caprices of the generation through 1994 were triangular, but the 1995 window had a so-called "[[Hofmeister kink]]", featuring 4 sides and sweeping towards the front, lacking the sharp corner pointed toward the rear), and the wagon was given the same mirrors as the sedan. In 1995 and 1996 the [[Chevrolet Impala#Seventh generation (Impala SS, 1994–1996)|Impala SS]] was exported to Middle Eastern markets [[Badge engineering|badged]] as the Caprice SS, with the car being identical to its American counterpart except for the side fonts on the rear quarter panel and the badge on the dashboard saying ''Caprice SS''.{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}} In 1994 the Caprice received new engines, including an optional mildly detuned version of the [[Chevrolet Corvette|Corvette's]] LT1 350 cu in (5.7 L) engine that put out 260 hp (194 kW) and 330 lb·ft (447 N·m) of torque on 87 octane. The standard engine in all sedans, including 9C1 police cars, was the {{convert|200|hp|abbr=on}}, L99 263 (4.3 L) V8. The LT1 was optional in the 9C1 police package and standard in the wagon.{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}} The LT1 350 was standard in civilian sedans with the addition of the V92 towing package.{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}} The V92 towing package also gave a heavy duty suspension with similar spring rates to the 9C1 police car suspension, 2.93 gears, V08 heavy duty cooling with a mechanical fan, heavy duty rear drum brakes and limited-slip differential.{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}} The 1994 Caprice's interior had a redesign which featured a [[Chevrolet Camaro (fourth generation)|Camaro]] steering wheel, digital speedometer and a new console.{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}} The Caprice 9C1 with the LT1 engine became one of the quickest and most popular modern day police vehicles. This vehicle established such strong devotion by many [[police]] departments that a [[cottage industry]] thrived in refurbishing Caprices for continued police service after GM discontinued production of the car.{{cite news |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1997-11-06/news/9711060120_1_squad-cars-caprices-patrol-cars |work=Chicago Tribune |date=1997-11-06 |page=3 |first=Pat |last=Clawson |title=Police Keep Beloved Caprice and Save Money |quote=The trend to restore Caprices began in 1995 when Shaheen Chevrolet of Lansing, Mich., refurbished the first of 918 squad cars for law agencies nationwide.}} [[File:Chevrolet Caprice wagon.jpg|left|thumb|Caprice Classic wagon]] The car's production was stopped in December of 1996 due to sales pressure from the mid-size [[Chevrolet Lumina]], financial troubles at [[General Motors]], and consumer demand shifting from full-sized family sedans to the increasingly popular [[sport utility vehicle]]s.{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}} The [[Arlington, Texas]] vehicle assembly plant (used for Caprices, [[Buick Roadmaster]], [[Oldsmobile Custom Cruiser]], and [[Cadillac Fleetwood]]) was converted to produce GM's more profitable full size SUVs (the [[Chevrolet Tahoe|Tahoe]] and [[Chevrolet Suburban|Suburban]]). In 1997, the Lumina LTZ would take the Caprice's place as Chevrolet's premium passenger car. Total production of 1991–96 models was 689,257 with production ending on December 13, 1996.The Encyclopedia of American Cars, 2006 Edition The [[Chevrolet Impala]] nameplate was reintroduced to the American passenger car market in 2000 as the marque's premium offering, albeit in a [[front wheel drive]] configuration. {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Yearly Changes of 4th-Generation (1991-1996) Chevrolet Caprice ! Both Single Exhaust |- !9C1 Police Package |350 cu in (5.7L) LO5 V8 195 hp, Single Exhaust | colspan="2" |350 cu in (5.7L) LO5 V8 205 hp Single Exhaust |} == Fifth generation (1999–2006) == {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | width = 200 | image1 = 1999-2003 Chevrolet Caprice SS sedan 01.jpg | caption1 = 1999–2003 Chevrolet Caprice SS | image2 = 1999 Holden Statesman (WH) sedan (2015-06-25) 01.jpg | caption2 = 1999–2001 [[Holden WH Statesman|Holden Statesman (WH)]] | image3 = 2003 Holden Statesman (WK) sedan (2016-01-04) 01.jpg | caption3 = 2003–2004 [[Holden WK Statesman|Holden Statesman (WK)]] }} {{Main|Holden Caprice}} General Motors revived the Chevrolet Caprice nameplate in the Middle East and Latin/South American markets on imported [[Holden Caprice|Holden Statesman and Caprice]] models built by its Australian subsidiary [[Holden]]. The [[Holden WH Caprice|WH]] series Statesman/Caprice was the first series to be engineered to support both left- and right-hand drive (Middle Eastern market being [[left-hand drive|LHD]] while Australia [[right-hand drive]]) in order to allow for manufacturing of export versions. Same was true for the related short-wheelbase [[Holden VT Commodore]], whose left-hand drive version became the [[Chevrolet Lumina]] in the Middle East (In Mexico only, the Commodore and Holden models were sold alongside the Lumina and Caprice). The Middle Eastern Caprice came out in 2000 in four versions, base LS, standard mid-range LTZ, a sporty SS and the range topper Royale (introduced in 2002). Differences between the models were mostly equipment and slight styling tweaks. The base LS came with a 3.8 L V6 engine; the LTZ came standard with a {{convert|295|hp|kW|0|order=flip|abbr=on}} 5.7 L ''Gen III'' V8, the SS and Royale came with a {{convert|325|hp|kW|0|order=flip|abbr=on}} version of the same engine. In 2003, Holden launched a revised and facelifted Statesman and Caprice, which was reflected in their Middle Eastern versions for the 2004 model year. The new models sported new front and rear fascias and completely redesigned interior. Engines carried over unchanged. In 1999, GM again considered resurrecting the Caprice name in America for 2000, this time under this generation, and as a new Caprice 9C1 long before the appearance of the sixth generation model (third generation Holden Caprice) as the Caprice PPV, but it did return several years later as such.{{cite web|url=http://www.drive.com.au/motor-news/true-blue-nypd-20100823-13g6n.html|title=True blue NYPD|publisher=drive.com.au|date=|accessdate=2014-08-04}} == Sixth generation (2006–2017) == {{Infobox automobile | name = Sixth generation | image = New Eagle Controls Display (24462211776).jpg | manufacturer = [[Holden]] ([[General Motors]]) | aka= [[Buick Park Avenue]] ([[China]])

6-speed [[GM 6L80 transmission|6L80]] automatic }} {{Main|Holden Caprice (WM)}} [[File:2008 Chevrolet Caprice LTZ (Kuwait) 01.jpg|thumb|left|2008 Chevrolet Caprice LTZ (Middle East)]] [[File:2008 Chevrolet Caprice LTZ (Kuwait) 02.jpg|thumb|left|2008 Chevrolet Caprice LTZ (Middle East)]] === Middle East === {{unreferenced section|date=September 2016}} In November 2006, a completely redesigned Caprice lineup was launched, again based on the recently introduced [[Holden Caprice (WM)|Holden WM Statesman/Caprice]]. The new Caprice lineup includes the base LS, LTZ, SS and Royale, all sporting the new {{convert|360|hp|kW|0|order=flip|abbr=on}} ''[[GM LS engine#L98|L98]]'' 6.0 L V8. The LS, LTZ, and Royale all share the front bumper as the Holden WM Statesman while the LS lacks the Statesman's trademark foglights which are seen on the LTZ and Royale; the SS gains the Caprice's front bumper and foglamps minus the parking sensors. The LS also gains the [[Holden Commodore (VE)|VE Commodore]] Omega's interior and rims, while the LTZ gains the rims from the VE Commodore V based on the Commodore Omega, and the Statesman's interior minus the headrests with the LCD screens and DVD player, while the Royale gains the Statesman's rims, and the Statesman's interior with the LCD screens in the head rests and DVD player from the Holden versions, the grille from the [[Holden Caprice|Daewoo Veritas]], hood ornament similar to the one that the appears on the 4th and 5th generation models, and the SS gains the same rims as the WM Caprice, interior from the Caprice minus the headrests with the LCD screens and DVD player, color coded version of the grille's trim, and the optional lip spoiler from the WM Caprice. The Caprice was updated for 2011 to include the features that Holden included the Holden Caprice. The Caprice lettering engraved on the chrome trim which was on the car from 2000 until 2010 on the trim was dropped & replaced by a Caprice nameplate badge which is below the chrome trim on the left end of the rear fascia on the trunk. The V6 engines were dropped in the LS & LTZ leaving the V8 as the standard engine while the LS got the rims that were previously on the LTZ from 2007-2010 as well as previously seen on the VE Commodore V based on the Omega Series I model, while the LTZ & Royale get the rims seen on the VE Commodore Calais V Series II & the 2010-2011 [[Chevrolet Omega|Chevrolet Omega Fittipaldi Edition]] and the SS now gains the rims that the WM Caprice V Series II has. The LS, LTZ, & Royale still retain the Statesman front bumper, while the SS still retains the Caprice/Caprice V front bumper. The Royale also gains a rear vision camera in the chrome trim on the trunk which is absent on the LS, LTZ, & SS like the Holden Caprice & Caprice V. For the 2013 model year for the Caprice SS the Impala badge on the trunk was dropped in favor of the traditional Chevrolet bowtie. The Caprice was updated again based on the [[Holden Caprice (WM)|Holden WN Caprice]]. The Caprice LS & LTZ still retain the front bumper as the WM Statesman while the Royale now gets the same front bumper as seen on the WM/WN Caprice & the Caprice SS & the rims that were previously on the 2011-2013 Caprice SS, the 2010-2013 WM Caprice V, & currently the WN Caprice LPG model, and the [[Holden Commodore (VF)]] Calais's interior just like the Holden models. The SS now gains the rear vision camera which was previously only available on the Caprice Royale while it is still not available on the Caprice LS or LTZ, the same interior updates the WN Caprice & Caprice Royale, and also gets the same rims as on the WN Caprice V & while the LS, LTZ & SS gain new rims. The Holden-sourced Chevrolet Caprice in the LS trim is used in Middle East police forces in the [[Saudi Arabia]], [[United Arab Emirates]] such as the [[Abu Dhabi Police]], [[Royal Oman Police]] and [[Dubai Police Force]]. In 2012 after the [[2011 Libyan Civil War|Libyan Civil War]] ended the Abu Dhabi Police donated 100 of its Caprice LS police cars to Libya along with uniforms making it the only country in the continent of [[Africa]] to have the Holden sourced Caprices in service. [[File:ChevroletCapricePPV-01.jpg|thumb|right|Chevrolet Caprice PPV (Concept)]] [[File:2011 Chevrolet Caprice PPV -- 12-06-2010 rear.jpg|thumb|right|Chevrolet Caprice PPV (US)]] === North America === On October 5, 2009, General Motors announced the Chevrolet Caprice [[Police vehicles in the United States and Canada|Police Patrol Vehicle (PPV)]].{{cite web |last=Wert |first=Ray |date=2009-10-05 |url=http://jalopnik.com/5373645/exclusive-the-chevy-caprice-police-car-is-back |title=EXCLUSIVE: The Chevy Caprice Police Car Is Back! |work=[[Jalopnik]] |publisher=[[Gawker Media]] |accessdate=2009-10-05}} The Chevrolet Caprice is sold only to law enforcement agencies in the U.S. and was not available to the Canadian market as of 2011. General Motors will not directly sell a Caprice PPV to the general public, however, some vehicles have been purchased by individuals via dealer sales channels. These included GM and dealer demonstrator vehicles, excess unsold dealer inventory, and purchases for demonstration use by law enforcement upfitters and other related businesses.{{cite web|url=http://www.newcaprice.com |title=New Caprice |publisher=New Caprice |date=|accessdate=2014-07-15}} The Caprice PPV is imported from Australia and is a [[captive import]] of the [[Holden Caprice]] from the [[Holden Caprice (WM)|WM range]], not the short-wheelbase [[Holden Commodore]] from the [[Holden Commodore (VE)|VE Range]], which is a main patrol car in Australia. However, these cars both share the Zeta platform.{{cite web |last=Pettendy |first=Marton |date=2009-10-05 |url=http://www.goauto.com.au/mellor/mellor.nsf/story2/4DB981DD3B661FE0CA25764600253D2B |title=Official: Holden to export Commodore as US police car |work=GoAuto |publisher=John Mellor |accessdate=2009-10-05}} The Caprice comes with the 6.0 L ''[[GM LS engine#L77|L77]]'' [[Active Fuel Management|AFM]] V8, which was standard in 2011 and has been optional since 2012; or the standard 3.6 L ''[[GM High Feature engine#LLT|LLT]]'' [[Gasoline direct injection|SIDI]] V6 engine, which became available nine months later.{{cite web |last=Dowling |first=Joshua |date=2009-10-05 |url=http://www.carpoint.com.au/news/2009/large-passenger/holden/caprice/holden-unveils-police-caprice-16924 |title=Holden unveils Police Caprice |work=CarPoint |accessdate=2009-10-05 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091008112312/http://carpoint.com.au/news/2009/large-passenger/holden/caprice/holden-unveils-police-caprice-16924 |archivedate=2009-10-08 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.gmfleet.com/pdf/2012_Police_Specifications_Manual.pdf |title=2012 GM police specifications |accessdate=2011-10-08 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120131112807/http://www.gmfleet.com/pdf/2012_Police_Specifications_Manual.pdf |archivedate=2012-01-31 }} Both engines are [[E85]] ethanol-capable. The Caprice PPV concept car was based on the Middle Eastern spec Caprice LS, which was based on the Holden WM Caprice Series I. The front end and grille are the same as the 2007-2010 Caprice LS. The Caprice letter is engraved into the chrome trim on the trunk, there is PPV lettering on the right side of the rear fascia and a FlexFuel nameplate, which was on GM vehicles in North America from 2007 through 2009. The PPV has dual exhaust, a floor shifter in the console, a prisoner partition with rifle and shotgun mounts, lights and siren controls in the console, 18 inch steel rims & center caps from the Impala 9C1, and a touch screen in place of the radio and HVAC controls. A prototype similar to the concept car in LAPD was shown around Australia by Holden. Another prototype tested by the [[Los Angeles Police Department|LAPD]] had the same front end, grille, steel rims and center caps as the production models, while the car was based on the Series I WM Caprice with its rear bumper, colored turn signal indicators lamps on the side of the car, chrome trim with Caprice engraved on it, & V8 badge from the 2007-2010 Caprice. Special features are added by Chevrolet for the Caprice Police Patrol Vehicle (PPV). The driver's seat has a special indentation made to accommodate a police officer's equipment belt so it makes it more comfortable to drive. Special tuning such as Performance Algorithm Liftfoot (PAL) calibration and a performance-tuned suspension was added for increased performance meant specifically for police needs. Previously, the future of Holden's North American export program had been the subject of contradictory announcements as General Motors emerged from [[General Motors Chapter 11 reorganization|bankruptcy]]. On July 11, 2009, [[Bob Lutz (businessman)|Bob Lutz]] declared the Commodore-based Pontiac G8 "too good to waste" and indicated it would return as a Chevrolet Caprice.{{cite web |last1=Tingwall |first1=Eric |last2=Zenela |first2=David |date=2009-07-11 |url=http://www.automobilemag.com/features/news/bob_lutz_pontiac_g8_chevrolet_caprice/index.html |title=Bob Lutz: Pontiac G8 will live on as a Chevrolet Caprice |work=[[Automobile Magazine]] |publisher=Source Interlink Media |accessdate=2009-07-12}}{{cite web |last=Welch |first=David |date=2009-07-10 |url=http://www.businessweek.com/bwdaily/dnflash/content/jul2009/db20090710_847893.htm |title=GM May Revive Its Popular Pontiac G8 |work=[[BusinessWeek]] |publisher=[[McGraw-Hill]] |accessdate=2009-07-11 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090715020336/http://www.businessweek.com/bwdaily/dnflash/content/jul2009/db20090710_847893.htm |archivedate=2009-07-15 }} However, it was undisclosed as to whether the revived Caprice was to be based on the short-wheelbase Holden Commodore (like the Pontiac G8) or the extended length Holden Caprice, like the Middle Eastern Chevrolet Caprice.{{cite web |last=Nunez |first=Alex |date=2009-07-11 |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2009/07/11/lutz-pontiac-g8-to-continue-as-chevy-caprice-in-u-s-z28-likel/ |title=BREAKING: Lutz says Pontiac G8 to survive as Chevy Caprice in U.S.; Camaro Z28 reportedly dead |work=[[Autoblog.com|Autoblog]] |publisher=[[Weblogs, Inc.]] |accessdate=2009-07-12}} Several days later, Lutz retracted his comment, citing market conditions,{{cite web |url=http://fastlane.gmblogs.com/archives/2009/07/it_seemed_like_a_good_idea_at_the_time….html |title=It Seemed Like a Good Idea at the Time… |author=Bob Lutz |work=GM FastLane Blog |date=2009-07-16 |accessdate=2009-07-19 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090720072540/http://fastlane.gmblogs.com/archives/2009/07/it_seemed_like_a_good_idea_at_the_time%E2%80%A6.html |archivedate=2009-07-20 }} while GM CEO [[Frederick Henderson]] confirmed that police applications were being studied.{{cite web |last=Lassa |first=Todd |date=2009-07-17 |url=http://www.motortrend.com/features/consumer/gm_ceo_fritz_henderson_interview/hummer_saturn_pontiac_g8.html |title=A Short Drive with GM CEO Fritz Henderson |work=[[Motor Trend]] |publisher=Source Interlink Media |accessdate=2009-10-05}} The Caprice police car has had a positive reception, placing perfect scores in an assessment by The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department, with the only criticism being directed at over-cautious electronic stability control.{{cite news |author=Barry Park |url=http://news.drive.com.au/drive/motor-news/holden-beats-ford-in-copcar-shootout-20110517-1eqox.html |title=Holden Caprice based police pursuit cop car |publisher=News.drive.com.au |accessdate=2013-12-26 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227101403/http://news.drive.com.au/drive/motor-news/holden-beats-ford-in-copcar-shootout-20110517-1eqox.html |archivedate=2013-12-27 }} What also makes the Caprice PPV different from its Australian & Middle Eastern counterparts the lower end of the front bumper is based on the Commodore Omega Series II's front end, honey comb grille similar to the 2001-2011 [[Ford Crown Victoria Police Interceptor]], and the interior is also from the Commodore Omega which was the common trim of VE Commodore to be used by law enforcement in Australia and New Zealand from 2007-2013. The detective version used the same interior that the Middle Eastern spec Caprice LS had from 2007-2013. Updates to the Caprice PPV for 2014 include the interior from the [[Holden VF Commodore|Commodore Evoke]] with a [[Gear stick|column shifter]] to make room for equipment replacing the floor shifter that was in the 2011-2013 models, a full mounting plate for equipment, & the 9C3 unmarked/detective version being discontinued. Updates to the Caprice PPV for 2015 now has the car gaining the same rear vision camera as the civilian WN, Royale, & SS models.{{cite web|url=http://gmauthority.com/blog/2014/08/2015-chevy-caprice-ppv-gets-rear-vision-camera-color-changes//|title=2015 Chevy Caprice PPV Gets Rear Vision Camera, Color Changes|publisher=gmauthority.com}} Like its Australian & Middle Eastern counterparts, production of the Caprice PPV ended in 2017 at the Elizabeth plant after Holden ended manufacturing operations.{{cite web|url=http://gmauthority.com/blog/2014/08/bad-news-from-oz-no-more-holden-caprice-after-2017/|title=Bad News From Oz: No More Holden Caprice After 2017|publisher=gmauthority.com}} South Africa (1975 to 1978)== From late 1975 to 1978 the [[Australia]]n developed [[Statesman (automobile)|Statesman Caprice]] was marketed in [[South Africa]] as the ''Chevrolet Caprice Classic''.''When is a Holden not a Holden'', Restored Cars #191, Nov-Dec 2008, pages 32 to 35[https://web.archive.org/web/20101231134120/http://moby302.co.za/brochures/1976_chevrolet/caprice.html South African brochure for 1976 Chevrolet Caprice Classic, moby302.co.za via web.archive.org] The V8-engined Caprice Classic received full equipment, with reading lights, air conditioning, and imported leather upholstery.{{cite journal | ref = SAM1275 | journal = SA Motor | title = News Models | page = 59 | editor-last = Howard | editor-first = Tony | publisher = Scott Publications | location = Cape Town, South Africa | date=December 1975 }} It was very similar to the 5-liter [[Chevrolet Constantia|Constantia]], albeit fitted with a different grille, hubcaps, and a vinyl roof. [[Category:Chevrolet vehicles|Lumina (Australia)]]

{{Commons Category}} [[File:1979 Chevrolet K5 Blazer Cheyenne.jpg|alt= Chevrolet Blazer (1979)|thumb|Chevrolet Blazer (1979)]] '''Chevrolet Blazer''' (and '''GMC Jimmy''') can refer to one of several SUV models from [[General Motors]]:
* The full-size [[Chevrolet K5 Blazer]], based on the C/K pickup chassis and built from 1969 to 1994 (renamed to Tahoe in 1995 for the 2-door model) * The compact and mid-size [[Chevrolet S-10 Blazer]], based on the S-10 pickup and built from 1983 to 2005 * The [[Chevrolet TrailBlazer]], originally a trim package on the S-10 Blazer until 2002, when it became its own, larger model * The [[Chevrolet Tahoe]], sold in Argentina, Brazil, Ecuador and Venezuela under the Grand Blazer name from 1990 to 2000 to 2019 * The [[Chevrolet Blazer (crossover)|Chevrolet Blazer]], a mid-size crossover that is available since 2019 * The [[Chevrolet Trailblazer (crossover)|Chevrolet Trailblazer]], a subcompact crossover that is available since 2019 in China and 2020 in North America
== See also == * [[GMC Yukon]] – nameplate created to reduce confusion between the compact and full size Jimmies.

1958 [[Chevrolet Nomad]] | engine = {{convert|235|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Blue Flame (engine)|''Blue Flame'']] [[Straight-six engine|I6]]
{{convert|283|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chevrolet Small-Block engine#283|''Turbo Fire'']] [[V8 engine|V8]]
{{convert|348|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chevrolet Big-Block engine#348|''W-series Turbo Thrust'']] V8 | transmission = 3-speed (close-ratio) [[Manual transmission|manual]]
3-speed [[overdrive (mechanics)|overdrive]] manual
[[Turboglide]] [[Automatic transmission|auto.]]
2-speed [[Powerglide]] auto. | wheelbase = {{convert|117.5|in|mm|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|209.1|in|mm|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|77.7|in|mm|abbr=on}} | height = | weight = 2-door {{convert|3696|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}}
4-door {{convert|3743|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} | predecessor = 1957 [[Chevrolet One-Fifty]] 2-door & 4-door wagons | sp = us }} The '''Chevrolet Yeoman''' was a [[station wagon]] produced by [[Chevrolet]] for the 1958 model year. The Yeoman was available in two models, a two-door and a four-door, both with six-passenger [[seating capacity]]. Based on the [[Chevrolet Delray|Delray]] passenger car series, the Yeoman represented the entry-level selections in the 1958 Chevrolet station wagon lineup, which also included the [[Chevrolet Brookwood|Brookwood]] and the [[Chevrolet Nomad|Nomad]]. ==Design== For 1958, Chevrolet models were redesigned longer, lower, and heavier than their 1957 predecessors. The first ever production Chevrolet big block V8, the [[Chevrolet Big-Block engine#348|{{convert|348|cuin|cc|abbr=on}}]], was now an option. Chevrolet's design for the year fared better than its other [[General Motors|GM]] offerings, and lacked the overabundance of chrome found on Pontiacs, Oldsmobiles, Buicks and Cadillacs. Complementing Chevrolet's front design was a broad grille and quad headlights that helped simulate a 'Baby Cadillac'; the wagon's tail received a fan-shaped alcove on both side panels, similar to the sedan's, but wagon's housed single tail lights instead of dual (triple on Impala) to accommodate the tailgate. Despite being a recession year, sales increased and overtook Ford, which held the top position in 1957) and the Bel Air the most popular Chevrolet model. The Nomad station wagon name also reappeared in 1958 when the vehicle became as the premium four-door Chevrolet [[station wagon]], rather than the two-door designs of the 1955-57 Nomads. Most Chevrolet station wagon models had two tail lights housed in abbreviated alcoves, which were made smaller to accommodate the rear gate. A new dash was used.{{cite web|url= http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet_Owners_Manual/1958%20Chevrolet%20Guide-04.html |title=Directory 1958 Chevrolet Owners Manual |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}} The value of a drag coefficient for 1958 Chevy wagons is estimated by a-c, is Cd = 0.6.{{cite web|url= http://www.automobile-catalog.com/make/chevrolet_usa/full-size_chevrolet_5gen/full-size_del_ray_wagon/1958.html |title=1958 Chevrolet (USA) Yeoman Wagon full range specs |publisher=Automobile-catalog.com |date= |accessdate=2015-12-16}} The Delray-based Yeoman was the lowest version and featured minimal interior and exterior trim and limited options. ==Safety== [[File:58 Chevrolet Wagon ad cut away.png|thumb|left| 1958 Chevrolet brochure wagon body cutaway]] The Yeoman featured Chevrolet's new "Safety-Girder" cruciform frame. Similar in layout to the frame adopted for the 1957 Cadillac, it featured box-section side rails and a boxed front cross member that bowed under the engine, these "x-frames" were used on other 1958 to 1964 Chevys, as well as Cadillac. The rear was tied together by a channel-section cross member. {{cite web|url= http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet_Wagons/1958%20Chevrolet%20Wagons-06-07.html |title=Directory Index: Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet_Wagons |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}} This design was later criticized as providing less protection in the event of a side impact collision, but would persevere until 1965.{{cite web|author=Auto Editors of ''Consumer Guide'' |url= http://auto.howstuffworks.com/1958-chevrolet.htm |title=1958 Chevrolet One-Fifty |publisher=Auto.howstuffworks.com |date=2007-08-19 |accessdate=2015-12-16}} ==Engines== *{{convert|235|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Blue Flame (engine)|''Blue Flame'']] straight six *{{convert|283|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} {{convert|195|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} to {{convert|220|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} [[Chevrolet Small-Block engine#283|''Turbo Fire'']] small block V8 *{{convert|348|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} {{convert|250|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} to {{convert|350|bhp|kW PS|0|abbr=on}} [[Chevrolet Big-Block engine#348|''W-series Turbo Thrust'']] big block V8 ==2 door wagons== [[File:Chevrolet Yeoman (rear).jpg|thumb|left|Chevrolet Yeoman (rear)]] Of the 187,000 1958 Chevrolet wagons built, only 16,590{{cite web|url= http://www.oldride.com/library/1958_chevrolet_brookwood.html |title=1958 Chevrolet Brookwood |publisher=Oldride.com |date= |accessdate=2015-12-16}} of these were 2-door model Yeoman (not counting Delray Sedan Delivery), Chevrolet’s entry-level wagon. The Yeoman was dropped (along with the Delray) at the end of 1958. For 1959, Chevrolet's Brookwood would now offer a 2-door wagon and become the lowest priced station wagon. Chevrolet's two other wagon lines, the mid-range Brookwood and top-trimmed Nomad were available only as 4-door wagons for 1958. {{clear}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Early Chevrolet cars}} {{Chevrolet Vehicles}} [[Category:Chevrolet vehicles|Yeoman]] [[Category:Station wagons]] [[Category:Full-size vehicles]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:1950s cars]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/2001:B07:645F:16D1:A45D:887:F134:231E|2001:B07:645F:16D1:A45D:887:F134:231E]] ([[User talk:2001:B07:645F:16D1:A45D:887:F134:231E|talk]]) to last version by Cydebot
revision.text:
The '''Chevrolet Parkwood''' was a [[station wagon]] built by [[Chevrolet]] from 1959 to 1961. As the station wagon equivalent of the [[Chevrolet Bel Air|Bel Air]] passenger car series, it represented the middle member of the Chevrolet station wagon lineup of those years, above the lowest-priced [[Chevrolet Brookwood|Brookwood]] models, but below the luxury-leader [[Chevrolet Nomad|Nomad]]. ==1959-1960== {{Infobox automobile | name = First generation | image = [[Image:1959 Chevrolet Parkwood.jpg|250px]] | caption = 1959 Chevrolet Parkwood at the Bayside Exposition Center in Boston, Massachusetts | manufacturer = [[Chevrolet]] ([[General Motors]]) | aka = | production = | model_years = 1959-1960 | assembly = | designer = | class = [[Full-size]] | body_style = 4-door [[station wagon#Four-door wagons|wagon]] | layout = [[FR layout]] | platform = [[GM B platform]] | related = 1959–1960 [[Chevrolet Biscayne]]
1959–1960 [[Chevrolet Bel Air]]
1959–1960 [[Chevrolet Impala]]
1959–1960 [[Chevrolet Brookwood]]
1959–1960 [[Chevrolet Kingswood]]
1959–1960 [[Chevrolet Nomad]]
1959–1960 [[Chevrolet El Camino]] | wheelbase = {{convert|119.0|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}http://www.oldride.com/library/1959_chevrolet_brookwood.html | length = | width = | height = | weight = | predecessor = 1958 [[Chevrolet Brookwood]] wagon | successor = | sp = us }} All 1959 and 1960 Parkwoods were six-passenger models, whereas the [[Chevrolet Kingswood|Kingswood]] (Chevrolet's other Bel Air equivalent during those two years), had seating for nine. The Parkwood became available in both passenger configurations for 1961, when the Kingswood name was dropped. (The latter name returned for 1969.) The Parkwood name was also dropped for 1962, when all Chevrolet station wagons began sharing series names with their passenger-car linemates. Throughout its three-year production run, the Parkwood was available with either a six-cylinder or [[V8 engine]]. [[Image:1960 Chevrolet Parkwood.jpg|thumb|left|Tailgate of the 1960 Chevrolet Parkwood station wagon]] {{clear}} ==1961== {{Infobox automobile | name = Second generation | image = [[File:1961 Chevrolet Parkwood wagon.jpg|250px]] | caption = 1961 Chevrolet Parkwood 9-passenger wagon | manufacturer = | aka = | production = | model_years = 1961 | assembly = | designer = | class = [[Full-size]] | body_style = 4-door [[station wagon]] | layout = [[FR layout]] | platform = [[GM B platform|B-body]] | related = {{Unbulleted list| 1961–1964 [[Chevrolet Biscayne]]|1961–1964 [[Chevrolet Bel Air]]| 1961–1964 [[Chevrolet Impala]]| 1961 [[Chevrolet Brookwood]]| 1961 [[Chevrolet Nomad]] }} | engine = {{convert|235|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Blue Flame (engine)|''Blue Flame'']] [[Straight-six engine|I6]]
{{convert|283|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chevrolet Small-Block engine#283|''Turbo Fire'']] [[V8 engine|V8]]
{{convert|348|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[Chevrolet Big-Block engine#348|''W-series Turbo Thrust'']] [[V8 engine|V8]] | transmission = 3-speed manual
4-speed manual
Powerglide automatic{{cite web|url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Chevrolet/1962_Chevrolet/1962_Chevrolet_Full_Size_Brochure/1962%20Chevrolet%20Full%20Size-14-15.html |title=Directory Index: Chevrolet/1962_Chevrolet/1962_Chevrolet_Full_Size_Brochure |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-11}} | wheelbase = {{convert|119|in|mm|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|209.3|in|mm|abbr=on}} | width = | height = | weight = | predecessor = | successor = 1962 [[Chevrolet Bel Air]] wagon | sp = us }} For 1961, Chevrolet again had a totally new body, not just new sheetmetal. Its wheelbase remained {{convert|119|in|mm|abbr=on}}, but its length was now reduced slightly to {{convert|209.3|in|mm|abbr=on}}. All engines options of the previous year remained in effect with the standard engines being the 235.5 CID Six of {{convert|135|hp|kW|abbr=on}} or the 283 CID V8 of {{convert|170|hp|kW|abbr=on}}. The V8 cost $110 more than the Six and weighed {{convert|5|lb|kg|abbr=on}} less. GM discontinued the Chevrolet Parkwood name for 1962, instead naming their station wagons after their series names: [[Chevrolet Biscayne|Biscayne]], [[Chevrolet Bel Air|Bel Air]] and [[Chevrolet Impala|Impala]]. ===Safety=== Chevrolet's 1961 Parkwood (as well as all other full size Chevrolets) featured a shortened version of Chevrolet's "Safety-Girder" cruciform frame introduced in '58. Similar in layout to the frame adopted for the 1957 Cadillac, it featured box-section side rails and a boxed front cross member that bowed under the engine, these "x-frames" were used on other 1958 to 1964 Chevys, as well as Cadillac. The rear was tied together by a channel-section cross member. {{cite web|url=http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet_Wagons/1958%20Chevrolet%20Wagons-06-07.html |title=Directory Index: Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet_Wagons |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}} This design was later criticized as providing less protection in the event of a side impact collision, but would persevere until 1965. http://auto.howstuffworks.com/1958-chevrolet.htm ===Chevrolet Parkwood Discontinuation and Replacement=== GM discontinued the Chevrolet Parkwood wagon nameplate (as well as the Brookwood and Nomad wagon names) for 1962, instead naming their station wagons after their series names: [[Chevrolet Biscayne|Biscayne]] (replacing Brookwood directly), [[Chevrolet Bel Air|Bel Air]] and [[Chevrolet Impala|Impala]]. The 1962-'64 Biscayne, Bel Air, and Impala wagons were very similar to Chevy's 1961 wagon models. {{clear}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Early Chevrolet cars}} {{Chevrolet vehicles}} [[Category:Chevrolet vehicles|Parkwood]] [[Category:Station wagons]] [[Category:1950s cars]] [[Category:1960s cars]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1959]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]] {{classicpow-auto-stub}}

{{about|the minivan sold in North America during 1989-1996|the sedan and coupé sold in North America during 1990-2001|Chevrolet Lumina|other uses|Chevrolet Lumina (disambiguation)}} {{more citations needed|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox automobile |image=1994-1996 Chevrolet Lumina APV.jpg |name=Chevrolet Lumina APV |aka=Chevrolet Lumina Minivan (1994-1996) |manufacturer=[[General Motors]] |production=1989–1996 |class=[[Minivan]] |transmission= 3-speed [[Turbo-Hydramatic 125#Turbo-Hydramatic 125|3T40]] [[automatic transmission|automatic]]
4-speed [[GM 4T60-E transmission|4T60-E]] automatic |layout=[[Front-engine, front-wheel-drive layout|Transverse front-engine, front-wheel drive]] |platform=[[GM U platform]]: GMT199 |body_style=3-door [[van]] |engine=3.1 L ''[[GM 60-Degree V6 engine#LG6|LG6]]'' [[V6]]
3.4 L ''[[GM 60-Degree V6 engine#LA1|LA1]]'' [[V6]]
3.8 L ''[[GM 3800 engine#L27 Naturally Aspirated|L27]]'' [[V6]] |length=1990–93: {{convert|194.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1993–96: {{convert|191.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |wheelbase={{convert|109.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |width={{convert|73.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height=1990–92: {{convert|65.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1993–97: {{convert|65.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |weight=3599–3899 lb (1632–1769 kg) |predecessor=[[Chevrolet Celebrity|Chevrolet Celebrity (station wagon)]] |successor=[[Chevrolet Venture]] |assembly=[[Tarrytown, New York]], U.S. |related=[[Oldsmobile Silhouette]]
[[Pontiac Trans Sport]] |designer=Dick Ruzzin{{cite web|last1=Rosa|first1=Mike|title=Design Notes: Interview with Dick Ruzzin|url=http://autosofinterest.com/2012/10/04/design-notes-interview-with-d-ick-ruzzin/|website=Autos of Interest|accessdate=21 September 2016}} }} The '''Chevrolet Lumina APV''' is a [[minivan]] that was produced by the [[Chevrolet]] division of [[General Motors]]. The first front-wheel drive minivan sold by Chevrolet, the Lumina APV was sold in a single generation from the 1990 to 1996 model years. Marketed alongside the [[Pontiac Trans Sport]] and [[Oldsmobile Silhouette]], the Lumina APV competed against the Dodge Grand Caravan/Plymouth Grand Voyager, the extended-length Ford Aerostar, and the Mazda MPV. Introduced a year before the [[Chrysler minivans (AS)|second-generation Chrysler minivans]], the Lumina APV was the first American-market minivan to adopt the form factor of the Dodge Caravan and Plymouth Voyager. Though manufactured on a model-specific chassis, the Lumina APV was front-wheel drive, deriving its powertrain from GM sedans. In terms of size, the Lumina APV was slotted between the [[Chevrolet Astro]] and full-size [[Chevrolet van|Chevrolet Van]]. During its production, the Lumina APV and its Pontiac and Oldsmobile counterparts were assembled at the [[North Tarrytown Assembly]] facility, becoming the final vehicles produced there prior to its closure. For 1997, Chevrolet adopted a distinct nameplate for its front-wheel drive minivan, replacing the Lumina APV with the [[Chevrolet Venture]].    == Background == In response to the [[Chrysler minivans (S)|first-generation Chrysler minivans]], General Motors introduced the rear-wheel drive [[Chevrolet Astro]] (and GMC Safari) for the 1985 model year. Sized closely to the short-wheelbase Chevrolet Van, the Astro was marketed in both passenger and cargo van configurations. In 1986, GM unveiled the [[Pontiac Trans Sport]] concept vehicle, largely serving as a preview of the APV model lines.{{Cite web|url=https://jalopnik.com/was-this-gm-minivan-the-greatest-letdown-in-automotive-1665847028|title=Was This GM Minivan The Greatest Letdown In Automotive History?|last=Orlove|first=Raphael|website=Jalopnik|language=en-US|access-date=2019-06-26}} While far more radical in body design, the Trans Sport concept was the first minivan to adopt the front-wheel drive form factor used by the Chrysler minivans. In contrast to the Astro/Safari, which used a variety of components from Chevrolet/GMC light trucks, the front-wheel drive GMT199 platform was dedicated to the Chevrolet, Pontiac, and Oldsmobile minivans, sharing primarily engines and transmissions with other GM vehicles. In place of the official GMT199 platform designation, GM began to use the APV name, standing for All Purpose Vehicle. Chevrolet would receive a Lumina APV, with Oldsmobile receiving the Silhouette; Pontiac adopted the Trans Sport name from the 1986 concept van. During its development, the APV model lines largely benchmarked the extended-length Chrysler vans, closely matching their length, width, and height (on a shorter wheelbase). To expand its market potential (and to mitigate any potential model overlap), GM sought distinct marketing objectives for each model line. The Lumina APV was to compete with the higher-volume Voyager/Caravan directly, serving as a "volume leader"{{Citation|last=MotorWeek|title=1990 GM APV's {{!}} Retro Review|date=2018-06-14|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zg4St9cJuHg|access-date=2019-06-28}}, the Trans Sport was to be the minivan equivalent of sporty Pontiac sedans, and the luxury-trim Silhouette was intended as a more contemporary competitor to the [[Chrysler Town & Country]] and Ford Aerostar Eddie Bauer. == Model overview == At the time of its 1990 release, the Lumina APV was marketed as a bodystyle of the [[Chevrolet Lumina]] model line. For the 1989 model year, Chevrolet introduced the Lumina, effectively consolidating the Celebrity and Monte Carlo into a single model line, with the Lumina APV replacing the Celebrity station wagon. At its 1990 introduction, the Lumina APV was offered in two trim levels; a base trim and an up-level CL trim.{{Cite web|url=https://consumerguide.com/used/1990-96-chevrolet-lumina-apvminivan/|title=1990-96 Chevrolet Lumina APV/Minivan|date=2014-06-19|website=Consumer Guide Auto|language=en-US|access-date=2019-06-28}} Base-trim versions featured chrome exterior trim while CL versions were produced with red exterior trim and badging (similar to the Lumina Euro). For 1993, the CL trim was renamed LS; the Lumina APV badging was removed from the doors. For 1994, the model underwent a mid-cycle revision and was renamed the Chevrolet Lumina Minivan (in place of the APV suffix). === Chassis specification === The Chevrolet Lumina APV is a GM [[GM U platform|U-body vehicle]], using the GMT199 platform designation. In contrast to the unibody design used by the Astro/Safari and the Van/Vandura, the Lumina APV chassis uses a chassis design similar to the [[Pontiac Fiero]] and [[Saturn S series|Saturn SL]], with a galvanized steel spaceframe supporting exterior body panels. The Lumina APV has a 109.8 inch wheelbase, sized between the Lumina sedan/coupe and the Astro/Safari. In line with the Chrysler minivans, the Lumina APV was fitted with independent front suspension with MacPherson struts.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ultimatespecs.com/car-specs/Chevrolet/4771/Chevrolet-Lumina-APV-31i.html|title=Chevrolet Lumina APV 3.1i Specs (1990 - 1992) - Technical Specifications for Years 1990, 1991, 1992}}{{Citation|last=David Ruelas|title=1990 Chevrolet Lumina APV Salesman Training|date=2017-10-26|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qS5fRgKd1T4|access-date=2019-06-28}} The rear beam axle was fitted with coil springs (the only other minivan besides the Ford Aerostar and Renault Espace at the time). As an option, Chevrolet offered the Lumina APV with load-leveling rear air springs, utilizing the air compressor that inflated the rear air springs for auxiliary use with an air hose kit. The front brakes were vented discs, with drum brakes at the rear; anti-lock braking (ABS) was introduced for 1992. During 1994, traction control was introduced as an option (with the 3.8L V6). ==== Powertrain ==== Upon its 1990 release, the Lumina APV was powered by a 3.1L V6, producing 120 hp; a 3-speed automatic was the sole transmission offering. For 1992, a {{convert|170|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} 3.8L V6 became an option, introduced with a 4-speed automatic. For 1996, both engines were replaced by a 180 hp 3.4L V6; the 3-speed automatic was discontinued. [[File:1990-93 Chevrolet Lumina APV.jpg|thumb|1990-1992 Lumina APV]] [[File:Chevrolet-Lumina-APV.jpg|thumb|1993 Lumina APV]] [[File:94-96 Chevrolet Lumina APV.jpg|alt=|thumb|Lumina Minivan (post-facelift)]] [[File:ChevroletLuminaAPV.jpg|thumb|Lumina Minivan LS]] === Body design === ==== Exterior ==== Distinguished by its large windshield and sloped hoodline, the Lumina APV was of a "one-box" design, a configuration similar to the [[Ford Aerostar]] and [[Renault Espace]]. In line with the Aerostar and Chrysler minivans, the Lumina APV was configured with a single sliding door and a rear liftgate. Closely matching the 1987-1990 Chrysler "Grand" minivans in length, width, and height, the Lumina APV is nearly {{convert|10|in|mm|abbr=out}} lower than the Astro and {{convert|3|in|mm|sigfig=1|abbr=out}} narrower. For 1993, the Lumina APV (and its counterparts) introduced a power-operated sliding door, the first American-market minivan to offer the design. Coinciding with the use of a galvanized steel spaceframe (in place of a conventional unit-body design), the Lumina APV was fitted with [[Sheet moulding compound|composite plastic (SMC)]] body panels. Developed for the [[Pontiac Fiero]]{{Citation|last=MotorWeek|title=1990 GM APV's {{!}} Retro Review|date=2018-06-14|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zg4St9cJuHg|access-date=2019-06-28}} and later expanded in use for the [[Saturn S series|Saturn SL]], the manufacturing technique largely eliminated the threat of corrosion and damage from minor dents and dings. The manufacturing also allowed GM to style the Lumina APV separately from its Pontiac and Oldsmobile counterparts at low cost; each model line is externally distinguished by its hood and front fascia. Along from its front fascia, the Lumina APV is distinguished from its Pontiac and Oldsmobile counterparts in the styling of its roof. From the B-pillar to the windshield, the roof was painted black; on examples with tinted glass, the design was to retain the style of the glass roof of the 1986 Trans Sport concept.{{cite news|url=http://jalopnik.com/was-this-gm-minivan-the-greatest-letdown-in-automotive-1665847028|title=Was This GM Minivan The Greatest Letdown In Automotive History?|last=Orlove|first=Raphael|date=2 December 2014|work=Jalopnik|accessdate=23 September 2015}} The Trans Sport had its entire roof painted black (with the exception of a band joining the B-pillars) while the Silhouette had body-color A-pillars and black B-pillars. Two-tone versions of the Lumina APV were available; an early configuration featured a blacked-out upper body. For 1992, Chevrolet standardized the folding sideview mirrors of the CL trim. For the 1994 model year, the Lumina APV underwent an exterior revision, shortening the front overhang by nearly three inches. Largely intended to visually shorten the angle of the hoodline, the Lumina Minivan (dropping the APV suffix) was given a new hood, larger grille, and much larger headlights (shared with the [[Pontiac Bonneville#Ninth generation (1992–1999)|Pontiac Bonneville SSEi]]). 15-inch wheels became standard, with the LS offering a (restyled) version of the 16-inch wheels of the Beretta Z26. The roof was restyled slightly, adopting painted A-pillars and a full-length body-color roof. For 1995, a [[Automotive lighting#Centre high mount stop lamp (CHMSL)|center high-mount stop lamp (CHMSL)]] was added to the liftgate. As GM fitted the taillamps in the D-pillars, the CHMSL was the lowest-mounted of the three brake lamps. ==== Interior ==== Distinguished from its counterparts by trim, the interior design of the Lumina APV was centered around its modular rear seating system. Four configurations were offered: a two-seat cargo van, a five-seat passenger layout (2+3), six seats (2+2+2), and seven seats (2+3+2). In contrast to removable rear bench seats (a design derived from full-size vans), the 34-pound rear seats of the Lumina APV were individually removable and each seatback folded flat. To supplement the cupholders of the interior, each seatback was fitted with two built-in cupholders. As part of the 1994 revision, 7-passenger versions were offered with the option of integrated child seats. For 1996, the five and six-passenger configurations were deleted. While sharing most of its dashboard design with the Trans Sport/Silhouette, the Lumina APV featured its own instrument panel design (derived from the [[Chevrolet Corsica|Corsica]]). As a consequence of its sloped windshield design, the depth of the dashboard of the Lumina APV (and its counterparts) was among the highest ever seen in a mass-produced automobile. For 1991, the dashboard padding was revised was revised to address complaints about glare. For 1992, the external radio antenna was replaced by an integrated design mounted between the headliner and the roof. The 1994 revision brought an update to the instrument panel, lower dashboard (and center console controls), and introduced a driver-side airbag (replacing the steering wheel of the Lumina Z34 with one from the Camaro).{{Clear}} == Variants == === Cargo van === From 1990 to 1996, Chevrolet produced the Lumina APV as a [[Cargo Van|cargo van]], known simply as APV (no Lumina badging was used on the exterior). Slotted below the Astro/Safari, the cargo van competed against the Grand Caravan C/V. While sharing an identical body with its passenger-van counterpart, Chevrolet deleted the rear interior of the cargo van to include a rubber-mat floor; the rear glass windows were replaced by body-color plastic panels bonded in place. Of the three GMT199/APV vans, only Chevrolet offered a cargo van configuration. === Chinese clone === Chevrolet marketed the Lumina APV in China from 1993 to 1996, selling a number of examples in the country.{{Cite web|url=http://chinacarhistory.com/2017/12/27/the-nusheng-jb6500-is-a-chevrolet-lumina-apv-copy-with-a-chrysler-engine/|title=The Nushen JB6500 Is A Chinese Chevrolet Lumina APV Copy With A Chrysler Engine|last=Feijter|first=Author Tycho de|date=2017-12-27|website=ChinaCarHistory|language=en-US|access-date=2019-06-29}} In 1996, Jiangsu Nushen Automobile (Nushen) debuted the Nushen JB6500. While nearly identical in dimensions and exterior design, the JB6500 is a rear-wheel drive vehicle, powered by an 87 hp Chrysler-designed 2.2 L inline-four, paired to a 5-speed manual transmission. In 2001, Nushen ended production of the JB6500. ==See also== *[[Oldsmobile Silhouette]] *[[Pontiac Trans Sport]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{commons category}} {{Chevrolet Truck}} {{Chevrolet vehicles}} [[Category:Chevrolet vehicles|Lumina APV]] [[Category:Minivans]] [[Category:Front-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:1990s cars]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1990]]

1991–96: {{convert|67.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height = 1988–1990: {{convert|55.3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1991–96: {{convert|53.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |engine = {{ubl | 2.0 L ''[[General Motors 122 engine#LL8|LL8]]'' [[OHV]] [[Inline-four engine|I4]] | 2.2 L ''[[General Motors 122 engine#LM3|LM3]]/[[General Motors 122 engine#LN2|LN2]]'' OHV I4 | 2.3 L ''[[Quad 4 engine#LG0|LG0]]'' [[DOHC]] [[Multi-valve|16V]] I4 | 2.8 L ''[[General Motors 60° V6 engine#LB6|LB6]]'' OHV [[V6 engine|V6]] | 3.1 L ''[[General Motors 60° V6 engine#LH0 2|LH0]]'' OHV V6 | 3.1 L ''[[General Motors 60° V6 engine#L82|L82]]'' OHV V6 }} |designer=Jerry Palmer{{cite web|last=Patton|first=Phil|title=The Shape of Ford's Success |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/24/magazine/the-shape-of-ford-s-success.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=21 September 2016}} }} The '''Chevrolet Beretta''' is a [[front-wheel-drive]] two-door [[coupé]] produced by [[Chevrolet]] from 1987 to 1996. The Beretta was designed in the same design studio as the [[Chevrolet Camaro|Camaro]] and the [[Chevrolet Corvette|Corvette]], Chevrolet Exterior Studio 3, and was built at the [[Wilmington Assembly|Wilmington, Delaware]], and [[Linden Assembly|Linden, New Jersey]] assembly plants with other [[GM L platform]] models, the [[Chevrolet Corsica]] which came shortly before the Beretta, and the [[Canada]]-only [[Pontiac Tempest]] four-door [[Sedan (car)|sedan]]s. The Beretta was produced in base, CL, GT, GTU, Indy, GTZ and Z26 models. A [[Convertible (car)|convertible]] was the [[pace car]] for the 1990 [[Indianapolis 500]], and GM initially announced a production convertible replica, but a coupe version was offered instead. ==Models and changes== Base model Berettas were equipped with the same powertrain as the Chevrolet Cavalier, the 2.2 L OHV four-cylinder engine and the three-speed automatic transmission by default, or the 60-degree V6. A five-speed manual was available only by special order if paired with the 2.2 L OHV, however very few special orders ever took place, and the three-speed automatic was the default option. [[File:'89 Beretta GT.jpg|thumb|left|1989 Chevrolet Beretta GT]] The GT included a 125 hp 2.8-liter V6,{{cite web|title=Beretta Debuts|url=http://www.beretta.net/model_info/1988.htm|accessdate=2013-04-18}} which grew to a 3.1 L in 1990, and the Z51 suspension package with 15-inch styled steel wheels and Goodyear Eagle GT tires. Also included was a sport cloth interior and sport steering wheel. The GTU was available from 1988 until the 1990 model year. Beretta GTUs (with the FE7 suspension package) were shipped to Cars and Concepts where they were equipped with 16x7-inch aluminum alloy wheels, custom body kits, a rear spoiler, mirrors, custom trim, and decals. With the FE7 Chevrolet claimed the Beretta GTU would deliver 0.92 g on the skid pad, a claim that most magazines of the day failed to duplicate.{{cite web |title=Lost Cars of the 1980s – Chevrolet Beretta GTU |url=https://www.hemmings.com/blog/2013/11/25/lost-cars-of-the-1980s-chevrolet-beretta-gtu/ |website=www.hemmings.com |publisher=Hemmings |accessdate=25 February 2020}} GTUs were only available in black, red and white. The GTZ, which replaced the GTU, took over as the high-performance version of the Beretta. It was produced from 1990 to 1993. It came standard with Oldsmobile's 2.3-L high output [[GM Quad-4 engine|Quad 4]] [[Inline-four engine|inline-four]], which produced 180 hp (134 kW) and 160 lb·ft (217 N·m) of torque. Also standard was a [[Getrag]] five-speed [[manual transmission]] and GM's FE7 performance suspension. ''Motor Trend'''s only complaint was the Quad 4's NVH (noise, vibration and harshness) and noted it was one of the most raucous engines of its time. Beginning in 1991, the 3.1 L V6 could be had as an option on the GTZ, but it was only available with a three-speed automatic transmission that increased the 0-to-60 mph time to around 9.0 seconds. The 3.1 L V6 was standard on 1990–1992 GT models and optional for all base models and GTs in 1992. Starting in the 1994 model year the 3.1 L [[V6]] could only be ordered with an [[automatic transmission]]. The 1991 model year saw major interior updates, including a new dashboard and center console and the addition of a driver's side airbag. In 1994, the GT and GTZ were replaced by the Beretta Z26, which put it squarely between the [[Chevrolet Cavalier|Cavalier]] Z24 and Lumina Z34 in Chevrolet's lineup. The 3.1 L V6 was redesigned and became the 3100 V6 and gained 20 hp at 160. The new 3100 V6 was only available with a new four-speed automatic transmission. The Quad 4 HO lost a total of 10 hp (7 kW) in 1994, its last year of production. The 2.3 L Quad 4 was only available with a five-speed manual transmission. In 1995 the 3100 V6 lost 5 hp, down to {{convert|155|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}, which also carried on to the 1996 model. Beretta sales steadily declined every year of production as the market turned away from two-door models. In 1996, Chevrolet ended production of both the Beretta and Corsica after 10 model years. The Corsica was replaced by the [[Chevrolet Malibu]] in 1997. The last Beretta rolled off the assembly line on July 30, 1996. ==Models== * 1987–1996 base/CL * 1988–1993 GT * 1988–1989 GTU * 1990 Indy * 1990–1993 GTZ had a 0–60 mph time of 7.6 seconds * 1994–1996 Z26 had a 0–60 mph time of 8.3 seconds ==Gallery== {{gallery |lines=3 |File:1988 Chevrolet Beretta GT in blue, rear right.jpg|1988 Beretta GT, rear view |File:1990 Chevy Beretta Indy Pace Car Replica.jpg|1990 [[Indianapolis 500 pace cars|Indianapolis 500 pace car]] replica |File:89 Beretta GT.jpg|1989 GT |}} {{-}} ==Trademark issue== General Motors was sued by [[Beretta|Fabbrica d'Armi Pietro Beretta]] for trademark infringement involving their use of the Beretta name for a car.{{cite news|last1=Mateja|first1=Jim|title=What`s In A Name? A Lot, Beretta Tells Gm|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1988-07-25/business/8801170633_1_chevrolet-beretta-beretta-gun-gm-executive-vice-president|accessdate=23 August 2015|work=Chicago Tribune|date=25 July 1988}}{{cite news |author= |title=G.M. and Beretta Settle Lawsuit |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/26/business/company-news-gm-and-beretta-settle-lawsuit.html |newspaper=New York Times |date=26 May 1989 |access-date=20 August 2015 |quote=According to the provisions of the settlement, which were first described by Beretta in February, the auto maker received the right to market the Chevrolet under the Beretta name, which it has been using since the model's introduction late in 1986.}} The suit was settled out of court in 1989; GM and Beretta exchanged symbolic gifts: a Beretta GTU coupe and a pair of Beretta shotguns. General Motors donated [[USD|US$]]500,000 to a Beretta-sponsored charity{{cite news |author= |title=Beretta Allows GM to Use Name |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-05-25/business/fi-1075_1_beretta-foundation-gm-chevrolet-beretta-gtu-coupe |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=25 May 1989 |access-date=20 August 2015 |quote=Pier Giuseppe Beretta, chairman of the weapons maker Fabbrica D'Armi Pietro Beretta S.p.A., and General Motors Chairman Roger Smith signed an agreement allowing GM to use the Beretta name for the Chevrolet Beretta car.}}{{cite web|title=General Motors donates $500,000 to the Beretta Foundation |url=http://www.fondazioneberetta.com/index.aspx?m=53&did=266 |website=Beretta Foundation |publisher=Fabbrica d’Armi Pietro Beretta S.p.A |date=25 May 1989 |accessdate=16 May 2016}} which was also affiliated with the [[GM Cancer Research Foundation]]. ==Motorsport== The Beretta, using a splayed valve 4.5 liter 90 degree V6 engine, won the [[Trans Am Series]] championship in 1990. == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Chevrolet Beretta}} *[http://www.beretta.net Beretta Net] *[http://www.berettaspeed.com Beretta Speed] *[https://iberetta.eu Chevrolet Beretta Club Europe] {{Chevrolet}} {{Chevrolet vehicles}} [[Category:Chevrolet vehicles|Beretta]] [[Category:Mid-size cars]] [[Category:Front-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Coupés]] [[Category:1980s cars]] [[Category:1990s cars]] [[Category:Sports cars]] [[Category:Front-wheel-drive sports cars]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1987]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]]
