revision.text:
{{see also|Opel Omega}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox automobile | name = Chevrolet Omega | image = PR comboio.jpg | caption = Chevrolet Omega B (VX)
in a Brazilian presidential convoy | manufacturer = [[Chevrolet]] ([[General Motors]]) (1992–1998)
[[Holden]] ([[General Motors]]) (1998–2008, 2010–2011) | production = 1992–2008
2010–2011 | predecessor = [[Chevrolet Opala]] | class = [[Executive car]] }} The '''Chevrolet Omega''' is an [[executive car]] sold by [[Chevrolet]] for the [[Brazil]]ian market. Replacing the [[Chevrolet Opala]], which was a development of the [[Opel Rekord]] C, the original Chevrolet Omega was based on the [[Opel Omega]] A, and built locally between 1992 and 1998. After 1999, local production ceased, and [[General Motors do Brasil]] imported [[Badge engineering|badge engineered]] versions of the [[Holden Commodore]] from Australia. __TOC__ {{clear}} == Omega A == {{Infobox automobile | image = Opel Omega A front 20090430.jpg | caption = Opel Omega A on which the Chevrolet Omega A is based | name = Omega A | aka = [[Opel Omega]]
[[Vauxhall Carlton]] | production = 1992–1998 | body style = 4-door [[sedan (car)|sedan]]
5-door [[station wagon]] | platform = [[FR layout|FR]] [[GM V platform (RWD)|GM V platform]] | transmission = 5-speed manual
4-speed automatic | wheelbase = {{convert|2730|mm|1|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|4687|mm|1|abbr=on}},
{{convert|4730|mm|1|abbr=on}} (Suprema) | width = {{convert|1772|mm|1|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|1445|mm|1|abbr=on}},
{{convert|1480|mm|1|abbr=on}} (Suprema) | weight = {{convert|1150|kg|0|abbr=on}} }} Based on the [[Opel Omega]] A, the Chevrolet Omega A debuted in [[Brazil]] in 1992 with a choice of two engines—a 2.0-liter four-cylinder (GLS and GL trim) and 3.0-liter six-cylinder (CD trim). From 1995, following the discontinuation of Omega A in Germany, the engines were upgraded to a 2.2-liter four (GLS) and a {{convert|4.1|L|cid|-1|abbr=on}} [[Chevrolet straight-6 engine#250|Chevrolet straight-six engine]] (CD) as used in the previous GM Opala albeit tuned by [[Lotus cars|Lotus]] and with electronic multiport fuel injection added.[http://blog.hemmings.com/index.php/2010/02/25/chevrolet-omega-the-last-250/ Chevrolet Omega, the last 250 at Hemmings Blog: Classic and collectible cars and parts][http://carinfo.autold.com/car-chevrolet_omega-22-gls.html Chevrolet Omega 2.2 GLS specifications][http://carinfo.autold.com/car-chevrolet_omega-41-cd.html Chevrolet Omega 4.1 CD specifications] Both [[sedan (car)|sedan]] and [[station wagon]] (called Omega Suprema) [[Car body style|body styles]] were available. The station wagon shared the exact powertrain configuration and trim options with the sedan versions. Some funeral parlor owners chose the Omega Suprema as the preferred car for hearse-based modifications. In addition to the bigger engines, suited to local petrol quality, [[General Motors do Brasil]] had also deemed it necessary to beef up the suspension of the Omega to deal with Brazilian road conditions.{{citation | url = http://gerpisa.org/ancien-gerpisa/actes/25/25-3.pdf | title = Globalisation and assembler-supplier relations: Brazil and India | journal = Actes du GERPISA | location = São Paulo, Sussex | last1 = Humphrey | first1 = John | first2 = Mario | last2 = Salerno | page = 52}} The CD version was offered the availability of the ''[[GM 4L30-E transmission|4L30-E]]'' automatic transmission as an option. {| class="wikitable" |+ Powertrain: ! Engine || Cyl. || Power || Torque || Notes[http://carspector.com/marque/chevrolet/Omega/ Chevrolet Omega series – technical specifications of Chevrolet Omega cars] |- | [[C20NE]] 2.0 || [[Inline-four engine|I4]] || {{convert|116|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} || {{convert|170|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}} || MY 1992–1995 |- | 2.2 || [[Inline-four engine|I4]] || {{convert|116|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} || {{convert|197|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}} || MY 1995–1998 |- | 3.0 || [[Straight-six engine|I6]] || {{convert|165|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} || {{convert|230|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}} ||MY 1992–1995 |- | [[Chevrolet straight-6 engine#250|4.1 (250)]] || [[Straight-six engine|I6]] || {{convert|168|PS|kW hp|0|abbr=on}} || {{convert|285|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}} || MY 1995–1998 |} {{clear}} == Omega B == {{Infobox automobile | name = Omega B | image = PR comboio.jpg | caption = | aka = [[Holden Commodore|Holden Calais]] ([[Holden VT Commodore|VT]], [[Holden VX Commodore|VX]], [[Holden Commodore (VY)|VY]]
[[Holden Commodore (VZ)|Holden Berlina (VZ)]]
[[Holden Commodore#Chevrolet Lumina|Chevrolet Lumina]] | production = 1998–2006 | assembly = [[Elizabeth, South Australia]] | body style = 4-door [[sedan (car)|sedan]] | platform = [[FR layout|FR]] [[GM V platform (RWD)|GM V platform]] | engine = 3.8 L ''[[Buick V6 engine|Ecotec]]'' [[V6 engine|V6]] (1998–2005)
3.6 L ''[[GM High Feature engine|Alloytec]]'' [[V6 engine|V6]] (2005–2006) | transmission = 4-speed ''[[GM 4L60-E transmission|GM 4L60-E]]'' [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] }} {{multiple image | align = left | direction = vertical | width = 220 | image1 = 2000-2001 Holden VX Calais sedan 01.jpg | image2 = 2002 Holden Calais (VY) sedan (2010-11-04).jpg | image3 = 2004 Holden Berlina (VZ) sedan (2016-01-04) 01.jpg | caption3 = VX, VY and VZ Holdens on which the equivalent Omega B are based | image4 = Did it rain last night? (3977887500).jpg | caption4 = The Chevrolet Lumina has the most close styling to the Chevrolet Omega }} {{multiple image | align = left | direction = vertical | width = 220 | image1 = 2000-2001 Holden VX Calais sedan 04.jpg | image2 = Chevrolet Lumina LS.JPG | caption2 = VX rear end styling: top as used on Australian luxury models and bottom as used on export Chevrolets ([[Holden Commodore#Chevrolet Lumina|Lumina]] shown) }} In October 1998, with the Chevrolet Omega B, [[General Motors do Brasil]] ceased local production in favour of a [[rebadging|rebadged]] version of the [[Holden Commodore (VT)|Holden Calais (VT)]] sedan imported from Australia{{cite press release | last = Davi | first = Susete | url = https://archives.media.gm.com/division/brazil/news/press/1999/mar/pr18031999.html | title = Omega: líder absoluto de vendas |trans-title=Omega: absolute leader in sales | language = pt | location = [[São Caetano do Sul]] | publisher = [[General Motors do Brasil]] | date = 18 March 1999 | accessdate = 19 December 2014}}{{cite press release | url = https://archives.media.gm.com/division/brazil/news/press/2003/abr/pr28042003.htm | title = Chevrolet Omega CD | language = pt | location = [[São Caetano do Sul]] | publisher = [[General Motors do Brasil]] | date = 28 April 2003 | accessdate = 19 December 2014}}{{cite web | url = http://www1.an.com.br/1998/out/26/0vei.htm | title = Novo Omega chega importado da Austrália | trans-title = New Omega comes imported from Australia | language = pt | work = AN Veículos | date = 26 October 1998 | accessdate = 19 December 2014 | url-status = dead | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141219152003/http://www1.an.com.br/1998/out/26/0vei.htm | archivedate = 19 December 2014 | df = dmy-all }} (as would be the case for Middle East bound models, instead badged [[Holden Commodore#Chevrolet Lumina|Chevrolet Lumina]]). The Brazilian model sold in a single "CD" specification, based on the Holden Calais powered by the ''Ecotec'' 3.8-liter V6 engine developing {{convert|200|PS|kW|abbr=on}}.{{cite web | last = Meneghim | first = Luís | url = http://www1.an.com.br/1998/dez/06/0vei.htm | title = Omega | language = pt | work = AN Veículos | date = 6 December 1998 | accessdate = 19 December 2014 | url-status = dead | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160118231003/http://www1.an.com.br/1998/dez/06/0vei.htm | archivedate = 18 January 2016 | df = dmy-all }} The VT II model came to Brazil in December 1999.{{cite press release | last = Davi | first = Susete | url = https://archives.media.gm.com/division/brazil/news/press/1999/dez/pr01121999.html | title = Chegou o Chevrolet Omega 2000 |trans-title=The 2000 Chevrolet Omega has arrived | language = pt | location = [[São Caetano do Sul]] | publisher = [[General Motors do Brasil]] | date = 1 December 1999 | accessdate = 19 December 2014}} On 18 May 2001, GM announced that the Omega CD would now be based on the [[Holden Commodore (VX)#Calais|VX Calais]], designed and manufactured in Australia.{{cite press release | last = Davi | first = Susete | url = https://archives.media.gm.com/division/brazil/news/press/2001/mai/pr18052001.html | title = Novo Chevrolet Omega 2001: reestilização e mais tecnologia |trans-title=New Chevrolet Omega 2001: restyling and more technology | language = pt | location = [[São Caetano do Sul]] | publisher = [[General Motors do Brasil]] | date = 18 May 2001 | accessdate = 19 December 2014}}{{cite web | last = Guerrero | first = Luiz | url = http://quatrorodas.abril.com.br/carros/impressoes/conteudo_142901.shtml | title = Chevrolet Omega | language = pt | work = [[Quatro Rodas]] | date = July 2001 | accessdate = 19 December 2014 | url-status = dead | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141224043417/http://quatrorodas.abril.com.br/carros/impressoes/conteudo_142901.shtml | archivedate = 24 December 2014 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite press release | last = Davi | first = Susete | url = https://archives.media.gm.com/division/brazil/news/press/2001/out/pr01102001.html | title = Omega 2001: liderança absoluta |trans-title=Omega 2001: absolute leadership | language = pt | location = [[São Caetano do Sul]] | publisher = [[General Motors do Brasil]] | date = 1 October 2001 | accessdate = 19 December 2014}} Although based on the Holden Calais, the Brazilian model instead featured the boot lid from VX series base models (whose tail lamps did not extend into the boot lid). The next update was announced by GM on 28 April 2003, with the Omega CD now based on the [[Holden Commodore (VY)#Calais|VY Calais]], again in a single "CD" specification.{{cite press release | url = https://archives.media.gm.com/archive/documents/domain_21/docId_9241_pr.html | title = Holden Reaches Golden Milestone With 50 Years of Exports | location = Melbourne | publisher = [[Holden]] | date = 9 November 2004 | accessdate = 19 December 2014}} GM announced a final update of Omega B on 9 March 2005, now based on the [[Holden Commodore (VZ)|Holden VZ series]],{{cite press release | url = https://archives.media.gm.com/archive/documents/domain_73/docId_13028_pr.html | title = Chevrolet Omega 2005 muito mais potência e luxo |trans-title=Chevrolet Omega 2005 more power and luxury | language = pt | location = [[São Caetano do Sul]] | publisher = [[General Motors do Brasil]] | date = 9 March 2005 | accessdate = 19 December 2014}} powered by the new 3.6-liter ''[[GM High Feature engine|Alloytec]]'' V6 engine. It was again sold in a single "CD" specification-specification CD model, this time based on the [[Holden Commodore (VZ)#Berlina|VZ Berlina]] with some extra equipment from the VZ Calais.{{cite web | url = http://www.nextcar.com.au/n.holden.2005.exports.06feb.html | title = Flagships star in GM Holden's export record | publisher = Next Car | date = 1 February 2006 | accessdate = 19 December 2014}}{{cite web | url = http://www.nextcar.com.au/n.holden.2006.exports.07feb.html | title = 2006 Best Ever Year For Holden in Middle East | publisher = Next Car | date = 4 February 2007 | accessdate = 19 December 2014}} Sales ended in 2007 with the arrival of the new Omega C. {{clear}} == Omega C == {{Infobox automobile | name = Omega C | image = 2009 Holden Berlina (VE MY09.5) sedan (2015-05-29) 01.jpg | caption = Holden Berlina (VE) on which the Chevrolet Omega C is based | aka = [[Holden Commodore (VE)|Holden Berlina (VE)]]
[[Holden Commodore#Chevrolet Lumina|Chevrolet Lumina]]
[[Pontiac G8]] | production = 2007–2008
2010–2011 | assembly = [[Elizabeth, South Australia]] | body style = 4-door [[sedan (car)|sedan]] | platform = [[FR layout|FR]] [[GM Zeta platform]] | engine = 3.6 L ''[[GM High Feature engine|Alloytec]]'' [[V6 engine|V6]] | transmission = 4-speed ''[[GM 4L60-E transmission|GM 4L60-E]]'' [[automatic transmission|automatic]] }} For the third generation Chevrolet Omega C, General Motors again looked to [[Holden]]. The new model was announced on 4 July 2007,{{cite press release | url = https://archives.media.gm.com/archive/documents/domain_73/docId_37592_pr.html | title = GM do Brasil lança nova geraçăo do sofisticado automóvel Chevrolet Omega |trans-title=GM do Brasil launches new generation of the sophisticated Chevrolet Omega automobile | language = pt | location = [[São Caetano do Sul]] | publisher = [[General Motors do Brasil]] | date = 4 July 2007 | accessdate = 19 December 2014}} was now based on a rebadged [[Holden Commodore (VE)|Holden Berlina (VE)]]. It was again powered by the 3.6-liter ''Alloytec'' V6 engine.{{cite web | last = Pettendy | first = Marton | date = 5 July 2007 | url = http://www.goauto.com.au/mellor/mellor.nsf/story2/E9AB3A07C912C8B5CA25730F002176DB | title = Commodore goes to Rio | publisher = John Mellor Pty Ltd | accessdate = 6 July 2007}} Due to the global financial crisis, imports ceased in 2008.{{cite web | last = Mathioudakis | first = Bryon | date = 31 August 2010 | url = http://www.goauto.com.au/mellor/mellor.nsf/story2/20AE7EEB8B7D801CCA25778F0081487A | title = Commodore returns to Brazil | publisher = John Mellor Pty Ltd | accessdate = 6 September 2010 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100903151613/http://goauto.com.au/mellor/mellor.nsf/story2/20AE7EEB8B7D801CCA25778F0081487A# | archive-date = 3 September 2010 | url-status = dead | df = dmy-all }} === Facelift === The Omega was re-released in September 2010. The first 600 models were sold as the "Omega [[Emerson Fittipaldi|Fittipaldi]] Edition", named after the homonymous 1970s Brazilian [[Formula One]] [[List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions|World Champion]]. The new Omega's specifications now reflected those of the Australian [[Holden Commodore (VE)|Holden Calais (VE Series II)]], except for specially tuned suspension settings for Brazil's road conditions.{{cite web | url = http://www.themotorreport.com.au/50768/holden-commodore-series-ii-exports-to-brazil-announced | work = The Motor Report | title = Holden Commodore Series II Exports To Brazil Announced | first = Tony | last = O'Kane | date = 1 October 2010 | accessdate = 24 April 2013}} Imports ceased after 2011 with no further Holden-based products being sold in Brazil since.{{cite web | url = http://www.carsales.com.au/news/2011/medium-passenger/holden/commodore/holden-loses-another-commodore-export-deal-27621 | title = Holden loses another Commodore export deal | publisher = carsales.com.au | date = 14 November 2007 | accessdate = 28 March 2012 | url-status = dead | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131202225854/http://www.carsales.com.au/news/2011/medium-passenger/holden/commodore/holden-loses-another-commodore-export-deal-27621 | archivedate = 2 December 2013 | df = dmy-all }} {{clear}} == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Chevrolet vehicles}} [[Category:Chevrolet vehicles|Omega]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:1990s cars]] [[Category:2000s cars]] [[Category:2010s cars]]

{{Infobox automobile |image = File:1956 Chevrolet Belair Nomad.jpg |caption = 1956 Chevrolet Bel Air Nomad |name = Chevrolet Nomad |manufacturer = [[Chevrolet]] ([[General Motors]]) |production = 1955–1961
1968–1972 |engine = |layout = [[FR layout]] }} The '''Chevrolet Nomad''' is a [[station wagon]] model produced by [[Chevrolet]] that was marketed from 1955 to 1961, from 1967 to 1972, and then used as a [[trim package]] on the 1976 [[Chevrolet Vega|Vega]] as well as for [[Chevrolet van]]s during the late 1970s and early 1980s. In [[South Africa]], the Nomad name was used on a small utility vehicle. The Nomad is best remembered in its two-door [[Tri-Five]] form that was considered a [[halo model]] during its three-year production. It was named for ''[[nomad]]s''. ==Pre production== The two-door Nomad differed from other station wagons of the era by having unique styling more reminiscent of a hardtop sedan than that of a standard station wagon. Chevrolet shared this body with [[Pontiac]], which marketed its version as the [[Pontiac Safari]]. The Nomad's unique design had its roots in a [[Motorama|General Motors Motorama]] show car of the same name that was shared with the [[Chevrolet Corvette (C1)|Corvette]], [[Pontiac Bonneville Special]], and the [[Oldsmobile F-88]]. The Concept was introduced at the GM Motorama in 1954 as one of Head Stylist [[Harley Earl]]'s "dream cars". It followed the introduction in 1950 of the [[Ford Country Squire#First generation (1950–1951)|Ford Country Squire]] two-door station wagon. GM approved production of the vehicle if the design could be transferred to its standard model because top GM brass felt that they could sell more models if it were attached to the popular [[Chevrolet Bel Air|Bel Air]] model. Following the product debut in 1955, it was not uncommon for the car to be referred to as the Chevy "Bel Air Nomad". ==First generation: 1955–1957== {{Infobox automobile |name=First generation |production=1955–1957 |image=1955-chevy-nomad-chevrolet-archives.jpg |engine={{convert|265|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[V8 engine|V8]]
{{convert|283|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[V8 engine|V8]] |wheelbase = {{convert|115|in|mm|1|abbr=on}}https://auto.howstuffworks.com/1955-1957-chevrolet-nomad2.htm |platform = [[GM A platform (1936)|A-body]] |length = {{convert|201|in|mm|1|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url= http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Chevrolet/1957_Chevrolet/1957_Chevrolet_Owners_Manual/1957%20Chevrolet%20Manual-30.html |title=1957 Chevrolet Owners Manual |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}} |body_style = 2-door [[station wagon]] (1955–1957) }} *'''1955''' Chevrolets received all-new styling. Advertised as "The Hot One," the boxy new Chevy was crisp, clean, and thoroughly modern-looking, and its popularity was shared with the [[Tri-Five]] Chevrolets of this generation. Nomads, like Bel Airs, came loaded with interior carpet, chrome spears on front fenders, chrome window moldings, and full wheel covers. For 1955, Chevrolets gained a [[V8 engine]] option. The new [[Chevrolet small-block engine#265|{{convert|265|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} V8]] featured a modern, [[overhead valve]], high compression, short [[stroke (engine)|stroke]] design that was so good that it remained in production in various forms for many decades. The base V8 had a two-barrel [[carburetor]] and was rated at {{convert|162|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}, and the "Power Pack" option featured a four-barrel carburetor and other upgrades yielding {{convert|180|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. Later in the year, a "Super Power Pack" option added high-compression and a further {{convert|15|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. It had room for six passengers.{{cite web|url= http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Chevrolet/1957_Chevrolet/1957_Chevrolet_Brochure_1/1957%20Chevrolet%20Brochure-07.html |title=1957 Chevrolet brochure 1 |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}} *'''1956''' Chevrolets received a face-lift. This gave Chevys a more conventional full-width grille, pleasing those customers who did not like the 1955 front end. Nomads now carried the same interior and rear-wheel sheet metal as other Bel Airs, lacking the original's unique trim. A padded dashboard was now available. For 1956 Chevy hid the gas cap behind a flip-down tail light on the left side. *'''1957''' V-8 engine displacement grew to [[Chevrolet small-block engine#283|{{convert|283|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}}]] from 265 in 1957, with the "Super Turbo Fire V8" option producing {{convert|283|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} with a [[fuel injection]] system. The vast majority of cars were had engines with carburetors. While considered to be a milestone vehicle design, General Motors discontinued the original Nomad Sport Wagon at the end of the 1957 model year due to low sales and the introduction of a new body for 1958. {{clear}} ==Second generation: 1958–1961== {{Infobox automobile |name=Second generation |production=1958–1961 |image=1960 Chevrolet Nomad.jpg |engine={{convert|265|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[V8 engine|V8]]
{{convert|283|cuin|L|1|abbr=on}} [[V8 engine|V8]] |body_style=4-door [[station wagon]] |platform=[[GM B platform]] }} *'''1958''' For the 1958 model year, Chevrolet moved the Nomad name to its top-line four-door Bel Air-based station wagon,{{cite web|url= http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet_Wagons/1958%20Chevrolet%20Wagons-02-03.html |title=1958 Chevrolet Wagons brochure |pages=2-3 |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}} right above the new mid-priced Biscayne based Brookwood. This was the only four-door Bel Air-based Nomad station wagon. Like the rest of Chevrolet's 1958 full-size car line up, the Nomad featured Chevrolet's new "Safety-Girder" cruciform frame. Similar in layout to the frame adapted for the 1957 Cadillac, it featured box-section side rails and a boxed front cross member that bowed under the engine, these "x-frames" were used on other 1958 to 1964 Chevys, as well as Cadillac. The rear was tied together by a channel-section cross member.{{cite web|url= http://www.oldcarbrochures.com/static/NA/Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet/1958_Chevrolet_Wagons/1958%20Chevrolet%20Wagons-06-07.html |title=1958 Chevrolet Wagons brochure |pages=6-7 |publisher=Oldcarbrochures.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-20}} *'''1959''' In 1959, the Nomad was transferred from the Bel Air to the expanded [[Chevrolet Impala|Impala]] model range, which had been the top-line Chevrolet two-door hardtop and convertible the previous year; Impala now became a separate model that included four-door cars. Nomad, still at the top was a six-passenger car. The other 1959 Chevrolet station wagons were the new [[Chevrolet Kingswood|Kingswood]] four-door, nine-passenger, the new [[Chevrolet Parkwood|Parkwood]] four-door six-passenger, the new [[Chevrolet Brookwood|Brookwood]] two-door six passengers, and Brookwood four-door six Passenger. With the [[Chevrolet Delray|Delray]] gone, the Biscayne-based Brookwood was now priced lowest. The Brookwood two-door marked the short-lived return of the two-door wagon and was the basis for the new-for-1959 [[Chevrolet El Camino|El Camino]]. The El Camino carried mid-level Parkwood (Bel Air) exterior trim, with Brookwood (Biscayne) interior. *'''1960''' For 1960, the Impala-based Nomad four-door was revised with more conventional styling. The Kingswood and the two-door Brookwood were dropped at the end of the year along with the El Camino. *'''1961''' In 1961, all full-size Chevrolets were restyled on the existing [[GM B platform]]. The new body styling was more trim and boxy than the 1958-60 models. Chevrolet continued to use the Nomad name until the end of the 1961 model year when all Chevrolet station wagons adopted the names of the regular sedan models for 1962. The Nomad had body-on-frame construction, using the "X" frame to the end. {{clear}} ==Third generation: 1968–1972== {{Main|Chevrolet Chevelle}} {{Infobox automobile |name=Third generation |production=1968–1972 |engine= |body_style=4-door [[station wagon]] |platform=[[GM A platform (RWD)]] |image=1969 Chevrolet Chevelle Nomad.jpg }} Between 1968 and 1972 the names Nomad and Nomad Custom were applied to the lowest-priced [[Chevrolet Chevelle|Chevelle]] four-door station wagon model, below the Chevelle Greenbrier, Chevelle Concours, and Chevelle Concours Estate. *'''1968''' For 1968, Chevelle got a new body style (though still under the 817 and 817 internal designations) emphasized the "Coke bottle" look even more. New Federal safety-mandated equipment included side marker lights on each fender, as well as shoulder belts for outboard front seat occupants on cars built after December 1, 1967. This explains why some '68s had shoulder belts, and some early-production cars did not. However, all '68s had anchored for the belts. Manual transmission cars got GM's "Air Injection Reactor (A.I.R)" smog pump, which added complexity under the hood. *'''1969''' By 1969, each Chevrolet station wagon regained its own unique model name. All '69 Chevelles also got a new locking steering column, one year ahead of the Federal requirement. Headrests, required for all cars sold in the U.S. after January 1, 1969, were installed on all '69 GM cars. *'''1970''' The 1970 Chevelle Nomad had even more restyling. Each [[head lamp]] was put in its own chrome housing and was no longer integrating into the grille. The body lines were less swept and a new integrated rear bumper was used. *'''1971''' For 1971, all Chevelles got two big headlights in place of the quads, and GM mandated all divisions design their engines to run on lower-octane regular, low-lead or unleaded gasoline due to tightening emission requirements and in anticipation of the [[catalytic converter]] that would be used on 1975 and later models, necessitating the use of unleaded fuel. To permit usage of the lower-octane fuels, all engines featured low compression ratios (9:1 and lower; well below the 10.25-11.25:1 range on high-performance engines of 1970 and earlier). *'''1972''' The last Nomad station wagon ended with the end of the second-generation Chevelle at the end of the 1972 model year. {{clear}} ==1976 Chevy Vega wagon Nomad package== {{Main|Chevrolet Vega}} In 1976, special Vega Nomad wagons were assembled with unique side window trim and filler panels (to make the 'b' pillars appear forward-slanted), tailgate rub strips, vinyl Nomad script identification. ==Chevy Van Nomad== [[File:Chevy Van Nomad.jpg|thumb|right|Chevy Van Nomad]] In the late 1970s and early 1980s, the name returned again on a trim package for the full-size [[Chevrolet Van]]. It featured five-passenger seating with swiveling captain seats up front, a bench in the middle, and a spacious cargo area in the rear with no quarter windows. It could be had with plaid [[upholstery]] and two-tone paint. It was offered along with Sportvan, CaraVan, Commercial Van, and Cube Van. {{clear}} ==South African Chevrolet Nomad== In South Africa, a small utility vehicle called the '''Chevrolet Nomad''' appeared in 1976. To save development costs and to keep the price low, the ladder-framed vehicle was only available with [[rear-wheel drive]] and a locally built [[Chevrolet 153 4-cylinder engine|2.5-liter cast-iron]] [[inline-four engine]], also of Chevrolet origins. Nonetheless, a combination of ample ground clearance, a short wheelbase, and light-weight, meant that off-road capabilities remained respectable.{{cite journal | ref = SAM1076 | journal = SA Motor | title = Chevrolet Nomad | page = 29 | last = Howard | first = Tony | publisher = Scott Publications | location = Cape Town, South Africa | date = October 1976 }} The wheelbase is {{convert|2083|mm|in|abbr=on}}, and the ground clearance {{convert|265|mm|in|abbr=on}}. It also has a sump guard and a sturdy steel box-section grille to protect the radiator and headlamps.[[#SAM1076|Howard]], p. 31 The Nomad was only available with an open two-door body, with a folding front window and an available soft-top or fiber-glass hardtop. The design was simple, entirely of flat panels designed for ease of construction and to enable local parts content to be maximized - at 82 percent it was the highest achieved yet in South Africa.[[#SAM1076|Howard]], pp. 33-34 The engine, also used in the [[Opel Rekord Series D#ZA|Chevrolet 2500]] as well as a host of other local GM products, was tuned down for improved lower-end torque. Now fitted with a Rochester carburetor it produces {{convert|67|kW|PS hp|0|abbr=on}} at 4000 rpm, enough for a top speed of {{convert|134.8|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}} in a period test. The front suspension proved weak, however, and by the time Chevrolet had redesigned it buyer resistance had already doomed the Nomad. ==Concept cars== [[File:1954ChevyNomadconcept.jpg|thumb|Reproduction of the 1954 Chevrolet Nomad concept]] [[File:1979_Chevrolet_Nomad_II_Concept_Minivan.jpg|thumb|right|1979 Chevrolet Nomad II concept car]] [[File:Chevy nomad concept.JPG|thumbnail|right|The 2004 Chevrolet Nomad concept car, with design cues from the original 1954 Corvette-based Nomad]] There are several Nomad concept cars: 1954 : The first was Harley Earl's Corvette-based concept introduced at the GM Motorama. 1979 : The front-wheel-drive Chevrolet Nomad II minivan concept, based on GM's [[GM X platform (1980)|X-platform]], several years before the [[Chrysler minivans (S)|Dodge Caravan]] and [[Renault Espace]]. It received strong approval from the customer clinics, but General Motors decided to not produce it.{{cite web|url=http://gmphotostore.com/1979-chevrolet-nomad-concept-poster/ |title=1979 Chevrolet Nomad Concept Poster |publisher=GM Photo Store}} 1999 : Another Nomad concept was based on the [[Chevrolet Camaro (first generation)|first generation Camaro]], powered by a V8.{{cite press release|url= http://www.seriouswheels.com/cars/top-1999-Chevrolet-Nomad-Concept.htm |title=1999 Chevrolet Nomad Concept |website=seriouswheels.com |accessdate=12 November 2019}} 2004 : Another concept was based on the [[GM Kappa platform]] and resembled the 1954 Corvette-based Nomad show car.{{cite web |title=Chevy Nomad concept recalls 1954 Nomad |url=http://www.autos.ca/general-news/chevy-nomad-concept-recalls-1954-nomad/ |website=Canadian Driver |date=4 January 2004 |accessdate=12 November 2019}}{{cite web |title=Chevrolet Nomad, 2004 |url=http://www.madle.org/egmnomad.htm |website=madle.org |accessdate=12 November 2019}} It had a 107-inch wheelbase and was 155.5 inches long.{{cite book|last=Newberry|first=Stephan|title=The Car design yearbook 3|year=2005|publisher=Merrell|isbn=1-85894-242-X}} ==See also== *[[Chevrolet 150]] *[[Chevrolet 210]] *[[Ford Del Rio]], direct competition to the Nomad (1957-58) {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== {{Commons category|Chevrolet Nomad}} * {{cite book | author = Gunnell, John, Editor | title = The Standard Catalog of American Cars 1946-1975 | publisher = Krause Publications | year = 1987 | isbn = 0-87341-096-3}} * {{cite book | author = Dammann, George H. | title = 75 Years of Chevrolet | publisher = Motorbooks International(Crestline Series)| year = 1986 | isbn = 0-87938-692-4}} *"[http://www.oldride.com/library/chevrolet_nomad.html Chevrolet Nomad]." Pictures and Information on ''oldride.com.'' {{Early Chevrolet cars}} [[Category:Chevrolet vehicles|Nomad]] [[Category:Chevrolet concept vehicles|Nomad]] [[Category:Full-size vehicles]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Station wagons]] [[Category:1950s cars]] [[Category:1960s cars]] [[Category:Vans]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]]

revision.comment: opening paragraph and main section didnt reflect the recent china-centric revival.
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Vauxhall Cavalier|AMC Cavalier|Packard Cavalier}} {{Infobox automobile | image = 3rd Chevrolet Cavalier.jpg | name = Chevrolet Cavalier | manufacturer = [[General Motors]] (1982-2005)
[[SAIC-GM|Shanghai GM]] (2017-present) | production = May 1981–October 6, 2005
2016–present (China) | model_years = 1982–2005, 2016-present (China Only) | class = [[Compact car|Compact]] | predecessor = [[Chevrolet Monza]] | successor = [[Chevrolet Cobalt]] (United States and Canada)
[[Chevrolet Optra]] (Mexico) | platform = [[GM J platform|J-body]] | layout = [[Front-engine, front-wheel-drive layout|FF layout]] }} The '''Chevrolet Cavalier''' is a line of small cars produced for the model years 1982 through 2005 by [[Chevrolet]], and then later reintroduced in 2016 for the Chinese Market. As a rebadged variant of [[General Motors]]' [[GM J platform|J-cars]], the Cavalier was manufactured alongside the [[Cadillac Cimarron]], [[Buick Skyhawk]], [[Oldsmobile Firenza]], and [[Pontiac Sunbird|Pontiac J2000/2000/Sunbird]] at GM's [[South Gate Assembly]] and [[Janesville Assembly Plant|Janesville Assembly]] plants, achieving its highest sales in 1984. == Predecessors == The Cavalier replaced the [[Chevrolet Monza|Monza]] in North America. The Monza was available as a 2-door [[coupe]], a 3-door [[hatchback]] and a 3-door [[station wagon|wagon]] (using the same body as the discontinued [[Chevrolet Vega|Vega]] wagon, the model it replaced). The inexpensive [[Chevrolet Chevette|Chevette]] was retained even as sales declined, and was formally replaced by even smaller [[captive import]]s. Both previous platforms had rear-drive layouts while the new design followed the front wheel drive trend, as in the [[Dodge Omni]] and [[Honda Civic]]. [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] and [[Chrysler]] also introduced new front drive compacts. The largely successful mission of capturing the bulk of domestic compact sales would fall on the Cavalier's 2-door [[coupe]], 4-door [[sedan (car)|sedan]] and 4-door [[station wagon]], the relatively short-lived 3-door [[hatchback]] (which replaced the Monza [[2+2 (car body style)|2+2]] Sport 2-door hatchback) and, in later years, a 2-door [[convertible (car)|convertible]]. The small Cavalier even helped fill in lagging sales of the [[Compact car|compact]] [[Chevrolet Citation|Citation]]. == First generation (1982–1987) == {{refimprove section|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox automobile | name = First generation | image = 1st Chevrolet Cavalier sedan.jpg | production = 1981–1987 | model_years = 1982–1987 | assembly = United States: [[Lordstown, Ohio]] ([[Lordstown Assembly]])

[[South Gate, California]] ([[South Gate Assembly]])
[[Kansas City, Missouri]] ([[Leeds Assembly]])

Wagon: {{convert|66.3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = Sedan & Coupe: {{convert|52.0|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
Wagon: {{convert|54.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | transmission = 4-speed [[Manual transmission|manual]]
5-speed manual
3-speed [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] | designer = Irvin Rybicki (1977){{cite web | title=85 Years of GM Design: the timeline | website=Car Body Design | date=2012-06-18 | url=http://www.carbodydesign.com/2012/06/gm-design-the-timeline/ | access-date=2019-08-15}}< }} [[File:1982 Chevrolet Cavalier Postcard.jpg|thumb|left|200px|1982 Chevrolet Cavalier CL 2-Door Coupe & 1982 Chevrolet Cavalier CL Station Wagon]] [[File:'85-'88 Chevrolet Cavalier Coupe.jpg|thumb|left|200px|1986–1987 Chevrolet Cavalier coupe]] [[File:Chevrolet Cavalier Station wagon (4847269073).jpg|thumb|left|200px|1986–1987 Chevrolet Cavalier wagon]] [[File:Cavalier Type 10 Hatch.jpg|thumb|left|200px|1982–1985 Chevrolet Cavalier Type 10 Hatchback]] The Cavalier first went on sale in May 1981 as a 1982 model with front-wheel-drive,{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/94300271/|title=J-cars 'dismal failure'|last=|first=|date=1982-04-26|work=Herald and Review|access-date=|location=Decatur, Illinois|edition=Evening|page=6}} a choice of two carbureted versions of the GM [[GM 122 engine|122]] series four-cylinder [[pushrod]] engines, and 2 and 4-door sedan, hatchback, and station wagon body styles. Convertibles were added in 1983, initial production totaling less than 1000. The Cavalier name originated from GM's then-British subsidiary [[Vauxhall Motors|Vauxhall]], who applied it to badge engineered variants of the [[Opel Ascona]], the third generation of which was the first J-body car to be released. 1983 Cavaliers offered [[throttle body]] [[fuel injection]], and a [[V6 engine]] became available in 1984. The 1984 models received a mild facelift featuring quad headlights. Z24 was introduced in 1985 for 1986 model year coupe and hatchback configurations. The Cavalier in [[Mexico]] was identical to the [[Pontiac Sunbird]] before the [[Pontiac]] brand was officially introduced there in 1992. After that time, the Cavaliers sold there featured Sunbird body panels, as opposed to US-spec Cavalier panels. From 1993 on, the sibling marques were both offered, much in the same way as in the United States. ===Engines=== * 1982: 1.8 L ''[[GM 122 engine#L46|L46]]'' carbureted OHV [[Straight-4|I4]] * 1983-1986: 2.0 L ''[[GM 122 engine#LQ5|LQ5]]'' TBI OHV I4 * 1987–1989: 2.0 L ''[[GM 122 engine#LL8|LL8]]'' TBI OHV I4 * 1985–1989: 2.8 L ''[[GM 60-Degree V6 engine#LB6|LB6]]'' MPFI OHV [[V6]] {{clear}} == Second generation (1988–1994) == {{Infobox automobile | name = Second generation | image = 88-90 Chevrolet Cavalier sedan.jpg | model_years = 1988–1994 | production = 1987–1994 | body_style = 2-door coupe

3-speed [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] | wheelbase = 1988–89: {{convert|101.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}

1988–89 Sedan/Coupe/Wagon: {{convert|66.0|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = 1988–1991 Coupe & 1990–91 Convertible: {{convert|52.0|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1988–1991 Sedan: {{convert|53.6|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1988–89 & 1992–95 Convertible: {{convert|52.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1988–89 Wagon: {{convert|54.3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1990–91 Wagon: {{convert|54.1|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1992–95 Wagon: {{convert|53.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1992–95 Coupe: {{convert|51.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1992–95 Sedan: {{convert|53.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|2359|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} (coupe)
{{convert|2363|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} (sedan)
{{convert|2271|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} (RS coupe)
{{convert|2414|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} (RS sedan)
{{convert|2558|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} (Z24 coupe)
{{convert|2665|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} (Z24 convertible) | designer = Irvin Rybicki (1984){{Cite web|url=https://www.firstcoastnews.com/article/news/local/auto/first-coat-gears-gm-design-celebrates-85-years/77-362931065|title=First Coat Gears: GM Design celebrates 85 years|date=2012-06-22|website=First Coast News|access-date=2019-08-15}} }} The Cavalier was restyled in 1987 for the 1988 model year.{{Cite magazine|last=|first=|date=Nov 1987|title=Cars for 1988|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u8wDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA170|magazine=Ebony|volume=43|issue=1|page=172|pages=|doi=|issn=0012-9011|pmid=|access-date=2019-08-15}} The three-door hatchback was dropped, while the coupe, sedan, wagon and convertible carried over. The sedan and wagon were unchanged from the doors back, while the coupe's exterior was completely redesigned. This resulted in different trunk designs for the coupe and sedan. Three trim levels were available for 1988: VL, RS, and Z24. The convertible was only available as a Z24. The VL and RS came standard with the [[GM 122 engine|2.0 L OHV L4]] engine, now upgraded to throttle-body injection, or TBI, producing {{Convert|90|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}}, while the [[GM 60-Degree V6 engine#Generation II|2.8 L V6]] producing {{Convert|125|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} was optional on the RS and standard on the Z24.{{cite web | title=1988 Chevrolet Cavalier | website=MSN Autos | date=2013-06-06 | url=http://autos.msn.com/research/vip/Spec_Glance.aspx?year=1988&make=Chevrolet&model=Cavalier | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606034231/http://autos.msn.com/research/vip/Spec_Glance.aspx?year=1988&make=Chevrolet&model=Cavalier | archive-date=2013-06-06 | url-status=dead | access-date=2019-08-15}} With two-door models, a 5-speed manual transmission was standard and a 3-speed automatic was optional, however the 3-speed automatic was made standard on sedans and wagons. An [[Digital dash|electronic dashboard]] was available with the RS and Z24 trims. [[File:1989 Chevrolet Cavalier Z24 Convertible in Dark Red, front left (Hershey 2019).jpg|thumb|left|1989 Cavalier Z24 convertible]] [[File:91-94 Chevrolet Cavalier wagon.jpg|thumb|left|1991–1994 Cavalier wagon]] For 1989, the [[steering column]] was redesigned. The new self-aligning steering wheel was designed so as to reduce injuries in a collision by bending to conform to the driver's chest. Also, rear shoulder belts became standard on all models. RS and Z24 custom cloth seating received a new style of front bucket seats with integral headrests. The optional V6 was retooled to 130 hp.{{cite web | title=1989 Chevrolet Cavalier | website=HowStuffWorks | date=2007-08-04 | url=https://auto.howstuffworks.com/chevrolet-cavalier.htm | access-date=2019-08-15}} For 1990, the base engine was enlarged to a [[GM 122 engine#2200 OHV|2.2 L OHV L4]], and power increased to {{convert|95|hp}}. Door-mounted automatic front seatbelts were added due to US passive restraint legislation. The optional V6 engine was also upgraded to the [[GM 60-Degree V6 engine#Generation II|3.1 L V6]] and 140 horsepower.{{cite web | title=1990 Chevrolet Cavalier | website=MSN Autos | date=2014-08-08 | url=http://autos.msn.com/research/vip/Spec_Glance.aspx?year=1990&make=Chevrolet&model=Cavalier | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808051438/http://autos.msn.com/research/vip/Spec_Glance.aspx?year=1990&make=Chevrolet&model=Cavalier | archive-date=2014-08-08 | url-status=dead | access-date=2019-08-15}} The convertible was dropped from availability to prevent internal competition with a planned [[Chevrolet Beretta|Beretta convertible]]. However, the Beretta convertible was shelved at the eleventh hour, before a 1990 Cavalier convertible could be prepared. [[File:91-94 Chevrolet Cavalier coupe.jpg|thumb|left|1993–1994 Cavalier coupe]] The 1991 Cavalier got a more extensive restyling that involved a new hood, bumpers, headlights, taillights, wheel covers and a redesigned interior, however with the body style remaining unchanged. Most notably, the cooling system was redesigned to draw air from the bumper, giving it a [[Ford Taurus (first-generation)|Ford Taurus]]-style bumper and grille-less nose. The new bumpers were unpainted, with the option to have them colored grey, black or white; the latter only available on white-colored models. The RS and the Z24 eschewed this for a color keyed body package. Z24 models also gained the options for a height adjustable driver's seat and a CD player. The platform and trim lines were carried over, while the convertible was brought back mid-year in the RS trim only with the V6 standard.{{cite web | last=Donaldson | first=Jessica | title=1990 Chevrolet Cavalier | website=conceptcarz.com | url=https://www.conceptcarz.com/vehicle/z12095/chevrolet-cavalier.aspx | access-date=2019-08-15}} Minor changes for 1991 also included the Alpha Tech ignition lock cylinder, which incorporated a dual-bit key that was larger and thicker in size in comparison to the old single-bit lock cylinder system that had been used for years. The lock system was intended to be a stronger deterrent to vehicle theft, but constant problems were reported with the lock jamming. It was dropped after an improved dual-bit single key system was introduced for the 1995 model year and redesign. For 1992, the 2.2 L OHV standard engine adopted [[MPFI#Multi-point fuel injection|multi-point fuel injection]], or MPFI to improve output to {{convert|110|hp}}, however unlike the SFI version of the 2.2L in the Chevrolet Corsica.{{cite web | title=1992 Chevrolet Cavalier | website=MSN Autos | date=2012-03-02 | url=http://autos.msn.com/research/vip/Spec_Glance.aspx?year=1992&make=Chevrolet&model=Cavalier | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302065644/http://autos.msn.com/research/vip/Spec_Glance.aspx?year=1992&make=Chevrolet&model=Cavalier | archive-date=2012-03-02 | url-status=dead | access-date=2019-08-15}} The convertible was now available in both RS and Z24 trims, with the V6 standard in the Z24 and optional with the RS. [[Antilock braking system|Antilock brakes]] were added as a standard feature, as [[Delco Moraine]] had managed to develop a low-cost system. Power locks were also standard, and were designed to automatically lock when the car is shifted out of park, or if the car is traveling at least 8 miles per hour in manual transmission equipped Coupe models. Model year 1993 brought minimal changes to the Cavalier line. The convertibles receive a glass rear window, allowing rear window defrost as an option.{{cite web | title=1993 Chevrolet Cavalier | website=HowStuffWorks | date=2007-08-04 | url=https://auto.howstuffworks.com/chevrolet-cavalier.htm | access-date=2019-08-15}} Also, General Motors received a new grille for the final time in this generation of the Chevrolet Cavalier. [[File:1994 Chevrolet Cavalier Z24.jpg|thumb|left|1994 Cavalier Z24 Convertible]] 1994 models were also carryovers, as a redesign of the Cavalier was in development. The VL trim was dropped on the wagon, while the [[GM 122 engine#2200 OHV|2.2 L OHV L4]] was now converted to the SFI version found in the Corsica, which delivered an output of 120 horsepower.{{cite web | title=1994 Chevrolet Cavalier | website=MSN Autos | date=2012-03-02 | url=http://autos.msn.com/research/vip/Spec_Glance.aspx?year=1994&make=Chevrolet&model=Cavalier | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302065651/http://autos.msn.com/research/vip/Spec_Glance.aspx?year=1994&make=Chevrolet&model=Cavalier | archive-date=2012-03-02 | url-status=dead | access-date=2019-08-15}} Additional changes included a slightly redesigned climate control interface and the power locking system being again redesigned: the doors would still lock automatically when put into gear, but they would also unlock automatically when the ignition was switched off. {{clear}} == Third generation (1995–2005) == {{Infobox automobile | name = Third generation | image = 2000-2002 Chevrolet Cavalier sedan.jpg | caption = 2000-2002 Cavalier sedan | model_years = 1995–2005 | production = August 8, 1994–October 6, 2005{{cite web | title=The story behind GM's costly J-car launch | website=WardsAuto | date=1995-04-01 | url=https://www.wardsauto.com/news-analysis/story-behind-gms-costly-j-car-launch | access-date=2019-08-15}} | assembly = [[Lordstown, Ohio]], [[United States]]

[[Chevrolet Optra]] (For Mexico) | designer = Chuck Jordan (1991){{cite book|last=Schefter|first=James|title=All Corvettes Are Red|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D7CwZpAjDNcC&pg=PA104|date=1998-01-21|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-671-68501-0|page=104}} }} [[File:Chevrolet Cavalier convertible.jpg|thumb|left|1995–1999 Chevrolet Cavalier convertible
(Z24)]] [[File:1995 Chevrolet Cavalier.JPG|thumb|left|1995–1999 Chevrolet Cavalier coupe
(RS and Base)]] [[File:2000-2002 Chevrolet Cavalier Coupe.jpg|thumb|left|2000–2002 Chevrolet Cavalier coupe
(RS and LS Sport)]] [[File:2003 Chevrolet Cavalier coupe -- NHTSA.jpg|thumb|left|2003-2005 Chevrolet Cavalier coupe
(Base, LS)]] The Cavalier received its first total redesign for 1995, with expanded dimensions and more aerodynamic styling, taking minor design cues from the 4th generation Chevrolet Camaro. Some of the basic styling cues remained however, such as the bumper-integrated grille, the coupes' dipped beltline, and the charcoal-colored bumpers on some base model cars. Coupe, sedan, and convertible options were offered, however the wagon model was discontinued. The car now had the available option of 15 and 16 inch wheels. By 1997, the Cavalier became the best selling car within the entire GM lineup. For the 3rd generation, powertrain options were limited to inline-four engines. The option for a [[V6 engine]], which had been available in the first and second generation, was dropped and replaced by a new four-cylinder of similar power output. Base and RS models still retained the 2.2L pushrod four-cylinder engine (2.2 L OHV) of the previous models, which was primarily mated to a 3-speed automatic, but was available with 5-speed Manual in the two-door models, in particular the RS models. As of 1996 a new 4-speed automatic became available in any trim. The Z24 and LS convertible used the 2.3 L LD2 Quad-4 engine in 1995, but they received a new engine in 1996, the 2.4 liter DOHC [[Quad 4 engine#LD9|LD9]]. This engine produced {{Convert|150|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{Convert|155|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} of torque and was used until 2002. In 2000, the car gained a minor facelift consisting of bigger headlights and an improved grille, lost the "CHEVROLET" text badge at the trunklid and gained a new "CAVALIER" badge along with new "five spoke" hubcaps. The 2.4-litre engine came mated standard with the [[Getrag F23]] 5-speed [[manual transmission]] on the Z24 models, or with the optional 4-speed automatic on both the Z24 and the LS models. The Z24 only came in two-door coupe models until 2001 and featured a sport-tuned suspension, 16-inch tires, alloy wheels and improved interior electronics. Aesthetically little changed from the other models other than a ground effects kit and taller rear spoiler. In 2000 a 4-door Z24 Sedan debuted, featuring the same mechanics but having a less sporty body. The Z24 trim also received several other upgrades including a wider front sway bar and FE2 Sports Suspension for better handling characteristics, and less aggressive ABS anti-lock braking system. In 2002, the 3-speed automatic was dropped from the base models equipped with the 2.2-L, and the 4-speed automatic became the main offering across the entire lineup, with 5-speed still available in the 2-door cars. Also, the RS was replaced by the LS Sport line, which featured the new '''[[Ecotec]]''' L61 motors ({{Convert|140|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{Convert|150|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} torque). These engines improved fuel economy, featuring the same displacement as the GM 122 Pushrod Engine (2.2 L OHV) while maintaining most of the power of the older LD9 motors. The new Ecotec motors replaced the GM 122 Pushrod Engine (2.2 L OHV) in base models in 2003, and became the sole engine choice in the entire Cavalier line-up until 2005 when the Chevrolet Cavalier was replaced by the [[Chevrolet Cobalt]]. A GM Eaton M45 [[Supercharger]] kit was also offered for the Z24 trim as well. The supercharger kit was developed and tested by General Motors and could only be installed at a GM dealer. This upgrade increased performance considerably due to a pressure of 4.7 PSI which in turn added approximately {{Convert|40|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{Convert|40|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} of torque increase; raising the Z24's ratings to approximately {{Convert|190|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{Convert|195|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} of torque. ===Facelifts=== The third generation Cavalier had two facelifts. There was a minor one in 1999 with new front and rear bumper fascias which included revised headlamps and taillamps for 2000 models.{{cite web | title=2000 Chevrolet Cavalier Z24 Review | website=auto123.com | url=https://www.auto123.com/en/car-reviews/2000-chevrolet-cavalier-z24/46473/ | access-date=2019-08-15}} There was a more extensive refresh in 2002 for the 2003 model year, which included a complete new front end design, revised taillamps with a full-width rear reflector, a new rear spoiler and rear bumper fascia.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/114176162/|title=Classifieds|last=|first=|date=2002-09-03|work=Poughkeepsie Journal|access-date=2019-08-15|page=6E}} ===Safety=== The third-generation Cavalier earned several low scores in crash tests by the [[Insurance Institute for Highway Safety]] and [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]]. Also, IIHS fatality risks statistics rated the Cavalier among the "highest rates of driver deaths", with 150 (four-door) to 171 (two-door) driver deaths per million registered vehicle years. Average for the Cavalier class (small) was 103 (four-door) to 134 (two-door) driver deaths per million registered vehicle years.{{cite web|url=http://www.iihs.org/sr/pdfs/sr4204.pdf |title=Status Report, Vol. 42, No. 4, April 19, 2007 |format=PDF |accessdate=2010-10-05 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081127162428/http://www.iihs.org/sr/pdfs/sr4204.pdf |archivedate=2008-11-27 }} The IIHS gave the 1995-2005 Cavalier a "poor" overall score in their frontal offset collision test.{{cite web | title=2005 Chevrolet Cavalier | website=IIHS-HLDI crash testing and highway safety | url=https://www.iihs.org/ratings/vehicle/chevrolet/cavalier-4-door-sedan/2005 | access-date=2019-08-15}} 2005 [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] (NHTSA) Crash Test Ratings (coupe):{{cite web | title=2005 Chevrolet Cavalier 2 DR | website=NHTSA | date=2017-11-01 | url=https://www.nhtsa.gov/vehicle/2005/CHEVROLET/CAVALIER/2%252520DR | access-date=2019-08-15}} *Frontal driver: {{rating|4|5}} *Frontal passenger: {{rating|4|5}} *Side driver: {{rating|1|5}} *safety concern* *Side rear passenger: {{rating|2|5}} *Rollover: {{rating|4|5}} 2002 National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) Crash Test Ratings (sedan):{{cite web | title=2002 Chevrolet Cavalier 4 DR | website=NHTSA | date=2017-11-01 | url=https://www.nhtsa.gov/vehicle/2002/CHEVROLET/CAVALIER/4%252520DR | access-date=2019-08-15}} *Frontal driver: {{rating|4|5}} *Frontal passenger: {{rating|4|5}} *Side driver: {{rating|1|5}} *safety concern* *Side rear passenger: {{rating|3|5}} *Rollover: {{rating|4|5}} ===Toyota Cavalier=== [[File:Toyota cavalier coup japan export.jpg|thumb|right|1998 Toyota Cavalier coupé (Japanese export model with [[Amber (color)|amber]] rear turn signals, [[right hand drive]] and flecked red-grey interior)]] [[File:Toyota Cavalier 1.JPG|thumb|left|Toyota Cavalier sedan (Japan)]] As part of a wider effort to avoid additional restrictions on exports to the US, the third generation model was briefly sold in Japan by [[Toyota]] under an agreement with GM, [[Rebadging|badged]] as the {{ill|Toyota Cavalier|ja|トヨタ・キャバリエ|vertical-align=sup}}. Aside from the fact that it was right hand drive, the Toyota Cavalier also featured a leather-wrapped shift knob, steering wheel and park brake lever, wider front fenders, [[Amber (color)|amber]] turn signals for Japanese regulations, power folding side mirrors, side turn signal repeater lights on the front fenders, and carpeting on the inside of the trunk lid. Interior seats were often flecked with color, and the rear seat had a fold-down armrest. Vehicles produced from February through December 1998 were available with a leather interior equipped with an automatic transmission only. All models featured wheels borrowed from the [[Pontiac Sunfire]]. The Toyota Cavalier was available in 2.4G and 2.4Z trim levels. While all Chevrolet-badged Cavaliers received a facelift for 2000, the Toyota did as well with the updated center console, head-lights/hood/front bumper, tail-lights, and colors available. [[Toyota Racing Development|TRD]] made a body kit and rear wing for the Cavalier, available exclusively in Japan. The car was sold only at [[Toyota#Japan|Toyota Store]] Japanese dealerships. The Cavalier was not the only GM product sold in Japan; the [[Saturn S-series]] was sold at Saturn dealerships (some former [[Isuzu]] dealerships) from 1996 until 2003, and some Toyota Vista Stores also retailed Saturns. The Cavalier was entirely produced by GM in the USA at the [[Lordstown Assembly]] location, and sold from 1995–2000. The 1996-2000 Toyota Cavaliers came equipped with the 2.4 L LD9 engine, while the 1995 used the 2.3 L Quad 4. Due to the engine displacement and width dimensions ({{convert|1740|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} for the coupe, {{convert|1735|mm|in|0|abbr=on}} for the sedan ) exceeding [[Vehicle size class#Japan|Japanese government regulations]] concerning exterior dimensions and maximum engine displacement, it was not considered a "compact" so it was sold as a "normal-class car" like the [[Toyota Mark II]] and [[Nissan Skyline]]. Prices for the coupe started at 2 million yen for the coupe, and 1.81 million yen for the sedan. the final Toyota Cavalier was imported in 2000. [[File:Toyota Cavalier 2.JPG|thumb|left|Toyota Cavalier with amber side and rear turn signals]] The introduction of the Toyota Cavalier was not the first time the Cavalier was sold in Japan. [[Yanase (car dealership)|Yanase Co., Ltd.]], a Japanese retail dealership that started importing European and North American vehicles soon after the end of World War II, sold various GM products including the Cavalier. When the decision was made to sell the Cavalier as a Toyota, this disrupted operations at Yanase. When the Toyota Cavalier was cancelled, Yanase continued to sell Chevrolet and other GM products. Yanase also provides complete maintenance services for all vehicles sold. Due to higher than typically average [[Motor-vehicle inspection (Japan)|vehicle inspection]] costs, a fair number of these vehicles are re-exported as Japanese used cars, most notably to Australia and New Zealand. Production of the Toyota Cavalier ceased in June 2000. Despite Toyota making considerable efforts to sell the Cavalier on the domestic market, the Japanese public perceived the quality of workmanship to not be up to the standard typically expected of locally built cars.{{cite web | title=The Toyota Cavalier And The Truth About Japanese Import Barriers | website=The Truth About Cars | date=2010-01-19 | url=https://www.thetruthaboutcars.com/2010/01/the-toyota-cavalier-and-the-truth-about-japanese-import-barriers/ | access-date=2019-08-15}} The car was also introduced while economic conditions in Japan were beginning to decline as a result of the collapse of the [[Japanese asset price bubble]] or "bubble economy" that ended in the early 1990s. == Production == Most Cavaliers were built at [[Lordstown Assembly]], although they have also been produced at [[South Gate Assembly]] (1982 model year only), [[Lansing Car Assembly]] (1996-1998 coupes), [[Lansing Craft Centre]] (1996-2000 convertibles), [[Janesville Assembly]], [[Ramos Arizpe, Coahuila|Ramos Arizpe]], and [[Leeds Assembly]]. This car was discontinued in 2005, the last Cavalier rolled off the assembly line on October 6, 2005. {{clear}} =={{anchor|Fourth|China|Kewozi}} Fourth generation (2016–present) == {{Infobox automobile | name = Fourth generation | image = Chevrolet Cavalier CN 01 China 2017-03-28.jpg | caption = Chevrolet Cavalier sedan (China) | production = 2016–present | assembly = [[Shanghai]], [[China]] ([[SAIC-GM|Shanghai GM]]) | body_style = 4-door [[sedan (automobile)|sedan]] | layout = [[Front-engine, front-wheel-drive layout|FF layout]] | platform = [[GM Delta II platform|Delta II platform]] | wheelbase = {{convert|2600|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|4544|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|1779|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|1467|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | engine = 1.5 L [[Daewoo S-TEC engine#S-TEC III|S-TEC III]] [[Inline-four engine|I4]] | transmission = 5-speed [[Manual transmission|manual]]
6-speed [[automatic transmission|automatic]] | predecessor = [[Chevrolet Sonic]] (Mexico){{cite web|last1=Roy|first1=Cesar|title=Chevrolet Aveo y Sonic se descontinúan; regresa Cavalier (Cobalt) en subcompacto B|url=http://www.alvolante.info/nacionales/chevrolet-aveo-y-sonic-se-descontinuan-regresa-cavalier-cobalt-en-subcompacto-b/|website=Al Volante|publisher=Al Volante|accessdate=May 2, 2018}} | successor = [[Chevrolet Monza (China)]]
[[Chevrolet Onix]] (China, also known as the Kewozi 科沃兹) }} [[File:2016 Chevrolet Cavalier rear 8.13.18.jpg|thumb|left|Chevrolet Cavalier]] [[Chevrolet]] reintroduced the Cavalier name on a new China-only compact sedan below the [[Chevrolet Cruze|Cruze]], with the Chinese name being Chevrolet Kewozi (科沃兹).{{cite web|url=https://www.autohome.com.cn/4105/|title=【科沃兹】雪佛兰_科沃兹报价_科沃兹图片_汽车之家|date=2018-02-05|website=autohome.com.cn|language=zh|trans-title=SAIC GM Chevrolet -Kovaz|access-date=2019-08-15}} The Cavalier was introduced at the 2016 Chengdu Auto Show on September 2, 2016. It was developed on the same platform as the first generation Cruze, the [[GM Delta II platform|Delta II platform]], and uses the 1.5 liter four-cylinder engine that powers many compact GM models in China, including the [[Chevrolet Sail]]. Its pricing sets the Cavalier exactly between the smaller Sail and the more modern second generation Cruze. Deliveries started in September, with almost 10,000 units sold in its first month, but there are indications the Cavalier cannibalizes sales of the similarly priced first generation Cruze, which continues to be sold in China. As of 2018, the fourth generation Cavalier is also sold in Mexico with the same name, replacing the [[Chevrolet Sonic]]. There, the 1.5 L engine produces {{convert|107|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|104|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} torque. The Cavalier was updated for the 2020 model year for Mexico with minor changes, adding three new colors, new alloy design, four airbags and ABS brakes, three-point seatbelts, and stability control as well as minor changes to the interior for the LT trim line including a 7" with Chevrolet myLink and Smartphone Integration for Apple CarPlay. The 2020 Cavalier went on sale on 23 September 2019.https://noticias.autocosmos.com.mx/2019/09/09/chevrolet-cavalier-2020-llega-a-mexico-ofreciendo-mejoras-en-seguridad-y-diseno {{clear}} == United States sales figures == * 58,904 -
