{{about|the sports car|other uses|Corvette (disambiguation)}} {{short description|Sports car by the Chevrolet division of General Motors (GM)}} {{Infobox automobile | name = Chevrolet Corvette | image = Corvette-Logo-C5.jpg | caption = Chevrolet Corvette logo for the C5 model | manufacturer = [[Chevrolet]] ([[General Motors]]) | aka = Sting Ray (1963–1967)
Stingray (1969–1976, 2014–present) | production = 1953–present | model_years = 1953–1982, 1984–present
{{bulleted list|[[Chevrolet Corvette (C1)|C1]]: 1953–1962|[[Chevrolet Corvette (C2)|C2]]: 1963–1967|[[Chevrolet Corvette (C3)|C3]]: 1968–1982|[[Chevrolet Corvette (C4)|C4]]: 1984–1996|[[Chevrolet Corvette (C5)|C5]]: 1997–2004|[[Chevrolet Corvette (C6)|C6]]: 2005–2013|[[Chevrolet Corvette (C7)|C7]]: 2014–2019|[[Chevrolet Corvette (C8)|C8]]: 2020–present}} | assembly = United States:
{{bulleted list|[[Flint, Michigan]]|[[St. Louis|St. Louis, Missouri]]|[[Bowling Green, Kentucky]]}} | class = [[sports car]] | body_style = 2-door [[coupé]]
2-door [[Convertible (car)|convertible]] | layout = {{unbulleted list|[[Front-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout|FR layout]]/FMR Layout (1953–2019)|[[Rear mid-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout|RMR layout]] (2020–present)}} | engine = {{unbulleted list|235 cu in ''[[Blue Flame (engine)|Blue Flame]]'' [[Straight-six engine|I6]]|265 cu in, 283 cu in, 327 cu in, 350 cu in ''[[Chevrolet Small-Block engine|small-block]]'' [[V8 engine|V8]]|305 cu in ''[[Chevrolet Small-Block engine#305|small-block]]'' V8 (1980; California only)|396 cu in, 427 cu in, 454 cu in ''[[Chevrolet Big-Block engine|big-block]]'' [[V8 engine|V8]]'' V8|5.7 L ''[[GM LT engine|LT1]]'', ''[[Chevrolet small-block engine#LT4|LT4]]'', ''[[Chevrolet small-block engine#LT5|LT5]]'' V8|5.7 L ''[[GM LS engine|LS1]]'', ''[[GM LS6 engine|LS6]]'' V8|6.0 L ''[[GM LS engine|LS2]]'' V8|6.2 L ''[[GM LS engine|LS3]]'' V8|7.0 L ''[[Chevrolet LS7|LS7]]'' V8|6.2 L ''[[GM LS9 engine|LS9]]'' [[Supercharger|supercharged]] V8|6.2 L ''[[GM LS engine|LT1]]'' [[V8 engine|V8]]|6.2 L ''[[GM LS engine|LT2]]'' [[V8 engine|V8]]|6.2 L ''[[GM LT engine|LT4]]'' [[supercharger|supercharged]] [[V8 engine|V8]]|6.2 L ''[[GM LT engine|LT5]]'' [[supercharger|supercharged]] [[V8 engine|V8]]}} }} The '''Chevrolet Corvette''', colloquially known as the '''Vette''',{{cite web|url=http://www.superchevy.com/vette-magazine/|title=Vette magazine - Super Chevy|publisher=}} is a two-door, two-passenger [[sports car]] manufactured and marketed by [[Chevrolet]] across more than 60 years of production and eight design generations.{{cite web|url=http://www.chevrolet.com/corvette-sports-car.html|title=2017 Corvette Stingray: Sports Cars - Chevrolet|publisher=}}{{cite book |author1=Ray Miller |author2=Glenn Embree |title=The Real Corvette: An Illustrated History of Chevrolet's Sports Car |isbn=978-0913056066|year=1975 }} From 1953 to 2019, it was front-engined, and since 2020, it is mid-engined.{{Cite web|url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a27116013/chevrolet-corvette-c8-mid-engine-confirmed-2020/|title=The Mid-Engined 2020 Chevrolet Corvette C8 Is Real, GM Confesses, and It Will Debut July 18|work=[[Car and Driver]]|last=Capparella|first=Joey|date=11 April 2019|accessdate=11 April 2019}} With its generations noted sequentially from C1 to C8, the Corvette serves as Chevrolet's [[halo car|halo vehicle]] and is widely noted for its performance and distinctive plastic—either fiberglass or composite—bodywork. In 1953, when GM executives were looking to name the new Chevrolet sports car, assistant director for the Public Relations department [[Myron Scott]] suggested ''Corvette'' after the [[corvette|small maneuverable warship]]—and the name was approved.{{cite book |title=The Complete Corvette |last=Falconer |first=Tom |year=2003 |publisher=Crestline |isbn=978-0-7603-1474-6 |page=9 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KCFqjW2AXTcC&pg=PT14&dq=Corvette++Myron+Scott |accessdate=Sep 30, 2012}} The first model, a [[convertible (car)|convertible]], was introduced at the [[General Motors Motorama|GM Motorama]] in 1953 as a concept and was followed ten years later by the 1963 second generation, in coupe and convertible styles. Originally manufactured in [[Flint, Michigan]], as well as [[St. Louis|St. Louis, Missouri]], the Corvette has been manufactured since 1981 in [[Bowling Green, Kentucky]]. The Corvette has since become widely known as "America's Sports Car."{{cite magazine |title = America's Sports Car |magazine = Road & Track |author = Thos L. Bryant |date = November 6, 2012 |url = https://www.roadandtrack.com/car-culture/a9336/americas-sports-car/}} [[Automotive News]] said that after 'starring' in the early 1960s television show ''[[Route 66 (TV series)|Route 66]]'', the Corvette became synonymous with freedom and adventure," ultimately becoming both "the most successful concept car in history and the most popular sports car in history.{{cite news |title = Corvette: A pop culture classic |newspaper = Automotive News |author = Jerry Burton |date = October 31, 2011 |url = http://www.autonews.com/article/20111031/CHEVY100/310319966/corvette%3A-a-pop-culture-classic}} == History == === First generation (C1; 1953–1962) === {{Main|Chevrolet Corvette (C1)}} The first generation of Corvette was introduced late in the 1953 [[model year]]. Originally designed as a show car for the 1953 Motorama display at the New York Auto Show, it generated enough interest to induce GM to make a production version to sell to the public. First production was on June 30, 1953.{{cite book|last=Emanuel |first=Dave|title=Corvette Tech Q & A|year=2002|publisher=Penguin|isbn=978-1557883766}}{{cite book|last=Porter |first=Lindsay|title=Chevrolet Corvette Restoration Guide|year=1997|publisher=MotorBooks International|isbn=978-0760303252|page=256|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BqpUBaVCOtEC&dq=Chevrolet+Corvette+(C1)+1955}}{{cite web |url=http://www.edmunds.com/chevrolet/corvette/history.html |title=Chevrolet Corvette History |publisher=Edmunds |accessdate=2013-03-29}}[[File:1953 Chevrolet Corvette Motorama Show Car.jpg|thumb|left|1953 Chevrolet Corvette displayed at the 1953 GM Motorama car show.]] This generation was often referred to as the "solid-axle" models (the [[independent rear suspension]] was not introduced until the second generation).{{cite book|last=Mueller|first=Mike|title=Classic Corvette 30 Years|year=2003|publisher=Crestline Imprints|isbn=978-0760318065|page=384|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jBtsVHSnt5gC&dq=Solid+axle+Corvette}} Three hundred hand-built polo white Corvette [[convertible (car)|convertibles]] were produced for the 1953 model year.{{cite book|last=Prince|first=Richard|title=Corvette Buyers Guide, 1953-1967|publisher=MotorBooks International|isbn=978-0760310090|page=192|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6fqyf5ceXucC&dq=Corvette+rushed+into+production|date=2002-08-08}} The 1954 model year vehicles could be ordered in Pennant Blue, Sportsman Red, Black, or Polo White; 3,640 were built, and sold slowly. The 1953 and 1954 model years were the only model years of the Corvette were the only ones that were sold with an engine that wasn't a V8. The engine used in these two model years was a 235 Cu. In. (3.9L) version of the second- generation Blue Flame inline-six generating 150 horsepower. The 1955 model offered a {{convert|265|cuin|L|abbr=on}} [[V8 engine]] as an option. With a large inventory of unsold 1954 models, GM limited production to 700 for 1955. With the new V8, the 0–60 mph time improved by 1.5 seconds. [[File:Chevrolet Corvette Transistorized Hybrid Car Radio-1956.JPG|thumb|left|1956 Chevrolet Corvette transistorized "hybrid" (vacuum tubes and transistors) car radio option, which was GM's first start in using the modern Solid-State electronics for a production car model.]] A new body was introduced for the 1956 model featuring a new "face" and side coves; the taillamp fins were also gone.{{cite book|last=W. Passon|first=Jerry|title=The Corvette in Literature and Culture: Symbolic Dimensions of America's Sports Car|year=2011|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0786462841|page=246|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l_Qrc1s2uAsC&dq=Chevrolet+Corvette+(C1)+1955}} An optional "[[Rochester Ramjet|Ramjet]]" [[fuel injection]] system was made available in the middle of the 1957 model year. It was one of the first American mass-produced engines in history to reach {{convert|1|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} per cubic inch (16.4 cubic cm) and Chevrolet's advertising agency used a "one hp per cubic inch" slogan for advertising the {{convert|283|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} {{convert|283|cuin|L|abbr=on}} [[Chevrolet Small-Block engine#283|Small-Block engine]].{{cite book|last=Gunnell|first=John|title=Standard Guide To 1950s American Cars|year=2004|publisher=Krause Publications|isbn=978-0873498685|page=[https://archive.org/details/standardguideto100john/page/256 256]|url=https://archive.org/details/standardguideto100john|url-access=registration|quote=one hp per cubic inch corvette.}} Other options included power windows (1956), [[hydraulic]]ally operated power [[convertible (car)|convertible]] top (1956), heavy duty brakes and suspension (1957), and four speed manual [[transmission (mechanics)|transmission]] (late 1957). Delco Radio transistorized signal-seeking "hybrid" car radio, which used both vacuum tubes and transistors in its radio's circuitry (1956 option).{{cite news |title=Chevrolet Restyles Sleek 1956 Corvette |work=Christian Science Monitor |date=February 20, 1956 |page=22}}1956 GM Year-End Annual Report, pg 15 The 1958 Corvette received a body and interior freshening which included a longer front end with quad headlamps, bumper exiting exhaust tips, a new steering wheel, and a dashboard with all gauges mounted directly in front of the driver.{{cite book|last=Gunnell|first=John|title=Standard catalog of Corvette, 1953-2005|year=2004|publisher=Krause Publications|isbn=978-0873499071|edition=Second|url=https://archive.org/details/standardcatalogo00john}} Exclusive to the 1958 model were hood louvers and twin trunk spears. The 1959–60 model years had few changes except a decreased amount of body chrome and more powerful engine offerings.{{cite book|author=Staff of ''Old Cars Weekly''|title=Corvette – The Great American Sports Car|year=2010|publisher=Krause Publications|isbn=978-1440215513|page=208|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WsjanO7xW58C&dq=1958+Corvette}} In 1961, the rear of the car was completely redesigned with the addition of a "duck tail" with four round lights. The light treatment would continue for all following model year Corvettes until 2014.{{cite book|last=Gunnell|first=John|title=Standard Catalog of Chevrolet, 1912–2003: 90 Years of History, Photos, Technical Data and Pricing|year=2011|publisher=F+W Media |isbn=978-1440230554|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lbWMwV86qPsC&dq=1961+corvette}} In 1962, the Chevrolet {{convert|283|cuin|L|abbr=on}} [[Chevrolet Small-Block engine|Small-Block]] was enlarged to {{convert|327|cuin|L|abbr=on}}. In standard form it produced {{convert|250|bhp|kW|abbr=on}}. For an extra 12% over list price, the fuel-injected version produced {{convert|360|bhp|kW|abbr=on}},{{cite book|last=Antonick|first=Mike|title=Corvette Black Book, 1953-2007|year=2006|publisher=MotorBooks International|isbn=978-0760328941|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9P-RNjfCeRYC&dq=1962+Corvette | pages = 44–45}} making it the fastest of the C1 generation. 1962 was also the last year for the wrap around windshield, solid rear axle, and convertible-only body style.{{cite book|last=Gunnell|first=John|title=Standard Catalog of Chevrolet – 3rd Edition|year=2011|publisher=Krause Publications|isbn=978-1440227936|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uMZwG4v0ZeAC&dq=1961+corvette}} The trunk lid and exposed headlamps did not reappear for many decades.{{cite book|last=Antonick|first=Mike|title=Corvette Black, Books 1953-2007|year=2006|publisher=MotorBooks International|isbn=978-0760328941|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9P-RNjfCeRYC&dq=1962+Corvette}} File:The first Corvettes produced in Flint, Michigan on June 30, 1953 assemble line.jpg|1953 Corvette exits assembly line File:1954 Chevrolet Corvette (18863241390).jpg|1954 Corvette convertible File:1956 Corvette Mt. Kisco.jpg|1956 Corvette convertible File:59 Chevrolet Corvette (9119262571).jpg|1959 Corvette convertible (rear) File:Heidelberg Historic 2015 - Chevrolet Corvette C1 1960 2015-07-11 16-25-02.JPG|1960 Corvette convertible === Second generation (C2; 1963–1967) === {{Main|Chevrolet Corvette (C2)}} [[File:1963 Corvette Sting Ray.jpg|thumb|right|1963 Corvette Sting Ray coupe]] The second generation (C2) Corvette, which introduced '''Sting Ray''' to the model, continued with fiberglass body panels, and overall, was smaller than the first generation. The C2 was later referred to as ''mid-years''.{{cite book|last=Mueller|first=Mike|title=The Corvette Factories: Building America's Sports Car|year=2009|publisher=MotorBooks International|isbn=978-0-7603-3551-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ogJxa6-rMLEC&dq=c2+corvette+Larry+Shinoda}} The car was designed by [[Larry Shinoda]] with major inspiration from a previous concept design called the "Q Corvette," which was created by Peter Brock and Chuck Pohlmann under the styling direction of [[Bill Mitchell (designer)|Bill Mitchell]].{{cite journal|journal=Popular Mechanics|date=March 2003 |issn=0032-4558|page=61|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=c88DAAAAMBAJ&dq=c2+corvette+Larry+Shinoda |title= 50 Corvette |last1=Magazines |first1=Hearst }} Earlier, Mitchell had sponsored a car known as the "[[Corvette Stingray (concept car)|Mitchell Sting Ray]]" in 1959 because Chevrolet no longer participated in factory racing. This vehicle had the largest effect on the styling of this generation, although it had no top and did not give away what the final version of the C2 would look like.{{cite book|last=Newton|first=Richard|title=Corvette Restoration Guide, 1963-1967|year=1999|publisher=MotorBooks International|isbn=978-0-7603-0179-1|page=18|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eUFVYkBduPEC&dq=Mitchell+Sting+Ray}} The third inspiration was a [[Mako Shark]] Mitchell had caught while deep-sea fishing.{{cite book|title=DieCastX Magazine|year=2007|publisher=Air Age|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OvoDAAAAMBAJ&dq=Mako+Shark+Mitchell+had+caught+while+deep-sea+fishing.}} Production started for the 1963 model year and ended in 1967. Introducing a new name, "Sting Ray", the 1963 model was the first year for a Corvette [[coupé]] and it featured a distinctive tapering rear deck (a feature that later reappeared on the 1971 "Boattail" [[Buick Riviera]]) with, for 1963 only, a split rear window. The Sting Ray featured hidden headlamps, non-functional hood vents, and an [[independent rear suspension]].{{cite journal|journal=Hot Rod |title=Street Machines and Bracket Racing |issue=5 |year=1981 |page=77}} Corvette chief engineer [[Zora Arkus-Duntov]] never liked the split rear window because it blocked rear vision, but Mitchell thought it to be a key part of the entire design. Maximum power for 1963 was {{convert|360|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} and was raised to {{convert|375|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} in 1964. Options included [[electronic ignition]], the breakerless magnetic pulse-triggered Delcotronic first offered on some 1963 [[Pontiac]] models.{{cite book| title=Super Street Cars|publisher=Super Street Cars|page=35}} On 1964 models the decorative hood vents were eliminated and Duntov, the Corvette's chief engineer, got his way with the split rear window changed to a full width window. [[File:1965 Corvette Sting Ray.jpg|thumb|left|1965 Corvette Sting Ray coupe]] Four-wheel [[disc brake]]s were introduced in 1965, as was a "[[big-block|big block]]" engine option: the [[Chevrolet Big-Block engine#Generation 2: Mark IV Series|{{convert|396|cuin|L|abbr=on}}]] V8. Side exhaust pipes were also optionally available in 1965, and continued to be offered through 1967. The introduction of the {{convert|425|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} {{convert|396|cuin|L|abbr=on}} big block in 1965 spelled the beginning of the end for the [[Rochester Products Division|Rochester]] fuel injection system.{{cite book|author=Staff of Old Cars Weekly|title=Nothin' but Muscle|year=2010|publisher=Krause Publications|isbn=978-1-4402-1549-0|page=34|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o6hBEhAvkUoC&dq=1965+%22big+block%22+Sting+Ray+corvette}} The {{convert|396|cuin|L|abbr=on}} option cost {{USD|292.70}} while the fuel injected {{convert|327|cuin|L|abbr=on}} engine cost {{USD|538.00}}. Few people could justify spending {{USD|245.00}} more for {{convert|50|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} less, even though FI could deliver over 20 mpg on the highway and would keep delivering fuel despite high G-loading in corners taken at racing speeds. Another rare '63 and '64 option was the Z06 competition package, which offered stiffer suspension, bigger, multi-segment lined brakes with finned drums, and more. Only a couple hundred coupes and a single convertible were factory-equipped this way in 1963. With only 771 fuel-injected cars built in 1965, Chevrolet discontinued the option at the end of the '65 production, having introduced a less-expensive big block 396 engine rated at 425 hp in the middle of the production year and selling over 2,000 in just a few months. For 1966, Chevrolet introduced an even larger {{convert|427|cuin|L|abbr=on}} [[Chevrolet Big-Block engine#427|Big Block]] version. Other options available on the C2 included the Wonderbar auto-tuning AM radio, AM-FM radio (mid-1963), air conditioning (late-1963), a telescopic steering wheel (1965), and headrests (1966). The Sting Ray's independent rear suspension was successfully adapted for the new-for-1965 [[Chevrolet Corvair]], which solved the quirky handling problems of that unique rear-engine compact.{{cite journal|journal=Popular Mechanics|date=September 1988 |issn=0032-4558|url= https://archive.org/details/bub_gb_zOQDAAAAMBAJ |quote=Sting Ray's independent rear suspension was.|title=Driving the New Corvette |publisher=Hearst Magazines }} [[File:1967 Corvette Sting Ray 427.jpg|thumb|right|1967 Corvette Sting Ray convertible]] 1967 was the final year for the C2 generation. The 1967 model featured restyled fender vents, less ornamentation, and back-up lamps which were on the inboard in 1966 were now rectangular and centrally located. The first use of all four taillights in red started in 1961 and was continued thru the C-2 line-up except for the 1966. The 1967 and subsequent models continuing on all Corvettes since. 1967 had the first L88 engine option which was rated at {{convert|430|bhp|kW|abbr=on}}, but unofficial estimates place the actual output at {{convert|560|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} or more.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1CqX-40TnVUC&pg=PA203 |last=Leffingwell|first=Randy |title=Corvette Fifty Years |publisher=MBI Publishing |year=2002 |page=203|isbn=978-0-7603-1180-6}} Only twenty such engines were installed at the factory. From 1967 (to 1969), the Holley triple two-barrel carburetor, or [[Tri-Power]], was available on the 427 L89 (a $368 option, on top of the cost for the high-performance 427).{{cite book |last=Flory, Jr. |first=J. "Kelly" |title=American Cars, 1960–1972: Every Model, Year by Year|publisher=McFarland |year=2004 |page=505 |isbn=978-0-7864-1273-0 }} Despite these changes, sales slipped over 15%, to 22,940 (8,504 coupes, off close to 15%, and 14,436 convertibles, down nearly 19%).Flory, p.509. Duntov came up with a lightweight version of the C2 in 1962. Concerned about Ford and what they were doing with the [[Shelby Cobra]], GM planned to manufacture 100 [[Chevrolet Corvette (C2)#Grand Sport|Grand Sport]] Corvettes, but only five were actually built.{{cite book|title=Popular Mechanics|year=2003|publisher=Hearst Magazines|issn=0032-4558|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c88DAAAAMBAJ&dq=Chevrolet+Corvette+(C2)+Grand+Sport}} They were driven by historic drivers such as [[Roger Penske]], [[A. J. Foyt]], [[Jim Hall (race car driver)|Jim Hall]], and Dick Guldstrand among others. Today the five cars (001-005) are all held by private owners, and are among the most coveted and valuable Corvettes ever built.{{cite book|last=Friedman|first=Dave|title=Corvette Grand Sport|year=2004|publisher=MotorBooks International|isbn=978-0-7603-1926-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=363HifpJYnsC&dq=Dick+Thompson+was+the+first+driver+to+win+a+race+in+the+Grand+Sport}} 002 is exhibited in the [[Simeone Foundation Automotive Museum]] and is in running condition.{{cite web|url=http://www.simeonemuseum.org/the-collection/watkins-glen/1963-chevrolet-corvette-grand-sport|title=1963 Chevrolet Corvette Grand Sport|work=simeonemuseum.org}} === Third generation (C3; 1968–1982) === {{Main|Chevrolet Corvette (C3)}} [[File:69 Corvette Stingray.jpg|thumb|1969 Corvette Stingray coupe with T-top panels removed]] [[File:1971 Corvette coupe.jpg|thumb|1971 Corvette Stingray coupe]] The third generation Corvette, patterned after the [[Corvette Mako Shark (Concept car)|Mako Shark II]] concept car, was introduced for the 1968 model year and was in production until 1982. C3 coupes featured the first use of [[T-top]] removable roof panels. It introduced monikers that were later revived, such as LT-1, ZR-1, Z07 and Collector Edition. In 1978, the Corvette's 25th anniversary was celebrated with a two-tone Silver Anniversary Edition and an Indy Pace Car replica edition of the C3. This was also the first time that a Corvette was used as a Pace Car for the [[Indianapolis 500]].{{cite book|title=Popular Mechanics|year=1977|publisher=Hearst Magazines|issn=0032-4558}} Engines and chassis components were mostly carried over from the C2, but the body and interior were new. The {{convert|350|cuin|L|abbr=on}} engine replaced the old {{convert|327|cuin|L|abbr=on}} as the base engine in 1969, but power remained at {{convert|300|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. 1969 was the only year for a C3 to optionally offer either a factory installed side exhaust or normal rear exit with chrome tips. The all-aluminum ZL1 engine was also new for 1969; the special big-block engine was listed at 430-hp (320 kW), but was reported to produce {{convert|560|hp|kW|abbr=on}} and propelled a ZL1 through the 1/4 mile in 10.89 seconds.Corvette 50th Anniversary-specifications and performance-by the Editors of Consumer Guide There was an extended production run for the 1969 [[model year]] due to a lengthy labor strike, which meant sales were down on the 1970 models, to 17,316.Flory, p.734. 1970 small-block power peaked with the optional high compression, high-revving LT-1 that produced {{convert|370|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. The 427 big-block was enlarged to {{convert|454|cuin|L|abbr=on}} with a {{convert|390|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}} rating. The ZR-1 special package was an option available on the 1970 through 1972 model years, and included the LT-1 engine combined with special racing equipment. Only 53 ZR-1's were built.{{cite web|author=Auto Editors of ''Consumer Guide''|url=http://auto.howstuffworks.com/1971-corvette.htm |title=1971 Corvette |publisher=auto.howstuffworks.com |date=2007-06-07|accessdate=Sep 30, 2012}} In 1971, to accommodate regular low-lead fuel with lower anti-knock properties, the engine compression ratios were lowered which resulted in reduced power ratings. The power rating for the {{convert|350|cuin|L|abbr=on}} L48 base engine decreased from 300 to 270 horsepower and the optional special high performance LT1 engine decreased from 370 to 330 horsepower. The LS5 454 cu in (7.4 L) motor was carried over and produced 365 hp (272 kW). Offered in ‘71 only was the LS6 454 cu in (7.4 L) big-block featuring aluminum heads and delivering 425 hp (317 kW), highest of the 1970-72 series, and could be ordered with an automatic transmission. For the 1972 model year, GM moved to the [[Horsepower#SAE net power|SAE Net]] measurement which resulted in further reduced, but more realistic, power ratings than the previous SAE Gross standard.{{cite book|last=Antonick|first=Mike|title=Corvette Black, Books 1953-2007|year=2006|publisher=MotorBooks International|isbn=978-0-7603-2894-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9P-RNjfCeRYC&dq=1971+Corvette}} Although the 1972 model's {{convert|350|cuin|L|abbr=on}} horsepower was actually the same as that for the 1971 model year, the lower net horsepower numbers were used instead of gross horsepower. The L48 base engine was now rated at {{convert|200|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} and the optional LT1 engine was now rated at {{convert|270|bhp|kW|abbr=on}}. 1974 models had the last true dual exhaust system that was dropped on the 1975 models with the introduction of [[catalytic converter]]s requiring the use of no-lead fuel. Engine power decreased with the base ZQ3 engine producing {{convert|165|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}, the optional L82's output {{convert|205|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}, while the 454 big-block engine was discontinued. Gradual power increases after 1975 peaked with the 1980 model's optional L82 producing {{convert|230|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. The 1981 L82 had {{convert|190|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and the 1982 L82 had {{convert|200|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. [[File:Corvette Stingray dutch licence registration 33-YB-84 pic2.JPG|thumb|left|1974 Corvette Stingray coupe]] [[File:Corvette Tail Lights.jpg|thumb|Corvette Sting Ray tail lights.]] [[File:Corvette III.jpg|thumb|Corvette Sting Ray detail.]] Styling changed subtly throughout the generation until 1978 for the car's 25th anniversary. The Sting Ray nameplate was not used on the 1968 model, but Chevrolet still referred to the Corvette as a Sting Ray; however, the 1969 (through 1976) models used the "[[Stingray]]" name as one word, without the space.{{cite book|last=Mann|first=James |first2=Tom |last2=Falconer |title=Corvette 1968-1982|year=2010|publisher=Motorbooks |isbn=978-0-7603-3747-9|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=oTh4irEsXCgC&dq=1968+Corvette }} In 1970, the body design was updated including fender flares, and interiors were refined, which included redesigned seats, and indication lights near the gear shift that were an early use of fiber optics . Due to government regulation, the 1973 Corvette's chrome front [[bumper (automobile)|bumper]] was changed to a {{convert|5|mph|0|adj=on}}system with a [[polyurethane|urethane]] bumper cover.{{cite book|last=McNicholl|first=George A.|title=How to rebuild Corvette rolling chassis 1963-1982|year=2007|publisher=Motorbooks |isbn=978-0-7603-3014-2|page=14}} 1973 Corvettes are unique in that sense, as they are the only year where the front bumper was polyurethane and the rear retained the chrome two-piece bumper set. 1973 was also the last year chrome bumpers were used. The optional wire-spoked wheel covers (left) were offered for the last time in 1973. Only 45 Z07 were built in 1973. From 1974 onwards both the front and rear bumpers were polyurethane. In 1974, a {{convert|5|mph|0|adj=on}} rear bumper system with a two-piece, tapering urethane bumper cover replaced the [[Kammback|Kamm-tail]] and chrome bumper blades, and matched the new front design from the previous year. 1975 was the last year for the convertible, (which did not return for 11 years) and [[Dave McLellan]] succeeded [[Zora Arkus-Duntov]] as the Corvette's Chief Engineer.{{cite web|url=http://www.corvettemuseum.com/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716165801/http://www.corvettemuseum.com/ |archivedate=2011-07-16 |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine|date=July 16, 2011|accessdate=Sep 30, 2012}} For the 1976 models the fiberglass floor was replaced with steel panels to provide protection from the [[catalytic converter]]'s high [[operating temperature]]. For 15 model years the names Corvette, Sting Ray, and Stingray were synonymous. 1977 was last year the tunneled roof treatment with vertical back window was used, in addition leather seats were available at no additional cost for the first time. The black exterior color returned after a six-year absence.{{cite web|title=Library and Archives|url=http://www.corvettemuseum.com/library-archives|publisher=National Corvette Museum|accessdate=8 December 2012}} [[Image:Flickr - DVS1mn - 78 Chevrolet Corvette Pace Car.jpg|thumb|1978 Corvette [[1978 Indianapolis 500|Indy 500]] Pace Car Edition (rear)]] The 1978 25th Anniversary model introduced the [[fastback]] glass rear window and featured a new interior and dashboard. Corvette's 25th anniversary was celebrated with the Indy 500 Pace Car limited edition and a Silver Anniversary model featuring silver over gray lower body paint. All 1979 models featured the previous year's pace car seats and offered the front and rear [[Spoiler (automotive)|spoilers]] as optional equipment. 53,807 were produced for the model year, making 1979 the peak production year for all versions of the Corvette. Sales have trended downward since then.{{cite news |title=Redesign intended to re-establish Corvette's cool factor |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/sns-wp-blm-news-bc-corvette11-20130111,0,3593080,full.story |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |accessdate=13 January 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130113172756/http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/sns-wp-blm-news-bc-corvette11-20130111%2C0%2C3593080%2Cfull.story |archivedate=13 January 2013 }} In 1980, the Corvette received an integrated [[aerodynamics|aerodynamic]] redesign that resulted in a significant reduction in [[Drag (physics)|drag]]. After several years of weight increases, 1980 Corvettes were lighter as engineers trimmed both body and chassis weight. In mid-1981, production shifted from [[St. Louis, Missouri]], to [[Bowling Green, Kentucky]] (where all subsequent Corvette generations have been built since), and several two-tone paint options were offered. The 1981 models were the last available with a manual transmission until well into the 1984 production run. In 1982, a fuel-injected engine returned, and a final C3 tribute Collectors Edition featured an exclusive, opening rear window hatch. === Fourth generation (C4; 1984–1996) === {{Main|Chevrolet Corvette (C4)}} [[File:Red Chevrolet Corvette C4 With Black License-Plate Cover (Auto classique '13).JPG|thumb|left|1984 Corvette with targa top open]] [[File:Chevrolet Corvette C4.jpg|thumb|left|1988 Corvette coupe]] The fourth generation Corvette was the first complete redesign of the Corvette since 1963. Production was to begin for the 1983 model year but quality issues and part delays resulted in only 43 prototypes for the 1983 model year being produced that were never sold. All of the 1983 prototypes were destroyed or serialized to 1984 except one with a white exterior, medium blue interior, L83 350 ci, 205 bhp V8, and 4-speed automatic transmission. After extensive testing and modifications were completed, it was initially retired as a display sitting in an external wall over the Bowling Green Assembly Plant's employee entrance. Later this only surviving 1983 prototype was removed, restored and is now on public display at the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Kentucky. It is still owned by GM.{{cite book|last=Mueller|first=Mike|title=The complete book of Corvette : every model since 1953|publisher=Motorbooks |isbn=978-0760341407 |date=2012-01-23}}{{cite web|last=Connell|first=Bill|title=The Missing 1983 Corvette|url=http://www.corvetteblog.com/2007/02/corvette-museum-the-missing-1983-corvette/|publisher=Corvette Blog|accessdate=2012-11-29}} On February 12, 2014, it was nearly lost to a sinkhole which opened up under the museum. Eight other Corvettes were severely damaged.{{cite web|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20140212/NEWS01/302120036/Massive-sink-hole-swallows-eight-cars-National-Corvette-Museum|archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20141216202307/http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20140212/NEWS01/302120036/Massive-sink-hole-swallows-eight-cars-National-Corvette-Museum|url-status=dead|archive-date=2014-12-16|title=See the surveillance video {{!}} No repair timetable for National Corvette Museum sink hole|work=The Courier-Journal}} Regular fourth generation production began on January 3, 1983; the 1984 model year and delivery to customers began in March 1983. The 1984 model carried over the {{convert|350|cuin|L|abbr=on}} [[L83]] slightly more powerful (5 bhp) "Crossfire" V8 engine from the final 1982 third generation model. New chassis features were aluminum brake calipers and an all-aluminum suspension for weight savings and rigidity. The new one piece targa top had no center reinforcement. A new electronic dashboard with digital [[liquid crystal displays]] for the speedometer and tachometer was standard. Beginning in 1985, the {{convert|230|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} L98 engine with tuned port fuel injection became the standard engine. [[File:1986 Chevrolet Corvette C4 Convertible (10323231024).jpg|thumb|1986 Corvette convertible Indy 500 Pace Car Edition]] September 1984 through 1988 Corvettes offered a Doug Nash designed "4+3" transmission – a 4-speed manual coupled to an automatic overdrive on the top three gears. It was designed to help the Corvette meet U.S. fuel economy standards. Since 1981 (when it was last offered), a manual transmission returned to the Corvette starting with production in late 1984. The transmission proved to be problematic and was replaced by a modern [[ZF Friedrichshafen|ZF]] 6-speed manual transmission in 1989.{{cite book|last=Cangialosi|first=Paul|title=How to rebuild and modify high-performance manual transmissions|year=2010|publisher=CarTech |isbn=978-1934709290}} In 1986, the second Corvette Indy Pace Car was released. It was the first convertible Corvette since 1975. A Center High Mounted Signal Light (CHMSL) – a third center brake light – was added in 1986 to comply with safety regulations. While the color of the pace car used in the race was yellow, all 1986 convertibles also had an Indy 500 emblem mounted on the console, making any color a "pace car edition". In 1987, the B2K twin-turbo option became available from the factory. The [[Callaway Cars Incorporated|Callaway]] Corvette was a [[Regular Production Option]] (RPO B2K). The B2K option coexisted from 1990 to 1991 with the ZR-1 option, which then replaced it. Early B2Ks produced {{convert|345|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|450|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}};{{cite web|url=http://www.corvetteactioncenter.com/specs/callaway/87tt.html|title=1987 Twin Turbo Callaway Corvette|publisher=Corvette Action Center|accessdate=Sep 30, 2012}} later versions boasted {{convert|450|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|613|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.corvetteactioncenter.com/specs/callaway/90tt.html|title=1990 Twin Turbo Callaway Corvette|publisher=Corvette Action Center|accessdate=Sep 30, 2012}} 1988 saw the 35th Anniversary Edition of the Corvette. Each of these featured a special badge with an identification number mounted next to the gear selector, and were finished with a white exterior, wheels, and interior. In 1990, the ZR1 option Corvette was introduced with the LT5 engine designed by Lotus and built in the Mercury Marine plant in Stillwater, Oklahoma. The LT5 engine was a 4 cam (DOHC) design producing 375 hp (280 kW) when at "open throttle". The C4 ZR1 ran from 1990 thru 1995 model years. In 1991, all Corvettes received updates to the body, interior, and wheels. The convex rear fascia that set the 1990 ZR-1 apart from the base model was now included on L98 Corvettes, making the styling of the expensive ZR-1 even closer to that of the base cars. The most obvious difference remaining between the base and ZR-1 models besides the wider rear wheels was the location of the CHMSL, which was integrated into the new rear fascia used on the base model, but remained at the top of the rear-hatch on the ZR-1's. [[File:92 Corvette ZR1.jpg|thumb|left|1992 Corvette ZR-1]] For the 1992 model year, the {{convert|300|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} [[GM LT engine|LT1]] engine was introduced, an increase of {{convert|50|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} over 1991's L98 engine. This engine featured [[Reverse-flow cylinder head|reverse-flow cooling]] (the heads were cooled before the block), which allowed for a higher compression ratio of 10.5:1. A new distributor was also debuted. Called "Optispark", the distributor was driven directly off the front of the camshaft and mounted in front of the timing cover, just above the crankshaft and harmonic balancer. Also new for 1992 was Acceleration Slip Regulation (ASR), a form of traction control which utilized the Corvette's brakes, spark retard, and throttle close-down to prevent excessive rear wheel spin and possible loss of control. The traction control device could be switched off if desired. [[File:1996 Corvette Grand Sport 2.jpg|thumb|1996 Corvette Grand Sport]] A special 40th Anniversary Edition was released in 1993, which featured a commemorative Ruby Red color, 40th anniversary badges, and embroidered seat backs. The 1993 Corvette also marked the introduction of the Passive Keyless Entry System, making it the first GM car to feature it. Production of the ZR-1 ended in 1995, after 6,939 cars had been built.{{cite book|last=Newton|first=Richard|title=101 projects for your Corvette : 1984-1996|year=2003|publisher=Motorbooks International |isbn=978-0760314616}} 1996 was the final year of C4 production, and featured special models and options, including the Grand Sport and Collector Edition, OBD II (On-Board Diagnostics), run flat tires, and the [[Chevrolet small-block engine#LT4|LT4]] engine. The {{convert|330|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}} [[Chevrolet small-block engine#LT4|LT4]] V8 was available only with a manual transmission, while all {{convert|300|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}} LT1 Corvettes used automatic transmissions. Chevrolet released the Grand Sport (GS) version in 1996 to mark the end of production of the C4 Corvette. The Grand Sport moniker was a nod to the original Grand Sport model produced in 1963. A total of 1,000 GS Corvettes were produced, 810 as coupes and 190 as convertibles. The 1996 GS came with the high-performance [[Chevrolet small-block engine#LT4|LT4]] [[V8 engine]], producing {{convert|330|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|340|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}}. The Grand Sport came only in Admiral Blue with a white stripe down the middle, and black wheels and two red stripes on the front left wheel arch.{{cite book|last=Mueller|first=Mike|title=Corvette milestones|year=1996|publisher=Motorbooks International |isbn=978-0760300954}} === Fifth generation (C5; 1997–2004) === {{Main|Chevrolet Corvette (C5)}} [[File:Chevrolet-Corvette-C5.jpg|thumb|Corvette C5 coupe]] [[File:Chevrolet C5 Corvette Convertible (Les chauds vendredis '10).jpg|thumb|Corvette C5 convertible]] The C5 was the most completely redesigned Corvette since the Corvette's inception in 1953. Production of the C5 Corvette actually began in 1996 but quality/manufacturing issues saw its release to the public in mass delayed until 1997, and continuing through the 2004 model year. The C5 was a completely new design that featured many new concepts and manufacturing breakthroughs that would be carried forward to the C6 & C7. It had a top speed of {{convert|176|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and was judged by the automotive press as a breakthrough with vastly improved dynamics in nearly every area over the previous C4 design. Innovations included a 0.29 drag coefficient, near 50/50 weight distribution, active handling (the first ever stability control for a Corvette), and electronic power steering assistance. It also weighed less than the C4. An all new LS1 aluminum engine (Gen III small block) featured individual ignition coils for each cylinder, and aluminum block and pistons. It was initially rated at {{convert|345|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} and {{convert|350|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}}, but was increased to {{convert|350|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} in the 2001 edition. The new engine, combined with the new body, was able to achieve up to 28 mpg on the highway.{{cite book|last=Thurn|first=Walt|title=High-performance C5 Corvette builder's guide|year=2007|publisher=CarTech |isbn=978-1932494334}}Corvette C5, Mike Mueller, 1998All Corvettes Are Red, James Schefter, 1996Corvette C5, Patrick Paternie, 2004Road & Track Corvette Portfolio 1997-2002:(Road & Track Series), Clarke, R.M, 2003Corvette: Iconic Cars, Car & Driver, 2001Corvette Racing, David Kimble, 2012Corvette: Sports Car Superstar, Editors of Consumer Guide, 2005Corvette: Fifty Years, Randy Leffingwell, 2002, 2004{{cite web|last=Pace|first=Harold|title=The Immortal Corvette: 1997-2003|url=http://www.automedia.com/The_Immortal_Corvette_19972003/res20031201c5/1/|publisher=autoMedia.com|accessdate=30 September 2012}} [[File:Z06-Blk-7.jpg|thumb|Corvette Z06]] For its first year, the C5 was available only as a coupe, although the new platform was designed from the ground up to be a convertible, which returned in 1998, followed by the fixed-roof coupe (FRC) in 1999. One concept for the FRC was for it to be a stripped-down model with a possible V6 engine (nicknamed in-house as the "Billy Bob").{{cite book|last=Newton|first=Richard|title=Corvette C5 performance projects|year=2006|publisher=MBI Pub. |isbn=978-0760320815|page=8}} By 2000, FRC plans laid the groundwork for the return in 2001 of the Z06, an RPO option not seen since Zora's 1963 race-ready Corvette.Schefter, pp. 96, 105, 108. The Z06 model replaced the FRC model as the highest performance C5 Corvette. Instead of a heavier double-overhead cam engine like the ZR-1 of the C4 generation, the Z06 used an LS6, a {{convert|385|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} derivative of the standard LS1 engine. Using the much more rigid fixed roof design allowed the Z06 unprecedented handling thanks to upgraded brakes and less body flex.{{cite book|last=Mueller|first=Mike|title=Essential musclecars|year=2004|publisher=Motorbooks International|location=St. Paul, MN|isbn=978-0760319666}} Those characteristics, along with the use of materials such as a titanium exhaust system and a carbon fiber hood in the 2004 model year, led to further weight savings and performance gains for the C5 Z06. The LS6 was later upgraded to {{convert|405|bhp|kW|abbr=on}}for 2002–2004. Although the Z06's rated power output equal to that of the C4 ZR-1, the improved rigidity, suspension, brakes, and reduced weight of the C5 produced a car quicker than C4 ZR-1.{{cite book|last=Endres|first=Christopher P.|title=Chevy LS1/LS6 performance : high performance modifications for street and racing : covers Chevy LS1 and LS6 engines, 1997 and up |year=1996 |publisher=HP Books|location=New York |isbn=978-1557884077|edition=1st}} === Sixth generation (C6; 2005–2013) === {{Main|Chevrolet Corvette (C6)}} [[File:Chevrolet Corvette Coupé Luxury (C6) – Frontansicht, 16. April 2011, Düsseldorf.jpg|thumb|Corvette C6 coupe]] [[File:Yellow Corvette (8028247140).jpg|thumb|Corvette C6]] For the C6 Corvette GM wanted to focus more upon refining the C5 than trying to redesign it.{{cite magazine |title=Corvette: Sports Car Superstar |author=Editors of Consumer Guide |year=2005}} However, this did not prevent GM from trying to sell the C6 as being "all new". The public immediately saw through the marketing ploy and GM's use of "simply changing the part numbers" despite a large number of the parts being interchangeable between the C5 & C6. Car & Driver, along with Motor Trend, quickly noticed the inaccuracy, noting that the C6 was more an "evolution of the C5, instead of a complete redo". This even led C&D to term the C6 as the "C5 and 11/16ths". To highlight the new generation, Chevrolet gave the C6 a face lift; reducing the exterior body overhangs for a noticeably overall reduction in outward dimension. The front headlights were also redone, deleting the traditional "pop-up" headlights, opting for a more modern look. Beyond that, the majority of the changes focused on improving the quality of the interior. The C6 has a slightly longer wheelbase than the C5, a change necessitated by the use of a different automatic transmission which resulted in the rear linkage points being relocated; thus presenting a "longer" wheelbase. The C6 brought a new and improved interior compared to the C5. As a result of the upgraded interior, the C6 had an slight increase in passenger hip room. It also sported an updated LS1/LS6 engine now called the LS2. This engine was primarily an LS1/LS6 with a bump in displacement from 5.7L to 6.0 liters. The increased displacement of the 6.0 bumped the LS2's horsepower up by 50 BHP over its LS1 progenitor, although still 5 BHP less than the upgraded LS6 engine found in the previous C5 Z06. Thus the LS2 was now at 364 cu in, and it produced {{convert|400|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} at 6000 rpm and {{convert|400|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} at 4400 rpm, giving the vehicle a 0–60 mph time of under 4.2 seconds.{{cite book|last=Berg|first=Phil|title=Corvette C6|year=2004|publisher=Motorbooks International|location=St. Paul, MN|isbn=978-0760318652}} Its top speed was {{convert|190|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. The C6 generation did not match the previous generation's relatively good [[fuel economy in automobiles|fuel economy]], despite its relatively low 0.28 [[drag coefficient]] and low curb weight, achieving 16/26 mpg (city/highway) equipped with automatic or manual transmissions; like all manual transmission Corvettes since 1989, it is fitted with Computer Aided Gear Selection (CAGS) to improve fuel economy by requiring drivers to shift from 1st gear directly to 4th in low-speed/low-throttle conditions. This feature helps the C6 avoid the [[Gas Guzzler Tax]] by achieving better fuel economy.{{cite web |url=http://www.web-cars.com/corvette/1989.php |title=The Corvette Story |accessdate=Sep 30, 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120918144316/http://www.web-cars.com/corvette/1989.php |archivedate=2012-09-18 }} The new Z06 arrived as a 2006 model in the third quarter of 2005. It has a 7.0 L version of the [[small block]] engine codenamed ''[[GM LS engine#LS7|LS7]]''. At 427.6 cubic inches, the Z06 was the largest small block ever offered from General Motors. Because of the Corvette's former use of 427 cubic-inch big blocks in the late-1960s and early 1970s, the LS7's size was rounded down to 427 cubic inches. Official output was {{convert|505|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and has a 0-{{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} time of 3.7 seconds. Top speed is {{convert|198|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.insideline.com/chevrolet/corvette/2006/first-drive-2006-chevrolet-corvette-z06.html|title=First Drive: 2006 Chevrolet Corvette Z06|publisher=Insideline.com|date=August 31, 2005|accessdate=Sep 30, 2012}} Another first for a Corvette, the Z06 featured a full aluminum chasis. The frame mirrored the C5/6 architecture but substituting aluminum hydroformed rails and aluminum extrustions and castings fore and aft. This dropped weight from 419 to 287 pounds while improving chassis stiffness.{{Cite magazine|url=http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/2006-chevrolet-corvette-z06-first-drive-review-how-light-can-it-get-page-3|title=2006 Chevrolet Corvette Z06 - First Drive Review|access-date=2017-07-08|magazine=Car and Driver}} [[File:Corvette ZR1 avant.JPG|thumb|left|Corvette ZR1]] For 2008, the Corvette received a mild freshening: a new [[GM LS engine|LS3]] engine with displacement increased to {{convert|6.2|L|cuin|abbr=on}}, resulting in {{convert|430|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|424|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} ({{convert|436|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}} and {{convert|428|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}} if ordered with the optional performance exhaust). The 6-speed manual transmission also has improved shift linkage and a 0–60 time of 4.0 seconds, while the automatic is set up for quicker shifts giving the C6 automatic a 0–60 time of 4.0 seconds, quicker than any other production automatic Corvette. The interior was slightly updated and a new 4LT leather-wrap interior package was added. The wheels were also updated to a new five-spoke design.{{cite web|url=http://www.edmunds.com/chevrolet/corvette/2008/road-test.html |title=First Drive: 2008 Chevrolet Corvette |publisher=Edmunds.com |date=Apr 27, 2007 |accessdate=Nov 22, 2008 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120818232707/http://www.edmunds.com/chevrolet/corvette/2008/road-test.html |archivedate=August 18, 2012 }} [[File:2010 Corvette Grand Sport at Dream Racing in Las Vegas.jpg|thumb|left|2010 Corvette Grand Sport]] The ZR1 was formally announced in a December 2007 press statement by General Motors, where it was revealed that their target of {{convert|100|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} per {{convert|1|L|cuin|abbr=on}} had been reached by a new "LS9" engine with an Eaton-[[supercharged]] 6.2-liter engine producing {{convert|638|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} and {{convert|604|lbft|Nm|abbr=on}}. The LS9 engine was the most powerful to be put into a GM production sports car.{{cite journal|url=http://blog.wired.com/cars/2008/04/the-numbers-are.html |title=The Numbers Are In: Corvette ZR1 Cranks Out 638 HP |journal=Wired |author=Marty Jerome |date=Apr 25, 2008|accessdate=Sep 30, 2012}} Its top speed was {{convert|205|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|url=http://jalopnik.com/383974/2009-corvette-zr1-power-numbers-finalized-ls9-v8-hits-638-hp|title=2009 Corvette ZR1 Power Numbers Finalized: LS9 V8 Hits 638 HP!}} The historical name ''Grand Sport'' returned to the Corvette lineup in 2010 as an entirely new model series that replaced the Z51 option. The new model was basically an LS3 equipped Z06 with a steel frame instead of aluminum. It retained many of the features of the Z06 including a wide body with 18x9.5 and 19x12 inch wheels, dry sump oiling (manual transmission coupes only), 6-piston 14" front brakes and 4-piston rear, and improved suspension. Manual power train equipped G/S coupe models receive a tweaked LS3 with a forged crank, are built in Z06 fashion by hand, and utilize a dry-sump oil system. The first three gears were also made shorter for better throttle response and faster acceleration.{{cite web|url=http://www.edmunds.com/chevrolet/corvette/2010/road-test-2/|title=2010 Chevrolet Corvette Grand Sport First Drive|publisher=}} A new launch control system was introduced for all models that allows for sub-4-second 0–60. EPA is estimated 26 MPG highway, 1.0 G on skid pad. Beginning with the 2011 model year, buyers of the Corvette Z06 and ZR1 were offered the opportunity to assist in the build of their engine. Titled the "Corvette Engine Build Experience," buyers paid extra to be flown to the Wixom, Michigan Performance Build Center.{{cite book|last=Earnest|first=Brian|title=Corvette the great American sports car|year=2010|publisher=Krause Publications|location=Iola, WI|isbn=978-1440217531}} Participants helped the assembly line workers build the V8 engine, then took delivery of the car at the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, KY, near the Corvette final assembly point.{{cite web|url=http://www.automoblog.net/2010/07/13/2011-chevy-corvette-engines-can-be-built-by-owner/|title=2011 Chevy Corvette Engines Can be Built by Owner|publisher=Automoblog.net|accessdate=Sep 30, 2012|date=2010-07-13}} The last C6 Corvette was manufactured in February 2013.{{cite web|url= http://forums.corvetteforum.com/c6-corvette-general-discussion/3015415-end-of-the-c6-1q-2013-a.html |title=End of the C6 1Q 2013 – Corvette Forum |publisher=Forums.corvetteforum.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-25}}{{cite magazine|url=http://www.autoweek.com/article/20121018/videonews/121019825|title=Last 2013 c6 vette 2/2013 and 1st C7 August/September 2012|magazine=Autoweek|accessdate=Dec 11, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029194430/http://www.autoweek.com/article/20121018/videonews/121019825|archive-date=October 29, 2013|url-status=dead}} In May 2013, a federal investigation of problems with more than 100,000 C6 lighting systems was announced.{{cite web|title=C6 Corvette Under Investigation over Faulty Headlamps|url=http://www.autoevolution.com/news/c6-corvette-under-investigation-over-faulty-headlamps-59280.html|publisher=Autoevolution|last=Florea|first=Ciprian|date=May 10, 2013|accessdate=February 18, 2015}} {{-}} === Seventh generation (C7; 2014–2019) === {{Main|Chevrolet Corvette (C7)}} [[File:2014 Chevy Corvette Stingray in yellow at LA Auto Show.jpg|thumb|2014 Corvette Stingray coupe]] [[File:2013-03-05 Geneva Motor Show 7858.JPG|thumb|2014 Corvette Stingray convertible]] [[File:2017 Corvette Collector Edition Number 45 Aerial Top.jpg|alt=2017 Corvette Grand Sport Collector Edition #43|thumb|[[2017 Chevrolet Corvette Grand Sport Collector Edition|2017 Corvette Grand Sport Collector Edition]] #43]] [[File:2017 Chevrolet Corvette Grand Sport Collector Edition Dash Plaque.jpg|alt=2017 Corvette Grand Sport Collector Edition Dash Plaque|thumb|[[2017 Chevrolet Corvette Grand Sport Collector Edition|2017 Corvette Grand Sport Collector Edition]] Dash Plaque]] [[File:Corvette ZR1 1Y7A6157.jpg|thumb|Corvette ZR1]] Development for the seventh generation Corvette started in 2007. Originally set to be introduced for the 2011 model year, its introduction was delayed for three years. It was finally released for the 2014 model year.{{cite journal |url=http://www.automobilemag.com/features/news/1201_2014_chevrolet_c7_corvette_spied/index.html |title=Spied: 2014 Chevrolet C7 Corvette |journal=Automobile Magazine |date=January 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222025544/http://www.automobilemag.com/features/news/1201_2014_chevrolet_c7_corvette_spied/index.html |archivedate=2012-02-22 }} [[Mid-engine]] and [[rear-engine design|rear-engine]] layouts had been considered, but the [[front-engine]], rear-wheel drive [[rear-wheel drive|(RWD)]] platform was chosen to keep production costs lower.{{cite news |url=http://www.motortrend.com/features/auto_news/2008/112_0812_c7_chevrolet_corvette_update/ |title=No Mid-Engine For Chevrolet Corvette C7 |first=Mike |last=Connor|journal=Motor Trend|date=December 2008|accessdate=Sep 30, 2012}} To GM's product planners and marketers, the fact that the Corvette had become known as an "old man's toy" became a prime factor in developing the next generation. Studies showed that about 46 percent of Corvette buyers in 2012, through October, were 55 or older, compared with 22 percent of [[Audi R8]] and 30 percent of [[Porsche 911]] customers. The head of Chevy marketing, Chris Perry, acknowledges that too many people saw it as the car of "the successful plumber." John Fitzpatrick, Corvette's marketing manager said "It's the old saying, 'Nobody wants to be seen driving an old man's car, but everybody wants to be seen driving a young man's car.' " To counter that perception GM planned to make the new generation C7 more aspirational to younger people. Towards that end, a camouflaged version of the car was made available in the popular video game ''[[Gran Turismo 5]]'' in November 2012.{{cite news|last=Higgins |first=Tim |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-01-11/corvette-not-just-for-successful-plumbers-with-new-design.html |title=Corvette Not Just for Successful Plumbers With New Design |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2013-01-11 |accessdate=2013-01-25}} As part of the marketing effort associated with the introduction of the new generation, the 2013 Indianapolis 500 utilized a Corvette for the 12th time as its pace car. Sales success of the new Corvette is important to GM. [[The Motley Fool]] reports that Chevrolet could be earning $10,000 or more in gross profit for every Corvette it sells.{{cite web|url=http://www.fool.com/investing/general/2013/11/09/the-2014-corvette-stingray-steps-on-the-gas.aspx|title=The 2014 Corvette Stingray Steps on the Gas|publisher=Motley Fool|date=2013-11-09|accessdate=2013-11-18|author=Adam Levine-Weinberg}} GM's profit on sales is separate from the profits made by the individual dealerships selling the cars to the public. The 2014 Chevrolet Corvette uses an LT1 6.2 L V8 (376 cu in) making {{convert|455|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} or {{convert|460|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} with the optional performance exhaust. The LT1 engine (the "LT1" designation was first used by GM in 1970 and then later in 1992.) is in the Gen V family of [[GM LT engine|small block]] engines, which will be used in GM vehicles as the new small V8 option. It features three advanced technologies to the new LT1 V8 engine: direct injection, variable valve timing, and an active fuel management system.{{Cite web | url=https://media.chevrolet.com/media/us/en/chevrolet/news.detail.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2012/Oct/1024_GenVSmallBlock.html |title = All-New 2014 Corvette LT1 V-8 a Technological Powerhouse|date = 2012-10-24}} Fuel injectors are located under the intake manifold. The Corvette remains rear-wheel drive with the transaxle located in the rear. Transmission choices include a 7-speed manual or a 6-speed (2014) / 8-speed (2015-) automatic with paddle shifters. The new interior includes wide-bottom seats as standard, with sportier versions with high side bolsters optional. The Corvette's flag logo has been revised for the new car and a small casting of a stingray has been added to the car's ornamentation. Features of the new generation's structure include a carbon fiber hood and removable roof panel. The fenders, doors and rear quarter panels remain composite. At the rear of the car, the trademark round taillights have changed to a more squarish form. The underbody panels are made of "carbon-nano" composite and it makes use of a new aluminum frame which locates the four wheels an inch farther apart, front to rear and side to side. Luggage space decreased by 33% from the previous generation's.{{cite news |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/classified/automotive/new/sns-mct-bc-auto-chevroletstingray-review-20131101,0,5604602.story |title=2014 Chevrolet StingRay Review |accessdate=2013-11-10 |work=Chicago Tribune |first=Mark |last=Phelan |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110050247/http://www.chicagotribune.com/classified/automotive/new/sns-mct-bc-auto-chevroletstingray-review-20131101%2C0%2C5604602.story |archivedate=2013-11-10 }} The overall weight of the car was not announced by General Motors for many months after its first showing in January 2013. Despite the increased use of aluminum and other light weight materials, numerous publications reported that the weight would remain essentially unchanged from that of the previous generation's.{{cite book|title=Corvette C7|publisher=Road & Track Magazine|first=Lawrence |last=Ulrich|page=47|date=February–March 2013}}{{cite web|last=Paukert |first=Chris |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2013/01/13/2014-chevrolet-corvette-c7-stingray-everything-there-is-to-know/ |title=2014 Chevrolet Corvette C7 Stingray, everything there is to know |publisher=Autoblog |date=2013-01-13 |accessdate=2013-03-29}}{{cite news |last=Krisher |first=Tom |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/13/c7-corvette-2014-stingray-chevy-gm_n_2469437.html/ |title=C7 Corvette, 2014 Model, Bursts Onto The Road After 9 Years |work=Huffington Post |date=2013-01-13 |accessdate=2013-03-29 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117034241/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/13/c7-corvette-2014-stingray-chevy-gm_n_2469437.html |archivedate=2013-01-17 }} In August, 2013, the weight of the new Corvette was reported to be {{convert|3444|lb|kg|abbr=on}},{{cite book|title=2014 Corvette|publisher=Road & Track Magazine|first=Larry |last=Webster|page=44|date=September 2013}} meaning it would weigh more than the previous generation's C6 ZR1 model ({{convert|3324|lb|kg|abbr=on}}). The ZR1 C6 weight included a supercharger and intercooler on its 6.2L engine.{{cite web|url=http://www.chevrolet.com/corvette-zr1-sports-car/ |title=2012 Chevrolet Corvette ZR1 |publisher=Chevrolet |date= |accessdate=2011-12-01}} Chevrolet announced the C7 Z06 at the 2014 Detroit Auto Show. The 2015 Z06 Corvette has 650 bhp from the supercharged LT4 aluminum 6.2L V-8 engine.{{cite news |last1=Undercoffler |first1=David |title=Detroit Auto Show: Corvette Z06 debuts with 600-plus horsepower |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-hy-detroit-auto-show-corvette-20140113,0,1175087.story#axzz2qkvC2rdw |work=Los Angeles Times |date=January 13, 2014}}{{cite web |title=2015 CORVETTE Z06 Supercar |url=http://www.chevrolet.com/2015-corvette-stingray-z06-supercar.html |website=Chevrolet |accessdate=February 2, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140220081811/http://www.chevrolet.com/2015-corvette-stingray-z06-supercar.html |archivedate=February 20, 2014}} The new generation Corvette resurrected the "Stingray" name (originally spelled "Sting Ray" on 1963 to 1967 models and "Stingray" from 1969 to 1976), last used in 1976.{{cite web|url=http://media.gm.com/media/us/en/gm/news.detail.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2012/Oct/1018_CorvetteCrossedFlag.html|title=Next-generation Corvette to Debut 1.13.13 in Detroit|work=media.gm.com|date=2012-10-18}} For the 2015 model, Chevrolet began offering a transaxle version of the [[GM 8L90 transmission|8L90]] 8-speed automatic to replace the previous 6-speed 6L80.{{cite web|last1=Colwell|first1=K.C.|title=2015 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray Eight-Speed Automatic|url=http://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/2015-chevrolet-corvette-eight-speed-automatic-first-drive-review|website=Car and Driver|accessdate=18 June 2015|date=2014-08-21}}{{cite web|title=New 8-Speed Enables Quicker, More Efficient Corvette |url=http://www.gm.com/article.content_pages_news_us_en_2014_aug_0820-8speed_0820-corvette-8-speed-lead.html |website=www.gm.com |publisher=General Motors |accessdate=21 August 2014 |date=20 August 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141222140302/http://www.gm.com/article.content_pages_news_us_en_2014_aug_0820-8speed_0820-corvette-8-speed-lead.html |archivedate=22 December 2014 }} For the 2017 model year Chevrolet once again introduced the Grand Sport (GS) model.{{Cite news|url=http://media.chevrolet.com/media/us/en/chevrolet/home.detail.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2016/apr/0429-corvette-gs.html|title=2017 Corvette Grand Sport Priced at $66,445|work=media.gm.com|access-date=2017-06-06}} This model includes Z06 wide body styling features and suspension tuning along with the Z51 dry sump LT1 engine configuration. Grand Sport models were available in 10 exterior colors and could have the optional Heritage Package which included hash-mark fender graphics (available in six colors. As part of the introduction of the Grand Sport in Geneva, Switzerland, Chevrolet also announced a [[2017 Chevrolet Corvette Grand Sport Collector Edition|Grand Sport Collector Edition]], which was to be limited to 1,000 vehicles in total and only 850 for the US Market. Final production numbers show 784 Coupes and 151 Convertibles were built; 935 total.{{Cite web|url=http://www.corvettemuseum.org/2017-final-corvette-stats/|title=2017 Final Corvette Stats – National Corvette Museum|website=www.corvettemuseum.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-10}} The $4,995 Z25 Option Package was a cosmetic upgrade that contained the following: blue fender hash-marks, two-tone blue leather seating surfaces with a logo on the seat headrest, blue leather stitching, serialized edition numbered dash plaque and carpeted floor mats with logo, For the 2019 model year the ZR1 variant returned. This model features a new LT5 engine. The long block of the LT5 is the same as the LT4, but the supercharger displacement was increased from 1.7 liters to 2.65 liters. The C7 ZR1 power output is 755 horsepower. The last C7 Corvette (also making it the last front-engined Corvette), a black Z06, was auctioned off on June 28, 2019 for $2.7 million{{Cite web|url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a27113416/final-chevrolet-c7-corvette-auction/|title=The Last Front-Engined Chevrolet Corvette, a 2019 C7 Z06, Will Be Auctioned Off in June|work=[[Car and Driver]]|last=Golson|first=Daniel|date=28 June 2019|accessdate=8 July 2019}} at the [[Barrett-Jackson]] Northeast auction. The auction benefited the Stephen Siller Tunnel to Towers Foundation, which helps pay off mortgages for the families of first responders that were killed in the line of duty and builds "mortgage-free, accessible smart homes" for injured service members.{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N11U184FPns2019 |title=NORTHEAST AUCTION CHARITY CAR: Lot #3001 - 2019 CHEVROLET CORVETTE Z06 - LAST BUILT|date=29 June 2019|accessdate= 6 July 2019}} ===Eighth generation (C8; 2020–)=== {{Main|Chevrolet Corvette (C8)}} [[File:Chevrolet Corvette C8 Stingray blue.jpg|thumb|Chevrolet Corvette C8]] The 2020 Corvette model, both coupe and convertible configurations of the base-model Stingray made their debut within a 3-month gap. The coupe made its debut on July 18 with three launch colors, red (with the Z51 Package), white, and blue while the convertible made its debut on October 2 at the [[Kennedy Space Center]] along with the [[Chevrolet Corvette C8.R|C8.R]] race car, which will take part at the 2020 Daytona 24 Hours. The coupe and convertible are powered by a 6.2 liter naturally aspirated V8 called the LT2, this engine generates 495 horsepower and 470 lb/ft of torque when equipped with the Z51 performance package. The Corvette C8 convertible is the first Corvette with a retractable hardtop.{{Cite web|url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a27116013/chevrolet-corvette-c8-mid-engine-confirmed-2020/|title=The Mid-Engined 2020 Chevrolet Corvette C8 Is Real, GM Confesses, and It Will Debut July 18|work=[[Car and Driver]]|last=Capparella|first=Joey|date=11 April 2019|accessdate=11 April 2019}} The Corvette C8 is the first production Corvette to have a mid-engine configuration.American Icon, goes Mid-engine, and 0-60 in under three seconds — https://media.chevrolet.com/media/us/en/chevrolet/home.detail.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2019/jul/0718-corvette.html It is also GM's first mid-engine production car since the 1984 [[Pontiac Fiero]]. In January 2020 the car became the most expensive vehicle sold at the Barrett-Jackson auction, selling for $3 million. The proceeds of the sale went to the Detroit Children's Fund.{{Cite web|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/scottsdale/2020/01/18/barrett-jackson-corvette-charity-car-goes-3-million-auction/4515079002/|title=Barrett-Jackson: Corvette charity car goes for $3 million at auction|website=azcentral|language=en|access-date=2020-01-19}} {{clear}} == Awards == Over the years, the Corvette has won awards from automobile publications as well as organizations such as the [[Society of Automotive Engineers]]. * ''[[Automobile Magazine]]'' ranked the 1963–1967 Sting Ray first on their "100 Coolest Cars" list, above the [[Dodge Viper]] GTS, the [[Porsche 911]], and others.{{cite web |url=http://www.automobilemag.com/features/0410_coolest_cars/index.html |title=Features: 100 Coolest Cars |work=Automobile Magazine |page=3 |accessdate=Sep 30, 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205065435/http://www.automobilemag.com/features/0410_coolest_cars/index.html |archivedate=2012-02-05 |date=2004-10-07 }} In 2013, ''Automobile Magazine'' had selected the Corvette C7 as its "Automobile of the Year".{{cite web |last1=Valdes-Depna |first1=Peter |title=Corvette named Automobile of the Year |url=http://money.cnn.com/2013/11/16/autos/corvette-automobile-magazine-car-of-the-year/ |date=November 16, 2013|website=CNN Money}} * ''[[Sports Car International]]'' placed the Corvette at number 5 on their list of the "Top Sports Cars of the 1960s". * ''[[Hot Rod (magazine)|Hot Rod]]'' magazine in its March 1986 issue selected the 1973–74 Corvette LS6 454 as one of the "10 most collectable muscle cars" in the company of the 1968–70 [[Chevrolet Chevelle|Chevelle]], 1970 [[Plymouth Barracuda|'Cuda]], 1970 [[Dodge Challenger|Challenger]], 1966–67 [[Ford Fairlane (Americas)|Fairlane]], 1968–70 [[AMC AMX|AMX]], 1970 [[Chevrolet Camaro|Camaro Z28]], 1968–70 [[Pontiac GTO|GTO]], 1968–69 [[Dodge Charger|Charger]], and 1967–68 [[Ford Mustang|Mustang]].{{cite book | title=Hot Rod | publisher=Hot Rod | year=1986}} * ''[[Car and Driver]]'' readers selected the Corvette "Best all around car" nine out of eleven years in Car and Driver's Reader's Choice Polls including 1971, 1972, 1973, 1974, and 1975. * ''Car and Driver'' magazine selected the Corvette for its annual [[Car and Driver Ten Best|Ten Best]] list sixteen times: the C4 from 1985 through 1989, the C5 in 1998, 1999, and 2002 through 2004, the C6 from 2005 through 2009, and the C7 in 2014. * ''[[Motor Trend]]'' magazine named the Corvette [[Car of the Year]] in 1984, 1998 and 2020. * ''[[Society of Automotive Engineers]]'' publication ''Automotive Engineering International'' selected the 1999 Corvette Convertible, (along with the Mercedes-Benz S500) "Best Engineered Car of the 20th century".{{cite web|url=http://www.sae.org/automag/bestcar/10.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20000408214701/http://www.sae.org/automag/bestcar/10.htm|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 8, 2000|title=Best Engineered Car of the 20th century|publisher=Sae.org|accessdate=Sep 30, 2012}} * The 2005 Corvette was nominated for the [[North American Car of the Year]] award and was named "Most Coveted Vehicle" in the 2006 [[Canadian Car of the Year]] contest. * ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]''{{cite web|url=http://usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/cars-trucks/best-cars-for-the-money/ |title=Best Cars for the Money 2010 |accessdate=Sep 30, 2012 |date=Dec 11, 2009 |last=Deaton |first=Jamie Page |work=U.S. News & World Report |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090312045445/http://usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/cars-trucks/Best-Cars-for-the-Money/ |archivedate=2009-03-12 }} selected the 2010 Corvette the "Best Luxury Sports Car for the Money". * ''[[Edmunds.com]]'', in its "100 Best Cars Of All Time" list, ranked the 1963 Corvette Stingray as the 16th best car ever produced worldwide. The 1990 ZR1 took #50, the 1955 Corvette V8 took #72, and the 2009 ZR1 took #78 overall. * The 2014 Corvette was nominated for the [[North American Car of the Year]] award == NASA Corvettes == [[File:SaturnVcenterVette.JPG|thumb|Astronaut [[Alan Shepard]]'s Corvette on display at the [[Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex]]]] Astronaut [[Alan Shepard]], a long-time Corvette owner, was invited by then GM Chief Engineer [[Zora Arkus-Duntov]] to drive pre-production Corvette models. General Motors executives later gave Shepard a 1972 model with a Bill Mitchell interior. [[Jim Rathmann]], a [[Melbourne, Florida]] Chevrolet dealer and winner of the 1960 Indy 500, befriended astronauts Shepard, [[Gus Grissom]], and [[Gordon Cooper]]. Rathmann convinced GM President [[Ed Cole]] to set up a program which supplied each astronaut with a pair of new cars each year. Most chose a family car for their wives and a Corvette for themselves.{{Cite web | last=Bean | first=Alan | url=http://www.alanbean.com/astronaut_training.cfm | title=Training}} In his memoir ''Last Man On The Moon'', [[Gene Cernan]] describes how this worked. The astronauts received brand-new Corvettes, which they were given the option to purchase at a "used" price after they'd been driven 3000 miles. [[Alan Bean]] recalls Corvettes lined up in the parking lot outside the astronaut offices at the [[Johnson Space Center]] in Houston, and friendly races between Shepard and Grissom along the Florida beach roads and on beaches as local police turned a blind eye.{{Cite journal | last= Nelson | first=John | title=The AstroVette an astronaut's Corvette from the beginning of the Space Age | journal=Vette | date=June 2009 | url=http://www.vetteweb.com/features/vet1101_1969_chevrolet_astrovette_stingray/index.html}} Shepard, Grissom and Cooper even pulled each other on skis in the shallow water. The Mercury and later astronauts were unofficially tied to the Corvette and appeared in official photographs with their cars and with mock-ups of space vehicles such as the [[Apollo Lunar Module]] or [[Lunar Roving Vehicle]]. Cooper talked of the races along Cocoa Beach in his eulogy of Shepard at the Johnson Space Center in 1998.{{Cite book | last=French | first=Francis | title=Into That Silent Sea: Trailblazers of the Space Era, 1961–1965 | year=2009 | publisher=Bison Books | isbn=978-0-8032-2639-5 | page=261 | first2=Colin | last2=Burgess | first3=Paul | last3=Haney}} == Concept cars == Corvette [[concept car]]s have inspired the designs of several generations of Corvettes.{{cite book|author=auto editors of ''Consumer Guide'' |title=Corvette: 50th anniversary|year=2003|publisher=Publications International |isbn=978-0785379874}} The first Corvette, [[Harley Earl]]'s 1953 EX-122 [[Chevrolet Corvette C1#Origin 1951|Corvette prototype]] was itself, a concept show car, first shown to the public at the 1953 GM [[Motorama]] at the [[Waldorf-Astoria Hotel]] in New York City on January 17, 1953. It was brought to production in six months with only minor changes. [[File:1966 Chevrolet Ad-Mako shark II.jpg|thumb|[[Corvette Mako Shark (concept car)|Mako Shark]] II advertisement (1966)]] Harley Earl's successor, [[Bill Mitchell (designer)|Bill Mitchell]] was the man behind most of the Corvette concepts of the 1960s and 1970s. The second-generation (C2) of 1963 was his, and its design first appeared on the [[Corvette Stingray (concept car)|Stingray Racer]] of 1959. It made its public debut at Maryland's Marlborough Raceway on April 18, 1959, powered by a {{convert|283|cuin|L|abbr=on}} V8 with experimental 11:1 compression aluminum cylinder heads and took fourth place. It raced through 1960 wearing only "Sting Ray" badges before retiring to tour the auto-show circuit in 1961.{{cite book|first=Randy |last=Leffingwell |title=Corvette: fifty years|publisher=MBI |year=2002 |isbn=9780760311806 }} In 1961 the XP-755 [[Corvette Mako Shark (concept car)|Mako Shark]] show car was designed by Larry Shinoda as a concept for future Corvettes. In keeping with the name, the streamlining, pointed snout, and other detailing was partly inspired by the look of that very [[Mako shark|fast fish]]. The 1961 Corvette tail was given two additional tail lights (six total) for the concept car. The body inspired the 1963 production Sting Ray.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} In 1965 Mitchell removed the original concept body and redesigned it as the Mako Shark II. Chevrolet actually created two of them, only one of which was fully functional. The original Mako Shark was then retroactively called the Mako Shark I. The Mako Shark II debuted in 1965 as a show car and this concept influenced Mitchell's redesigned Corvette of 1968.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} The [[Chevrolet Aerovette|Aerovette]] has a [[mid-engine]] configuration using a [[Transverse engine|transverse]] mounting of its V-8 engine. [[Zora Arkus-Duntov]]'s engineers originally built two XP-882s during 1969. [[John DeLorean]], Chevy general manager, ordered one for display at the 1970 [[New York Auto Show]]. In 1972, DeLorean authorized further work on the XP-882. A near-identical body in [[aluminum alloy]] was constructed and became the XP-895 "Reynolds Aluminum Car." Duntov and Mitchell responded with two [[Chevrolet Vega]] (stillborn) [[Wankel engine|Wankel]] 2-rotor engines joined together as a 4-rotor {{convert|420|hp|kW|abbr=on}} engine which was used to power the XP-895. It was first shown in late 1973. The 4-rotor show car was outfitted with a {{convert|400|cuin|L|abbr=on}} small-block V8 in 1977 and rechristened Aerovette. GM chairman [[Thomas Murphy (chairman)|Thomas Murphy]] approved the Aerovette for 1980 production, but Mitchell's retirement that year, combined with then Corvette chief engineer [[Dave McLellan]]'s lack of enthusiasm for the mid-engine design and slow-selling data on mid-engined cars killed the last hope for a mid-engine Corvette.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} A [[Corvette Stingray (concept car)#2009 Stingray Concept|Corvette Stingray Anniversary]] concept car was unveiled at the 2009 [[Detroit Auto Show]], fifty years after the Sting Ray racer-concept of 1959.{{cite book|title=Friends magazine-published by Chevrolet for Corvette owners|publisher=Chevrolet}} The vehicle was based on a combination of the 1963 Sting Ray and the 1968 Stingray. The new Stingray concept appears in the 2009 movie ''[[Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen]]'', as the vehicle mode of the character Sideswipe.{{cite web|url=http://jalopnik.com/5151143/corvette-stingray-concept-sideswipe-in-disguise |title=Corvette Stingray Concept: Sideswipe In Disguise |publisher=Jalopnik.com |date=Feb 11, 2009|accessdate=Sep 30, 2012}} A convertible/speedster version was used for the same character in the 2011 sequel, ''[[Transformers: Dark of the Moon]]''.{{cite web|url=http://jalopnik.com/5802217/transformers-dark-of-the-moon-sideswipe-bumblebee-first-look |title=Transformers "Dark of the Moon" Sideswipe, Bumblebee: First Look |publisher=Jalopnik.com |date=May 16, 2011|accessdate=Nov 14, 2012}} File:1959 Corvette Stingray Concept.jpg|1959 Corvette XP-87 Stingray Racer concept File:GM Heritage Center - 089 - Corvette - Stingray Race & Production.jpg|The XP-87 with a 1963 model and designer [[Bill Mitchell (automobile designer)|Bill Mitchell]] File:1961_Mako_Shark_Concept.jpg|1961 Mako Shark concept File:65 Mako Shark.jpg|1965 Mako Shark II concept File:1977 Aero-Vette.jpg|1977 Aerovette concept File:Chevrolet Corvette Concept - CIAS 2012 (6950737373).jpg|2009 Corvette Stingray concept == Production == Production statistics from when the first generation of Corvettes were released in 1953 until present. {|class=wikitable |- ! introduced along with the second-generation [[Chevrolet Camaro]] on Feb. 26, 1970, new egg-grate metal front grills and fender grills, lower molded fender flares, new hi-back seats and interior trim, new custom interior option includes: leather seat trim, cut-pile carpeting, lower-carpeted door panels and wood-grain accents. |- align=right |1971||21,801||align=left|Significant power drops due to reduced compression ratios to meet GM corporate edict requiring all engines to run low-octane unleaded gasoline; power ratings based on both "gross" and "net" figures with the former based on engine hooked to dynometer while "net" ratings based on power as installed in vehicle with accessories and emission controls installed. |- align=right |1972||27,004||align=left|Power ratings now advertised in SAE net figures, last year for LT-1 engine, front and rear chrome bumpers, removable rear window, and windshield wiper door. |- align=right |1973||30,464||align=left|{{convert|5|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} front bumper system with urethane cover, pot-metal front grills (black with silver edges), chrome rear bumpers unchanged, new design front fender ducts, first year for radial tires (standard equipment), rubber body mounts, new hood with rear air induction and under-hood insulation, new front-end (round) emblem. cross-flag gas-lid emblem deleted towards the end of the model year. No gas lid emblem was used. Aluminum front grills (all-black), dual exhaust resonators added, revised radiator cooling and interior a/c ducts, integrated seat /shoulder belts in coupe.
