First year with OBD II diagnostics. |- style="text-align:right;" | rowspan=2|1997||rowspan=2|9,752|| style="text-align:left;" rowspan="2"|'''Fifth generation (C5) begins'''; [[GM LS1 engine|LS1]] engine is new; the [[hatchback]] [[coupé]] is the only body style offered. |- ! rowspan=9|C5 |- style="text-align:right;" |1998||31,084||align=left|Convertible C5 debuts with the first trunk in a Corvette convertible since 1962; [[pace car#Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis 500 Pace Car]] replica offered; [[Chevrolet Corvette C5 Z06#Active Handling|Active Handling System]] introduced as optional equipment. |- style="text-align:right;" |1999||33,270||align=left|Less-expensive [[hardtop]] coupé is offered. |- style="text-align:right;" |2000||33,682||align=left|Newly styled alloy wheels debut. |- style="text-align:right;" |2001||35,627||align=left|Hardtop coupé body style becomes top-performance Z06, utilizing the new [[GM LS6 engine|LS6]] engine and suspension improvements; [[Chevrolet Corvette C5 Z06#Active Handling|Second-Generation Active Handling System]] becomes standard equipment on all models; slight ({{convert|5|bhp|kW|abbr=on}}) increase in base model engine power. |- style="text-align:right;" |2002||35,767||align=left|{{convert|20|bhp|kW|abbr=on}} increase for the Z06 to 405 bhp. |- style="text-align:right;" |2003||35,469||align=left|50th Anniversary Edition package offered for Coupe and Convertible base models; F55 Magnetic Selective Ride Control Suspension supersedes F45 Selective Ride Control Suspension as base-model option. |- style="text-align:right;" |2004||34,064||align=left |24 Hours of Le Mans Commemorative Edition package offered for all models. |- align=right |rowspan=2|2005||rowspan=2|37,372|| style="text-align:left;" rowspan="2"|'''Sixth generation (C6) begins'''; New body is first with fixed headlamps since 1962; no Z06 model and a late convertible introduction. |- ! rowspan=10|C6 |- align=right |2006||34,021||align=left|Z06 debuts; 6-speed automatic with paddle shift available on non-Z06 models. |- align=right |2007||40,561||align=left|6-speed automatic paddle shift delays are reduced drastically compared to 2006. |- align=right |2008||35,310||align=left|Mild freshening, LS3 introduced, All leather interior added (4LT, LZ3). |- align=right |2009||16,956||align=left|ZR1 model added, new "Spyder" wheels for Z06. |- align=right |2010||12,194||align=left|Grand Sport Coupe and Convertible added; replaces the Z51 performance package, launch control standard on MN6 models. |- align=right |2011||13,596||align=left|Wheel choices are updated; Larger cross-drilled brake rotors (13.4" front and 12.8" rear) available on Coupe and Convertible, or included with (F55) Magnetic Selective Ride Control. Z07 Performance Package introduced for Z06. |- align=right |2012||11,647||align=left|Upgraded interior and new tires on the base model. Z06 acquires full-length rear spoiler and a carbon fiber hood as options. ZR1 gets adjusted gears for better fuel economy. ZR1 Performance Package introduced, Z07 Performance Package tweaked with new wheels. |- align=right |2013||13,466||align=left|Introduction of "427 Convertible" model with a limited production run of 2,552 "427" units. 9 month production run. |- align=right |rowspan=2|2014||rowspan=2|37,288|| style="text-align:left;" rowspan="2"|'''Seventh generation (C7) begins'''; All new styling, chassis and drivetrain. LT1 6162 cc 376 ci had 455 hp (460 hp with performance exhaust). |- ! rowspan=6|C7 |- align=right |2015||34,240||align=left|C7 Z06 debuts with LT4 6162 cc 376 ci that had 650 hp. 8L90 eight-speed automatic transmission now available for all models. |- align=right |2016||40,689|| align="left" | |- align=right |2017||32,782|| align="left" |The C7 Grand sport was introduced with the LT1 in a Z06 body and chassis. |- align=right |2018||9,686|| align="left" | |- align=right |2019||34,822|| align="left" |The C7 ZR1 was introduced with a LT5 6162 cc 376 ci that had 755 hp. |- align=right | colspan=2|Total||1,741,410|| align="left" | |} == Owner demographics == According to research by [[Specialty Equipment Market Association]] and Experian Automotive, as of 2009, there were approximately 750,000 Corvettes of all model years registered in the United States. Corvette owners were fairly equally distributed throughout the country, with the highest density in Michigan (3.47 per 1000 residents) and the lowest density in Utah, Mississippi, and Hawaii (1.66, 1.63, and 1.53 registrations per 1000 residents). 47% of them hold college degrees (significantly above the nationwide average of 27%), and 82% are between ages of 40 and 69 (median age being 53).{{cite web |url=http://www.sema.org/?q=node/1697 |title=Vette Owners Quick to Customize |publisher=SEMA |date=Jan 15, 2009 |accessdate=Sep 30, 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511072329/http://www.sema.org/?q=node%2F1697 |archivedate=2013-05-11 }} == Racing == === C5-R === {{Main|Chevrolet Corvette C5-R}} [[File:C5R and Maserati.JPG|thumb|A Corvette C5-R leading a [[Maserati MC12]] in [[Motorsport Arena Oschersleben|Oschersleben]], [[Germany]]]] In 1960, three C-1 Corvettes were race modified and entered in the 24 Hours of Le Mans by team owner Briggs Cunningham and which were numbered #1, #2 and #3 cars in the race. The numbered #3 car was driven by John Fitch and Bob Grossman and it had finished the race in eighth place overall, but it had won the big bore GT class.{{cite web|url=https://www.motorsport.com/lemans/news/gm-racing-corvette-history-at-le-mans/|title=GM Racing - Corvette history at Le Mans|publisher=}} The Chevrolet Corvette C5-R is a grand touring racing car built by Pratt & Miller and General Motors for competition in endurance racing. The car is based on the C5 generation of the Chevrolet Corvette sports car, yet is designed purely for motorsports use.{{cite book|title=Popular Mechanics|year=1991|publisher=Hearst Magazines|issn=0032-4558|page=156|url=https://archive.org/details/bub_gb_KuYDAAAAMBAJ|quote=Chevrolet Corvette C5-R.}} It became one of the most dominant cars in GT categories, with wins at the 24 Hours of Daytona, 12 Hours of Sebring, and 24 Hours of Le Mans, as well as championships in the American Le Mans Series.{{cite book|title=Popular Mechanics|year=1999|publisher=Hearst Magazines|issn=0032-4558|page=156|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QWYEAAAAMBAJ&dq=Chevrolet+Corvette+C5-R}} The Corvette C5-Rs debuted in 1999 and continues to be raced to this day, although the C5-R has effectively been replaced by the Corvette C6.R.{{cite book|last=DeLorenzo|first=Matt|title=The Corvette Dynasty|year=2007|publisher=Chronicle Books|isbn=978-1-932855-82-1|page=160}} === C6.R === {{Main|Chevrolet Corvette C6.R}} [[File:C6-R 2009 ALMS LBGP.JPG|thumb|A GT1 C6.R on the back straight of [[Long Beach]], [[California]]]] '''C6.R GT1 (Z06)''' In 2005, the factory Corvette Team began racing the C6.R to coincide with the new sixth generation (C6) Corvette being released to the public. Private teams, primarily in Europe, continued to race the C5-R for a couple of years before switching to the C6.R. Corvette C6.R went on to win its class at every race it entered in the 2005 [[ALMS]] season.{{cite web|title=2011 Chevrolet Corvette Z06 Carbon vs. 2010 Corvette Grand Sport vs. 2002 Corvette Z06 Comparison Test and Video|url=http://www.insideline.com/chevrolet/corvette/2011/2002-chevrolet-corvette-z06-vs-2010-corvette-grand-sport-vs-2011-corvette-z06-carbon-comparison-test-and-video.html|accessdate=10 October 2012}} By the end of 2009, Corvette had clinched four consecutive ALMS GT1 team and manufacturers titles (2005–2008) and three [[Le Mans 24 Hour]] class victories in the LMGT1 category (2005, 2006, 2009). 2007 and 2008 races were won by the factory [[Aston Martin]] squad's [[DBR9]]. The last official race for factory GT1 Corvettes was the [[2009 24 Hours of Le Mans]].{{cite web|title=Pratt & Miller Engineering Introduces Corvette C6RS Supercar for the Street |url=http://www.prattmillerc6rs.com/pressrelease.htm |work=Corvette C6RS |accessdate=10 October 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130323040729/http://www.prattmillerc6rs.com/pressrelease.htm |archivedate=23 March 2013 }} '''C6.R GT2 (ZR1)''' While some privateers continued to use GT1 version of the C6.R in Europe, the official factory team [[Corvette Racing]] switched from the slowly dying GT1 category to the much more competitive and popular GT2 class in mid-2009. The new GT2 C6.R used a modified version of the [[Chevrolet Corvette C6 ZR1|ZR1]] model body, but does not have the ZR1 supercharged engine. GT2 rules are based more on production vehicles, therefore the GT2 C6.R naturally aspirated engine was considerably more restricted and less powerful than its predecessor. The car debuted at [[Mid-Ohio]]'s ALMS round. They achieved one ALMS race victory in the remaining 2009 ALMS season, and one victory at the final round of 2010 ALMS season, [[Petit Le Mans]]. Corvette Racing's two GT2 C6.Rs also led most of the [[2010 24 Hours of Le Mans]], but both cars were forced to retire. Racing in the new GTE Pro class, the C6.R raced in the [[2011 24 Hours of Le Mans]] with the No. 73 car taking the class victory. The No. 74 car led the class for most of the race but crashed in the morning hours. The C6.R raced by Larbre Competition also took the GTE Am class victory.{{cite web|last=Schilke|first=Nancy|title=Shanghai victory sees Larbre Competition crowned GTE Am world champions|url=http://www.motorsport.com/wec/news/shanghai-victory-sees-larbre-competition-crowned-gte-am-world-champions/|work=Race reports|accessdate=8 December 2012}} In 2012, Corvette Racing returned to glory in the ALMS winning 4 of 10 races and claiming the Driver's, Team, and Manufacturer's Championships. Corvette Racing repeated the feat in 2013 by winning 5 of 10 races and claiming the Driver's, Team and Manufacturer's Championships again. === C7.R === {{Main|Chevrolet Corvette C7.R}} [[File:FoS20162016 0624 123543AA (27608392390).jpg|thumb|A Corvette C7.R at the 2016 [[Goodwood Festival of Speed]]]] In 2014, Corvette Racing introduced the new C7.R to coincide with the launch of the seventh-generation C7 Corvette. The car made its on track debut at the 2013 Rolex Motorsports Reunion and later participated in the 2014 Roar Before the Rolex 24 to prepare for the 2014 [[United SportsCar Championship]]. The car's new livery was debuted at the 2014 [[North American International Auto Show]]. In 2015, the Corvette Racing C7.R took class victories at both the [[2015 24 Hours of Daytona|24 Hours of Daytona]] and the [[2015 24 Hours of Le Mans|24 Hours of Le Mans]]. === C8.R === {{Main|Chevrolet Corvette C8.R}} In October 2019, at the Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex, the C8.R made its surprise debut during the world premiere of the C8 Convertible. Two cars took part in the 2020 Rolex 24 at Daytona International Speedway. The cars placed 4th and 7th in the GTLM Class. === Indianapolis 500 pace cars === [[File:Bloomington gold 2007 04.jpg|thumb|2007 Corvette Indy 500 Pace Car]] A Corvette has been selected as the [[List of Indianapolis 500 pace cars|pace car]] at the [[Indianapolis 500]], 15 times.{{cite news | last = Bruce | first = Chris | title = Check Out The 15 Times The Chevy Corvette Has Paced The Indy 500 | publisher = [[Motorsport Network|Motor1.com]] | date = 2018-05-23 | url = https://www.motor1.com/features/242804/chevy-corvette-pace-car-list/ | access-date = 2019-01-18}} The 2008 edition of the Indy 500 represented a record fifth-consecutive year to lead the field until 2009 when the [[Chevrolet Camaro (fifth generation)|Chevrolet Camaro SS]] was selected. The Corvette's pace car years and details include: * 1978 – Driven by 1960 race winner [[Jim Rathmann]]; Chevrolet produced 6,502 production replicas. * 1986 – Driven by famed pilot [[Chuck Yeager]]; all 7,315 production convertibles were considered pace car convertibles and included official graphics (to be installed at the owner's discretion). * 1995 – Driven by then Chevrolet General Manager Jim Perkins; 527 production replicas produced. * 1998 – Driven by 1963 race winner [[Parnelli Jones]] when an injury prevented golfer [[Greg Norman]] from performing the duty; 1,158 production replicas produced. * 2002 – Driven by actor [[Jim Caviezel]]; no production replicas produced but graphics were available through SPO – approximately 300 sets sold. * 2004 – Driven by actor [[Morgan Freeman]]; no production replicas produced. * 2005 – Driven by [[General Colin Powell]]; no production replicas produced. * 2006 – Driven by cycling champion [[Lance Armstrong]] (prior to scandal); first [[Chevrolet Corvette C6|Corvette Z06]] pace car; no production replicas produced. * 2007 – Driven by actor [[Patrick Dempsey]]; 500 production replicas – all convertibles. * 2008 – Driven by [[Emerson Fittipaldi]]; 500 production replicas – coupes and convertibles. * 2012 – Driven by [[Guy Fieri]]; first [[Chevrolet Corvette C6 ZR1|Corvette C6 ZR1]] pace car; no production replicas produced. * 2013 – Driven by [[Jim Harbaugh]]; first year of production for C7 generation. * 2015 – Driven by [[Jeff Gordon]]; first [[Chevrolet Corvette C7 Z06]] pace car * 2017 – Driven by actor [[Jeffrey Dean Morgan]]; 2017 Grand Sport Convertible{{cite news|last1=Lindquist|first1=David|title=Indy 500 casts 'Walking Dead' villain for pace car|url=https://www.indystar.com/story/entertainment/2017/05/25/negan-twd-indianapolis-speedway-driver-celebrity-race-indycar/346834001/|accessdate=3 February 2018|work=Indianapolis Star|date=25 May 2017}} * 2018 - Driven by professional basketball player [[Victor Oladipo]] - Chevrolet Corvette C7 ZR1; no production replicas produced. * 2019 - Driven by [[NBC Sports]] broadcaster [[Dale Earnhardt, Jr.]] - last year of production for C7 generation; no production replicas produced. == See also == * [[Chevrolet Engineering Research Vehicle]] * [[Kaiser Darrin]], prototype in 1952, 435 built for 1954 model year * [[Nash-Healey]], 1951–1954 * [[National Corvette Museum]] * [[VH1 Corvette Give-away Sweepstakes]] (also known as the "VH1 Collection", 36 Corvettes, one for each model year, 1953-1989) * [[CorvetteForum]], the largest Corvette enthusiasts' club in the world == References == {{Reflist}} {{Refbegin}} * Nichols, Richard. ''Corvette: 1953 to the Present''. London: Bison Books, 1985. {{ISBN|0-86124-218-1}}. {{Refend}} == Further media == ; Videos: * {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cz7BHp8dlgg|title=Why Chevy Is Radically Changing The Corvette|publisher=[[CNBC]]|date=2019-09-11}} == External links == {{Commons category|Chevrolet Corvette}} * {{curlie|Recreation/Autos/Makes_and_Models/Chevrolet/Corvette/|Chevrolet Corvette}} * [http://www.chevrolet.com/corvette/ Chevrolet Corvette (North American site)] * [http://www.corvette-europe.com/ Corvette Europe] {{Corvette timeline}} {{Chevrolet vehicles}} [[Category:Chevrolet Corvette|*]] [[Category:1950s cars]] [[Category:1960s cars]] [[Category:1970s cars]] [[Category:1980s cars]] [[Category:1990s cars]] [[Category:2000s cars]] [[Category:2010s cars]] [[Category:2020s cars]] [[Category:Bowling Green, Kentucky]] [[Category:Chevrolet vehicles|Corvette]] [[Category:Coupés]] [[Category:Motor vehicles manufactured in the United States]] [[Category:Rear-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Roadsters]] [[Category:Sports cars]] [[Category:Hatchbacks]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 1953]] [[Category:Flagship vehicles]]

{{Infobox automobile | image = File:Chevrolet Monza CN RS 01 China 2019-03-28.jpg | caption = Chevrolet Monza (China) | name = Chevrolet Monza (China) |manufacturer = [[SAIC-GM]] | production = 2019–present | predecessor = [[Chevrolet Cavalier#China|Chevrolet Cavalier]]
[[Chevrolet Cruze]] | assembly = [[Wuhan]], China | class = [[Compact car|Compact]] | layout = [[FF layout]] | platform = GM-PATAC K | related = [[Buick Excelle GT]] | body_style = 4-door [[sedan (automobile)|sedan]] | engine = 1.0 L [[Straight-three engine|I3]] ([[turbo]] [[Petrol engine|petrol]])
1.3 L ''LIY'' [[Straight-three engine|I3]] (turbo petrol) | transmission = 6-speed [[manual transmission|manual]]
6-speed [[automatic transmission|automatic]]
6-speed [[Dual clutch transmission|DCT]] | wheelbase = {{convert|2640|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|4614|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} (320T models)
{{convert|4630|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} (330T models) | width = {{convert|1798|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | height = {{convert|1485|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|1225|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} (1.0 L manual)
{{convert|1245|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} (1.0 L dual clutch)
{{convert|1265|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} (1.3 L models) }} The '''Chevrolet Monza''' is a [[compact car|compact]] [[Sedan (automobile)|sedan]] produced by [[SAIC-GM]] under the [[Chevrolet]] brand. == History == [[File:Chevrolet Monza 005.jpg|thumb|left|Chevrolet Monza rear]] The vehicle debuted in November 2018 at the [[Auto Guangzhou|Guangzhou Auto Show]]. Since 21 March 2019, it is sold in [[China]]. It is built on the same platform that the [[Buick Excelle GT]] and the [[Buick GL6]] use.{{cite web|title=New Details About All-New Chevrolet Monza Sedan Emerge|periodical=gmauthority.com|url=http://gmauthority.com/blog/2019/01/new-details-about-all-new-chevrolet-monza-sedan-emerge/|accessdate=2019-04-17|first=Deivis | last = Centeno|date=2019-01-23 }} == Specifications == The Monza is available in two trim levels (the 320T and the 330T) and in five models overall. The 320T is available with a 1-litre turbocharged three-cylinder engine while the 330T gets a 1.3-litre turbocharged three-cylinder engine. 1-litre models receive either a 6-speed manual or a 6-speed [[Dual-clutch transmission|dual-clutch gearbox]] while the 1.3-litre models are only available with a 6-speed automatic gearbox.{{cite web | url= https://car.autohome.com.cn/config/spec/38389.html#pvareaid=3454541 | title=2019 Chevrolet Monza (China)}} === Engines === {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: center;" !Model !Engine !Power !Torque !Fuel economy |- |320T | rowspan="1" | 1.0-L I3 |{{convert|92|kW|hp|0|abbr=on}}
at 5600 rpm |{{convert|170|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}}
at 2000-4000 rpm |{{convert|5.2|l/100 km|mpgus|0|abbr=on}} |- |RS 330T | rowspan="1" | 1.3-L I3 |{{convert|120|kW|hp|0|abbr=on}}
at 5500 rpm |{{convert|230|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}}
at 1800-4400 rpm |{{convert|5.8|l/100 km|mpgus|0|abbr=on}} |} {{clear}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{Chevrolet vehicles}} [[Category:Cars of China]] [[Category:Chevrolet vehicles|Monza]] [[Category:Compact cars]] [[Category:Sedans]] [[Category:Cars introduced in 2019]] [[Category:2010s cars]]
